EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 122 closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Plenty of moisture ahead of a cold front moving across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys led to heavy rainfall. As much as 4 inches of rain fell during this event leading to some flash flooding across portions of western Virginia on the 16th of November.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding overwhelmed two culverts, causing them to collapse and damage sections of Middle Creek Road, and Jones Ridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system off the North Carolina coast coupled with an upper level cutoff low to dump intense rainfall across portions of southeast Virginia. Rainfall amounts in excess of 10 inches resulted in numerous road closures and moderate to major river flooding from late Friday October 6th through Saturday October 7th. Up to 28,000 Dominion Virginia Power customers lost power during the event. Moderate to severe coastal flooding also resulted in western portions of the southern Chesapeake Bay.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed county-wide by flooding due to 8-12 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep low pressure system moved from the Tennessee Valley to the eastern great Lakes on November 16, sweeping a strong cold front across the Mid Atlantic. This system brought widespread moderate to heavy rain to the region near sunrise, then strong thunderstorms around noon. These thunderstorms produced periods of heavier rainfall as well as gusty and isolated damaging winds. |Heavy rains began to spread northeast across the Shenandoah Valley during the mid morning hours. In Craigsville in Augusta County, a car was inundated by 3 to 4 feet of water and a water rescue was required due to flash flooding. A number of roads were closed in the western, southern and eastern portions of the county.|Thunderstorms embedded within this large area of rain became severe across Spotsylvania and Rockingham Counties as well as the City of Harrisonburg.  Several trees were downed due to thunderstorms in the western portion of Spotsylvania County. A wind gust of 52 knots was reported with thunderstorms in Rockingham County and a tree fell on a house during a thunderstorm in the City of Harrisonburg. Also in Harrisonburg, eight storm doors were blown off their hinges at a greenhouse business.|Minor flooding was reported on roadways across Fairfax County. In Huntington, VA, flooding was reported nearly 30 feet from a cluster of homes. No damage was reported, but several homes were evacuated as a precaution. Other small creeks across the county flooded due to the heavy rain.|In Prince William County, exit ramps on Interstate 95 were closed due to flooding. Roads remained closed due to flooding into the afternoon hours of November 17. US 1 in Woodbridge was closed when Neabsco Creek flooded.|In the City of Manassas, part of Lucasville Rd was covered by 1 to 2 feet of water after heavy rains moved through the area.|The Catoctin Creek flooded out of its banks near Purcellville, VA, in Loudoun County.|In Stafford County, flooding was reported at Boswells Corner on US 1 in North Stafford. |In Spotsylvania County, school buses were forced to return students to school due to flooding on county roadways between Massaponax Church and Leavells. .|There was a foot of standing water at the intersection of King and Union Streets in the City of Alexandria.|Several secondary roads were closed throughout Madison, Nelson, Rockingham, Shenandoah and Frederick Counties due to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car was inundated by 3 to 4 feet of water and a water rescue was required due to flash flooding in Craigsville, VA. A number of roads were closed in the western, southern and eastern portions of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system off the North Carolina coast coupled with an upper level cutoff low to dump intense rainfall across portions of southeast Virginia. Rainfall amounts in excess of 10 inches resulted in numerous road closures and moderate to major river flooding from late Friday October 6th through Saturday October 7th. Up to 28,000 Dominion Virginia Power customers lost power during the event. Moderate to severe coastal flooding also resulted in western portions of the southern Chesapeake Bay.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Road closed at intersection of Templeton and Lansing Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Since the 5th of October, rainfall to some degree had been falling over portions of southwest and south central Virginia. Rainfall amounts were on the order of four inches in the 48 hour period. On the 7th, a slow moving area of upper level low pressure helped to maintain a persistent area of heavy rain over this same region. Rainfall amounts were on the order of an additional 2 inches, which was enough to prompt flash flooding in Buckingham and Appomattox Counties. Also, with the ground now saturated, wind speeds of only 30 to 35 mph were able to down some trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State Route 611 was flooded and closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving, heavy rain producing thunderstorms caused flash flooding to take place over parts of the area. One of these storms also reached severe limits and uprooted some trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy rain producing thunderstorm prompted a small creek along Brookstone Road to significantly leave its banks.  Subsequently, a home ended up having water surrounding it at one point.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving, heavy rain producing thunderstorms caused flash flooding to take place over parts of the area. One of these storms also reached severe limits and uprooted some trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy rain producing thunderstorm prompted Browns Creek to leave its banks.  The result was portions of both Grove Avenue and Waterlick Road being flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front combined with an upper level low pressure system to trigger numerous showers and thunderstorms central and northern Virginia during the afternoon and evening of July 29th.  Several of these storms became severe, producing damaging winds and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law Enforcement reported water over the road at Teton Drive and Landsdowne Road south of the City of Fredericksburg. A mudslide was also reported on Route 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of persistent, heavy rain developed on the northwest side of an area of low pressure that tracked from western North Carolina to eastern Virginia. Across Botetourt County Virginia, this rainfall amounted to 2.00 to 3.00 inches from late in the day on the 14th into morning hours on the 15th. This amount of rain in a short period of time in an area with steep terrain, lead to a mud slice occurring a few miles north of Buchanan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 2 inch deep mud slide closed a portion of Route 43.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary combined with unseasonably high levels of atmospheric moisture brought widespread heavy rainfall to much of southside Virginia into the northwest piedmont of North Carolina from late December 31 through the early morning hours of January 1. Total rainfall amounts ranged from 1 to 3 inches in many areas, with locally higher amounts in excess of 4 inches. Due to antecedent wet conditions across much of the region, the majority of this rain (which fell over a short period of about 3 hours) ran off into local creeks and streams, prompting them to quickly leave their banks, as well as, prompted the flooding and subsequent closure of streets and roads.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding resulted in Route 29, Sandy Creek Road, and Mountain View Roads near Danville, VA to be closed. In Danville, the flash flooding prompted Fall Creek to leave its banks and flood portions of Halifax and Water Streets.  In the process, two homes and one church experienced some inundation by the water.  Other streets in Danville were closed due to the flash flooding as well.  The flash flooding in Danville ultimately lead to moderate river flooding along the Dan River in Danville.  In total, in Danville and neighboring parts of Pittsylvania County, 27 roads were closed due to the flash flooding and subsequent river flooding on the Dan River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary combined with unseasonably high levels of atmospheric moisture brought widespread heavy rainfall to much of southside Virginia into the northwest piedmont of North Carolina from late December 31 through the early morning hours of January 1. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many steets were closed in Ridgeway due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought one to three inches of rain in a short period of time to Henry County. This resulted in Flash Flooding in the Fieldale and Collinsville areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 329 was closed due to flooding. Also, water was observed up to the door at the YMCA in Collinsville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rains produced flash flooding in Montgomery and Pulaski counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains of 2 to 3 inches produced flash flooding in the Hiwassee section of Pulaski county. Several roads were flooded in Hiwassee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rains produced flash flooding in Montgomery and Pulaski counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads flooded and a couple of homes had water reach them. Sections of Hightop, Merrimac and Yellow Sulphur roads were among those that were temporarily impassible.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of the 10th.  Two of these strengthened to severe levels resulting in wind damage. Also, the storms were slow moving, and this allowed for instances of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused Long Branch Creek and Apple Branch Creek to leave their banks. No damage occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of the 10th.  Two of these strengthened to severe levels resulting in wind damage. Also, the storms were slow moving, and this allowed for instances of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy rain producing thunderstorm caused flooding of streets on the north side of the City of Roanoke.  Some of these roads were closed by city officials.  There were no reports of damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of the 10th.  Two of these strengthened to severe levels resulting in wind damage. Also, the storms were slow moving, and this allowed for instances of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A slowly moving thunderstorm produced four inches of rain which prompted Alabama Creek to leave its banks.  The water flooded Route 605.  No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain producing, slow moving thunderstorms helped to promote flash flooding over parts of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced two to three inches of rain over parts of Appomattox County.  This heavy rain prompted Phelps Creek to leave its banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain producing, slow moving thunderstorms helped to promote flash flooding over parts of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms over Campbell County produced heavy rain that prompted  Seneca Creek to leave its banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of slow moving thunderstorms tracked across the same region repeatedly during the late afternoon and early evening of the 24th. Locally heavy rain resulted, and in some cases, helped to prompt flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains resulted in six to eight inches of water flowing across Collins Ferry Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms brought heavy rains to western Tazewell county during the evening of August 2nd, 2007. Two to four inches of rain in two hours produced flash flooding in the town of Richlands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to four inches of rain caused flash flooding in the town of Richlands, Virginia, during the evening of August 2nd. This resulted in several road closures in the town, including U.S. Highway 460. A 4 to 5 foot boulder also washed onto the road near the Red Ash Campground. Several homes were impacted by mudslides, sustaining minor structural damage. Damage amounts are based on rough estimates.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain produced flash flooding over portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many roads were flooded across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two to four inches of rain created flash flooding in Henry county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Buildings were flooded on Memorial Boulevard and the 800 block of Forest Street Extension. Six residences were relocated to a motel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two to four inches of rain created flash flooding in Henry county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads closed near Martinsville. A Pipe was washed out along Route 657. A car stalled driving through high water on Smith Lake Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain produced flash flooding over portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain produced flash flooding over portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed county wide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain produced flash flooding over portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One person had to be rescued from a car on Hopkins Road due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding in southside Hampton Roads during rush hour. Several cars stalled in high water as rainwater accumulated in underpasses.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tidewater Drive underpasses were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding in southside Hampton Roads during rush hour. Several cars stalled in high water as rainwater accumulated in underpasses.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall totaling 3.95 inches in 3 hours,and 4.31 inches in 6 hours ending at 17:30 EST, prompted flash flooding in several locations in the City of Martinsville, VA.  Reeves Road was covered with water and mud.  Liberty Street and Royal Avenue were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moving over West Virginia pushed a strong cold front through the region during the early morning hours of March 5th. This front triggered several strong to severe thunderstorms with gusty winds as well as heavy rain. Several lines of thunderstorms crossed the region from the evening of March 4th through the early morning of March 5th. Heavy rain lead to several road closures due to flooding. Wind gusts in excess of 50 mph were measured at several locations, with a maximum wind gust of 74 mph measured at Reagan National Airport. There were numerous reports of trees and power lines down across central and northern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stafford County Emergency Management reported flash flooding along creeks running into the Rappahannock River. A water rescue performed in Falmouth.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The City of Charlottesville Emergency Management reported 1 foot of running water over the roadway. There was also a washout of a road under construction at th3 00th block of 15 St NW.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent bands of showers and embedded thunderstorms produced heavy rains which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of roads closed due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of roads closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heavy rain producing thunderstorm prompted flash flooding along Daniels Creek along Daniels Creek Road. At the height of the flash flooding, one foot of water was flowing across the road.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Damage values are estimates.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approached the Mid Atlantic during the evening of June 3. Warm, moist and unstable air developed ahead of the front, allowing scattered strong to severe thunderstorms to develop. Several reports of downed trees and power lines were received. A roof was also blown off a house in Warrenton. One thunderstorm produced heavy rainfall that resulted in flash flooding in Mitchells in Culpeper County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mitchell Road was closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna made landfall along the North Carolina/South Carolina border during the early morning of September 6th as a strong tropical storm. The system then proceeded to move rapidly north and then northeast along Interstate 95 reaching the southern Chesapeake Bay by the afternoon. The strongest winds with Hanna remained east of the center over eastern North Carolina and southeast Virginia while persistent bands of heavy rain developed east of the Blue Ridge. This axis of heavy rain persisted over much of the piedmont and foothills from the pre-dawn hours of Saturday morning through about midday. This resulted in impressive rainfall totals of between 3 and 6 inches in a narrow corridor over parts of the piedmont while a sharp gradient to an inch or less was seen closer to the eastern slopes of the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Turnip Creek flooded closing Route 619.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving across the Appalachians created 1 to 3 inches of rain which resulted in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with thunderstorms resulted in flash flooding in Smyth county. Several roads including Highway 91,42,and 16 were closed because of flooding. Sulphur Spring creek, Stanley creek, and Walker creek  |came out of their banks. Flash flooding occurred in the Marion, Sugar Grove, Chilhowie and Broadford areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought several inches of rain in a small amount of time, supporting flash flooding in the Seven Mile Ford area of Smyth County during the early afternoon of June 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains in a short amount of time caused flash flooding of Highway 11 in Seven Mile Ford. There was several feet of water running across Highway 11. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An uncharacteristic area of relatively cool low pressure moved southeast out of Canada into the region. Daytime heating due to sunshine combined with the relatively cooler low overhead and helped to result in a very unstable atmosphere. The result was the formation of thunderstorms with numerous reports of severe hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated two inches of rain fell in an hour between Floyd and the Blue Ridge Parkway.  The result was flash flooding along Dodds Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An uncharacteristic area of relatively cool low pressure moved southeast out of Canada into the region. Daytime heating due to sunshine combined with the relatively cooler low overhead and helped to result in a very unstable atmosphere. The result was the formation of thunderstorms with numerous reports of severe hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding along Back Creek prompted the closure of Highway 116 at Leslie.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large outflow boundary from an overnight thunderstorm complex moved through the region during the morning and early afternoon hours of July 22. This prevented thunderstorm development until early evening when storms started developing. Meanwhile, a line of thunderstorms approached the area from the west. Outflow from the first storms generated scattered clusters of storms across the northwest NC and southwest VA Piedmont up to the Blue Ridge, while the more organized line of storms moved into the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured three to five inches of rain in parts of Botetourt County, VA helped to produce flash flooding in Fincastle, VA.  The flash flooding prompted the closure of several roads in Botetourt County.  Route 220 had 3.5 feet of water on it, and many cars became stalled.  Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with Tropical Storm Hanna caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wilkerson Road closed between Skipwith Road and Daniels Road intersections. High water or partial closures reported on several other roads across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with Tropical Storm Hanna caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 651 at Cales Drive was flooded. Also, portions of Bumpass and Willow Brook roads were flooded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads, including Route 627 (Hixburg Road) and Route 757 (South Fork Road) were flooded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 644 closed from Davenport Road to Stony Point Road. High water or partial closures reported on several other roads.

The system then proceeded to move rapidly north and then northeast along Interstate 95 reaching the southern Chesapeake Bay by the afternoon. The strongest winds with Hanna remained east of the center over eastern North Carolina and southeast Virginia while persistent bands of heavy rain developed east of the Blue Ridge. This axis of heavy rain persisted over much of the piedmont and foothills from the pre-dawn hours of Saturday morning through about midday. This resulted in impressive rainfall totals of between 3 and 6 inches in a narrow corridor over parts of the piedmont while a sharp gradient to an inch or less was seen closer to the eastern slopes of the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Due to widespread creek flooding, Route 24 was flooded in several locations between Concord and Rustburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna tracked up the Mid-Atlantic coast on the 6th with maximum sustained winds around 50 mph. Hanna originally made landfall near the border of North and South Carolina around 3:20 AM on the 6th. Hanna tracked across eastern North Carolina during the early afternoon hours before turning northeast across southeastern Virginia later in the afternoon. Hanna eventually tracked across the Chesapeake Bay and into Delaware during the evening hours. With the track of Hanna being to the east, the strongest winds were also confined to our east. However, Hanna was still responsible for heavy rain along with Tropical Storm force winds across northern and central Virginia. Rainfall amounts totaled around 4 to 8 inches across many locations with locally higher amounts over 9 inches. Numerous roads were closed throughout northern and central Virginia due to flash flooding. Tropical Storm force winds were responsible for downed trees and power lines across northern and central Virginia as well. The worst conditions occurred during the late morning and afternoon hours as the storm passed by just to the east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rolling Road was closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna tracked up the Mid-Atlantic coast on the 6th with maximum sustained winds around 50 mph. Hanna originally made landfall near the border of North and South Carolina around 3:20 AM on the 6th. Hanna tracked across eastern North Carolina during the early afternoon hours before turning northeast across southeastern Virginia later in the afternoon. Hanna eventually tracked across the Chesapeake Bay and into Delaware during the evening hours. With the track of Hanna being to the east, the strongest winds were also confined to our east. However, Hanna was still responsible for heavy rain along with Tropical Storm force winds across northern and central Virginia. Rainfall amounts totaled around 4 to 8 inches across many locations with locally higher amounts over 9 inches. Numerous roads were closed throughout northern and central Virginia due to flash flooding. Tropical Storm force winds were responsible for downed trees and power lines across northern and central Virginia as well. The worst conditions occurred during the late morning and afternoon hours as the storm passed by just to the east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding closed a road near Neabsco Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna made landfall along the North Carolina/South Carolina border during the early morning of September 6th as a strong tropical storm. The system then proceeded to move rapidly north and then northeast along Interstate 95 reaching the southern Chesapeake Bay by the afternoon. The strongest winds with Hanna remained east of the center over eastern North Carolina and southeast Virginia while persistent bands of heavy rain developed east of the Blue Ridge. This axis of heavy rain persisted over much of the piedmont and foothills from the pre-dawn hours of Saturday morning through about midday. This resulted in impressive rainfall totals of between 3 and 6 inches in a narrow corridor over parts of the piedmont while a sharp gradient to an inch or less was seen closer to the eastern slopes of the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A five foot diameter by 40 foot long pipe was washed out on Route 732, making the road impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Fay moved slowly up the west side of the Appalachian mountains and interacted with a frontal boundary just to our south. The heavier rains caused flash flooding over southern sections of Pittsylvania County during the afternoon of August 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sandy Creek flooded a portion of Hillside Road. One foot of water running across the road resulted in a closure of the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains from thunderstorms produced flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed due to high water or debris in the road across much of north central Chesterfield county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms, some severe, brought torrential rains to portions of Southwest Virginia, during the evening of May 8th, into the morning of May 9th. Up to 5 inches of rain fell in a few locations, leading to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flyblow Creek flooded a portion of Route 618/Farmers Road, one mile west of Renan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna made landfall along the North Carolina/South Carolina border during the early morning of September 6th as a strong tropical storm. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Whitefall Road closed due to flooding of tributaries to the Bannister River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved up the Mid-Atlantic coast on the 19th, bringing rain to central Virginia. A deep easterly flow ahead of this system allowed for copious amounts of moisture to move into the region causing the rain to be heavy at times. This resulted in an isolated flash flood event in Albemarle County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue was needed on Burchs Creek Road due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary was draped across southwest Virginia during the evening of May 14th and slowly drifted south toward the North Carolina border May 15th. Showers with embedded thunderstorms slowly moved along this boundary, setting up a training of heavy rains. This caused flash flooding over portions of southwest Virginia from the New River Valley east into the Piedmont.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive rainfall in a short amount of time caused urban flash flooding along North Franklin Street, in Christiansburg. The water reached a depth of 3 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving into the region helped trigger showers and thunderstorms. Some of the storms were slow movers, bring torrential rains in a short amount of time. This caused flash flooding over portions of southwest Virginia during the afternoon and early evening of May 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive rainfall caused flash flooding along Iron Ridge Road. A sinkhole formed as a result of the flooding, closing the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary was draped across southwest Virginia during the evening of May 14th and slowly drifted south toward the North Carolina border May 15th. This caused flash flooding over portions of southwest Virginia from the New River Valley east into the Piedmont.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Elk Creek flooded a portion of Bellevue Road, in eastern Bedford County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains produced a mudslide along Highway 24 in the Yellow Branch community.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local stream flooded a portion of Bells Mill Road, 4 miles south of Goode.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flat Creek flooded and closed Dearborn Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were flooded by Buffalo Creek in the Timberlake area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of the Virginia Eastern Shore.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported on Fisher road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of the Virginia Eastern Shore.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Considerable flooding was reported on Chincoteague Road (Route 175).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms associated with a trough of low pressure produced damaging winds and large hail across portions of central and eastern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous local roads were flooded on Gwynn Island.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple slow moving thunderstorms moved across the City of Roanoke. The result was an accumulation of heavy rains which lead to significant flash flooding within the city.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flooding across Shenandoah Avenue between 18th and 11th street with road closures at 18th and 11th street. Damage values estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple slow moving thunderstorms moved across the City of Roanoke. The result was an accumulation of heavy rains which lead to significant flash flooding within the city.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rains prompted flash flooding that resulted in one foot of water flowing across Starkey Road. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple slow moving thunderstorms moved across the City of Roanoke. The result was an accumulation of heavy rains which lead to significant flash flooding within the city.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding prompted Ore Branch to leave its banks.  The area of Franklin Road and Brandon Avenue was flooded. The flash flooding caused the Ramada Inn in the 1900 block of Franklin Road to have its parking lot inundated.  Numerous cars in the parking lot were floating in the water. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple slow moving thunderstorms moved across the City of Roanoke. The result was an accumulation of heavy rains which lead to significant flash flooding within the city.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains prompted flash flooding along Mud Lick Creek. Portions of Mudlick Road and Edgewood streets were flooded, prompting closure of the roads. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple slow moving thunderstorms moved across the City of Roanoke. The result was an accumulation of heavy rains which lead to significant flash flooding within the city.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains helped to produce a small mudslide along U.S. Highway 221 near Poages Mill. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple slow moving thunderstorms moved across the City of Roanoke. The result was an accumulation of heavy rains which lead to significant flash flooding within the city.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain prompted flash flooding on Campbell Ave. between 9th and 10th Streets. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled boundary remained over the area triggering showers and thunderstorms. Locally heavy amounts of rain in a short period time lead to isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over 5 inches of rain in Elkton caused 6 to 12 inches of water to flow over East Point Road along a corridor from River Road to Bethel Church Road to Florist Road to Stephen Conrad Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front combined with plenty of instability to trigger showers and thunderstorms on the 3rd. With plenty of moisture in place, some thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain which lead to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was stuck in the water at the corner of Braeburn Drive and Guinea Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front combined with plenty of instability to trigger showers and thunderstorms on the 3rd. With plenty of moisture in place, some thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain which lead to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brock Road near American Legion Road was closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front combined with plenty of instability to trigger showers and thunderstorms on the 3rd. With plenty of moisture in place, some thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain which lead to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flowing water 9 to 12 inches high was located on Route 50.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front combined with plenty of instability to trigger showers and thunderstorms on the 3rd. With plenty of moisture in place, some thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain which lead to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Centerville Road near Route 267 was closed due to flash flooding and cars were flooded on Elden Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled boundary triggered showers and thunderstorms on the 28th. Some thunderstorms produced locally heavy rainfall which resulted in an isolated case of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: U.S. 50 eastbound was closed from high water near Hogue Creek. Indian Hollow Road was also closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture remaining in place, along with a weak and slow moving frontal, kept the region in high risk of flash flooding, due to the recent heavy rains. Isolated flash flooding occurred across Montgomery and Carroll Counties during May 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Elliott Creek flooded and closed one lane of Union Valley Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture remaining in place, along with a weak and slow moving frontal, kept the region in high risk of flash flooding, due to the recent heavy rains. Isolated flash flooding occurred across Montgomery and Carroll Counties during May 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tributary of Wilson Creek flooded and closed Jennelle Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture remaining in place, along with a weak and slow moving frontal, kept the region in high risk of flash flooding, due to the recent heavy rains. Isolated flash flooding occurred across Montgomery and Carroll Counties during May 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: After 3 to 4 inches of rain, Chestnut Creek flooded a small portion of Chestnut Drive, close to 2 miles south of Galax.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture remaining in place, along with a weak and slow moving frontal, kept the region in high risk of flash flooding, due to the recent heavy rains. Isolated flash flooding occurred across Montgomery and Carroll Counties during May 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: After 3 to 4 inches of rain, Wards Mill Branch flooded a small portion of Coal Creek Road, close to 2 miles south-southeast of Galax.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving into the region helped trigger showers and thunderstorms. Some of the storms were slow movers, bring torrential rains in a short amount of time. This caused flash flooding over portions of southwest Virginia during the afternoon and early evening of May 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive rain caused a rock slide on Highway 52N near Fancy Gap.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving into the region helped trigger showers and thunderstorms. Some of the storms were slow movers, bring torrential rains in a short amount of time. This caused flash flooding over portions of southwest Virginia during the afternoon and early evening of May 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tributary into Little Cranberry Creek flooded a part of Hebron Road. Meanwhile, Little Cranberry Creek flooded a portion of Glendale Road in the same area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving into the region helped trigger showers and thunderstorms. Some of the storms were slow movers, bring torrential rains in a short amount of time. This caused flash flooding over portions of southwest Virginia during the afternoon and early evening of May 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Jerry Run flooded Route 688 near Bacova.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary was in the area, with a moist air mass in place. A thunderstorm slowly moved across central Patrick County, and brought torrential rains, and a flash flood to a small area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Grassy Branch flooded, causing three 48 inch metal pipes to wash out underneath Anthony Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture remaining in place, along with a weak and slow moving frontal, kept the region in high risk of flash flooding, due to the recent heavy rains. Isolated flash flooding occurred across Montgomery and Carroll Counties during May 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused urban street flooding along College Street in Christiansburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture remaining in place, along with a weak and slow moving frontal, kept the region in high risk of flash flooding, due to the recent heavy rains. Isolated flash flooding occurred across Montgomery and Carroll Counties during May 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Crab Creek flooded a few streets in the Cambria area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture remaining in place, along with a weak and slow moving frontal, kept the region in high risk of flash flooding, due to the recent heavy rains. Isolated flash flooding occurred across Montgomery and Carroll Counties during May 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Crab Creek flooded and closed Crab Creek Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture remaining in place, along with a weak and slow moving frontal, kept the region in high risk of flash flooding, due to the recent heavy rains. Isolated flash flooding occurred across Montgomery and Carroll Counties during May 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tributary of Wilson Creek partially washed out and closed Yellow Sulphur Road near Christiansburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture remaining in place, along with a weak and slow moving frontal, kept the region in high risk of flash flooding, due to the recent heavy rains. Isolated flash flooding occurred across Montgomery and Carroll Counties during May 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cedar Run flooded and closed Cedar Run Road, near Blacksburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was up to one foot of water covering parts of Darbytown, Monichan and Charles City Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several businesses were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated Thunderstorm produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of Mecklenburg county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets were closed due to heavy rain in downtown South Hill.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary ran from central Indiana, on southeast, across southeast Kentucky and into southwest Virginia. Clusters of showers and thunderstorms rode southeast along this boundary.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rains of 1 to 2 inches fell over wet soils during the late morning into the early afternoon, causing small streams to flood roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary ran from central Indiana, on southeast, across southeast Kentucky and into southwest Virginia. Clusters of showers and thunderstorms rode southeast along this boundary.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Another round of showers and thunderstorms moved through during the late afternoon.  This caused minor stream flooding.  Some of the same roads that were blocked earlier in the day, were flooded again.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorm in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of Southampton county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Section of State Highway 186 was flooded and partially closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets were flooded and partially closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gracie Road and State Highway 407 were flooded. Numerous vehicles were floating in flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Westbound Route 264 at the downtown tunnel was closed from Norfolk to Portsmouth due to a flooded roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Road was flooded at South Brambleton Road and Kimball Terrace near the Exit 11A interchange of Interstate 264.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed from flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of eastern and southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads were flooded in numerous locations downtown, including the Ghent area and in the vicinity of Old Dominion University. There was 1.5 to 2.5 feet of water over roads and major intersections were closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of eastern and southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A portion of Lombardy Road was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front in the Tennessee valley region continued to aid in the development of very heavy rainfall that contributed to flash flooding across southeast through northeast Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported with several inches of water over the road along Highway 612, making the road impassable due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front in the Tennessee valley region continued to aid in the development of very heavy rainfall that contributed to flash flooding across southeast through northeast Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along Virginia highway 782, with the road impassable due to at least a foot of water across the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure riding along a stalled boundary triggered rain and thunderstorms. Heavy amounts of rain in a short period of time lead to flash flooding across portions northern and central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was reported from Gum Springs Road and Route 50 to Evergreen Mills Road and Arcola Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure riding along a stalled boundary triggered rain and thunderstorms. Heavy amounts of rain in a short period of time lead to flash flooding across portions northern and central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was over the roadway on Route 110 at Memorial Drive and George Washington Parkway at Memorial Bridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure riding along a stalled boundary triggered rain and thunderstorms. Heavy amounts of rain in a short period of time lead to flash flooding across portions northern and central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lawyers Road at Hunters Station Road was closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure riding along a stalled boundary triggered rain and thunderstorms. Heavy amounts of rain in a short period of time lead to flash flooding across portions northern and central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Edwards Ferry Road near the Leesburg Bypass was closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure riding along a stalled boundary triggered rain and thunderstorms. Heavy amounts of rain in a short period of time lead to flash flooding across portions northern and central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Walney Road near Route 28 was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system over the Ohio Valley produced showers and thunderstorms over the mid-Atlantic. With saturated ground, early morning heavy rain produced flooding across portions of northern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lucasville Road at Hersch Farm Lane closed due to ponded water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance passed through the region during the heating of the afternoon. The result was the formation of thunderstorms...some of which reached severe criteria producing hail ranging from penny to quarter size and damaging winds. Very heavy rain also accompanied the storms. One location experienced flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy thunderstorm rains caused Turkey Fork to flow out of its banks along Spring Valley Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system over the Ohio Valley produced showers and thunderstorms over the mid-Atlantic. With saturated ground, early morning heavy rain produced flooding across portions of northern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fleetwood Road was closed Between Hazelwood Road and the Fauquier County line due to ponding on the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system over the Ohio Valley produced showers and thunderstorms over the mid-Atlantic. With saturated ground, early morning heavy rain produced flooding across portions of northern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bristerburg Road was closed at the 11900 Block due to ponding on the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the third day of having a tropical air mass over the region. The two days prior to this, there had been areas that received torrential rains. On this day, the low level flow had veered more to the southwest, and a cold front was approaching from the west. Thunderstorms moved into the mountains during the evening and overnight. The high rainfall rates associated with these storms caused flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Urban street flooding took place in Radford, along 2nd street. The street was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the third day of having a tropical air mass over the region. The two days prior to this, there had been areas that received torrential rains. On this day, the low level flow had veered more to the southwest, and a cold front was approaching from the west. Thunderstorms moved into the mountains during the evening and overnight. The high rainfall rates associated with these storms caused flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mudslide occurred on Arch Eaton Road, near Staffordsville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary was draped across southwest Virginia during the evening of May 14th and slowly drifted south toward the North Carolina border May 15th. Showers with embedded thunderstorms slowly moved along this boundary, setting up a training of heavy rains. This caused flash flooding over portions of southwest Virginia from the New River Valley east into the Piedmont.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: As much as 4 inches of rain in a two hour period caused flash flooding of Crab Creek. The flooding was observed from its headwaters east of Highway 460, west toward Vickers Switch and Walton. Several roads were closed, and several basements and a business were flooded, mainly in the Cambria section of Christiansburg. A mobile home in Walton sustained minor flood damage, and a vehicle also sustained water damage. Flood waters also caused one townhouse to slide off its foundation on Gold Leaf Drive.||Monetary damages are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the third day of having a tropical air mass over the region. The two days prior to this, there had been areas that received torrential rains. On this day, the low level flow had veered more to the southwest, and a cold front was approaching from the west. Thunderstorms moved into the mountains during the evening and overnight. The high rainfall rates associated with these storms caused flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains in the town of Dublin caused street flooding, particularly along 5th street. Some basements were flooded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tributary of Back Creek flooded the intersection of Black Hollow Road, and Montague Road, about two and a half miles west-northwest of Dublin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small stream that flows into the New River, flooded Highland Road, almost 2 miles north-northwest of Fairlawn. This road was closed.

The high rainfall rates associated with these storms caused flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rockslide occurred along Highway 42 near White Gate, closing the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the third day of having a tropical air mass over the region. The two days prior to this, there had been areas that received torrential rains. On this day, the low level flow had veered more to the southwest, and a cold front was approaching from the west. Thunderstorms moved into the mountains during the evening and overnight. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mudslide closed Federal Street in Rich Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorm produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of Suffolk.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was reported at the 3800 Block of Whaleyville Boulevard in Whaleyville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms along a warm frontal boundary produced rainfall of 1 to 2 inches in less than 2 hours in western Tazewell County during the late morning of June 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 6 and 12 inches of rapidly flowing water was observed at Highway 19 and 460 in Claypool Hill and flooding also was reported on Highway 460 at Richlands and at Raven. Roads were closed for one hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level disturbance combined with a surface boundary to trigger showers and thunderstorms during the evening hours of the 2nd. This activity lasted into the early morning hours of the 3rd. Thunderstorms were able to tap into high amounts of instability to produce locally heavy rainfall. Isolated areas of flash flooding resulted from the heavy rain across the Virginia Piedmont.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing over Courthouse and Piedmont Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level disturbance combined with a surface boundary to trigger showers and thunderstorms during the evening hours of the 2nd. This activity lasted into the early morning hours of the 3rd. Thunderstorms were able to tap into high amounts of instability to produce locally heavy rainfall. Isolated areas of flash flooding resulted from the heavy rain across the Virginia Piedmont.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The road was closed at the intersection of West Catharpin and West Pamunkey.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front was sinking south through Kentucky and southwest Virginia on the 4th.  Slow moving thunderstorms formed across Kentucky and moved through Dickenson County late in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Localized downpours of 1 to 2 inches fell in less than an hour.  The area was wet from rains of the previous day.  Water flowed off hillsides and carried debris onto roads.  Georges Fork flooded Route 83 near the mouth of Cooks Fork.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain in a short amount of time, produced flash flooding of a tributary that flows into Powder Mill Creek shortly after midnight on May 7th. This flooded School Board Road, with 12 to 18 inches of water running across it.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain in a short amount of time, caused a tributary of Powder Mill Creek to flood. This brought 12 to 18 inches of water across School Board Road, resulting in its closure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving into the region helped trigger showers and thunderstorms. Some of the storms were slow movers, bring torrential rains in a short amount of time. This caused flash flooding over portions of southwest Virginia during the afternoon and early evening of May 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falling Spring Creek flooded a portion of Highway 220, near the Bath and Alleghany County line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled surface front on June 4th near the North Carolina-Virginia border became the focus for heavy rainfall and embedded thunderstorms. Several severe storms developed along the boundary. These storms produced some high winds and penny-sized hail along with the heavy rain. Precipitation was heaviest over the southeast portion of the forecast area with a widespread 2 to 4 inches of rain over southern Pittsylvania and much of Halifax counties. Another 2 to 3.5 inches fell across parts of Patrick, Henry and Franklin counties. A number of roads were closed due to flooding although there was no serious damage reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of water was flowing across River St. in Danville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled surface front on June 4th near the North Carolina-Virginia border became the focus for heavy rainfall and embedded thunderstorms. Several severe storms developed along the boundary. These storms produced some high winds and penny-sized hail along with the heavy rain. Precipitation was heaviest over the southeast portion of the forecast area with a widespread 2 to 4 inches of rain over southern Pittsylvania and much of Halifax counties. Another 2 to 3.5 inches fell across parts of Patrick, Henry and Franklin counties. A number of roads were closed due to flooding although there was no serious damage reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 2 to 2.5 inches in several hours caused more than six inches of water to flow across Front Street in the town of Richlands.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled surface front on June 4th near the North Carolina-Virginia border became the focus for heavy rainfall and embedded thunderstorms. Precipitation was heaviest over the southeast portion of the forecast area with a widespread 2 to 4 inches of rain over southern Pittsylvania and much of Halifax counties. Another 2 to 3.5 inches fell across parts of Patrick, Henry and Franklin counties. A number of roads were closed due to flooding although there was no serious damage reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from heavy rains caused Pine Run to flood portions of Gap of the Road and Swallow Hollow Road west of Wytheville. A camper trailer was carried a small distance in a creek hollow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous showers and storms developed during the morning hours. Some of these storms reached severe levels in parts of Virginia. Locally heavy rain also accompanied some of the storms with flash flooding the outcome in one location.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused a creek to leave its banks and flood a part of Deyerle Road. Damage values estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous showers and storms developed during the morning hours. Some of these storms reached severe levels in parts of Virginia. Locally heavy rain also accompanied some of the storms with flash flooding the outcome in one location.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wiley Drive was closed due to flash flooding. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous showers and storms developed during the morning hours. Some of these storms reached severe levels in parts of Virginia. Locally heavy rain also accompanied some of the storms with flash flooding the outcome in one location.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mudlick Road near Brandon Avenue was closed due to flash flooding. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous showers and storms developed during the morning hours. Some of these storms reached severe levels in parts of Virginia. Locally heavy rain also accompanied some of the storms with flash flooding the outcome in one location.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Campbell Ave between 9th and 10th Streets was closed due to flash flooding. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous showers and storms developed during the morning hours. Some of these storms reached severe levels in parts of Virginia. Locally heavy rain also accompanied some of the storms with flash flooding the outcome in one location.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along a creek that borders Mudlick Road.  Water covered one lane of traffic. Damage values estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled surface front on June 4th near the North Carolina-Virginia border became the focus for heavy rainfall and embedded thunderstorms. Several severe storms developed along the boundary. These storms produced some high winds and penny-sized hail along with the heavy rain. Precipitation was heaviest over the southeast portion of the forecast area with a widespread 2 to 4 inches of rain over southern Pittsylvania and much of Halifax counties. Another 2 to 3.5 inches fell across parts of Patrick, Henry and Franklin counties. A number of roads were closed due to flooding although there was no serious damage reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 11 flooded in several locations west of Rural Retreat and the intersection of Highway 90 and Route 11 was under deep water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large complex of thunderstorms pushed from Tennessee and Kentucky into the western forecast area by late afternoon of June 11th. With moderate instability and a moist air mass in place storms became severe across western Virginia and some storms produced heavy rainfall. Rainfall across parts of Wythe, Pulaski and western Montgomery ranged from 1 to 3 inches in a couple of hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water from Pine Run Branch reported flowing across Kirby Road near Draper.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large complex of thunderstorms pushed from Tennessee and Kentucky into the western forecast area by late afternoon of June 11th. With moderate instability and a moist air mass in place storms became severe across western Virginia and some storms produced heavy rainfall. Rainfall across parts of Wythe, Pulaski and western Montgomery ranged from 1 to 3 inches in a couple of hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two feet of water from Peak Creek flooded portions or Dora Highway near Heritage Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large complex of thunderstorms pushed from Tennessee and Kentucky into the western forecast area by late afternoon of June 11th. With moderate instability and a moist air mass in place storms became severe across western Virginia and some storms produced heavy rainfall. Rainfall across parts of Wythe, Pulaski and western Montgomery ranged from 1 to 3 inches in a couple of hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding from Connellys Run closed a portion of Rock Road near Longs Trailer Park.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 42 closed by flooding near White Gate.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 602 near Shady Grove was closed at Bluewing Creek due to water flowing over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple slow moving thunderstorms moved across the City of Roanoke. The result was an accumulation of heavy rains which lead to significant flash flooding within the city.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains prompted flash flooding that caused the intersection of Boulevard St. and Patterson Ave to be flooded and closed. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorm produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of Hampton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were at least 6 roads closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A supercell storm, formed over eastern Buckingham County during the evening hours of June 26th. This storm persisted or regenerated over a duration of almost 4 hours and produced large hail and strong winds. The radar rainfall estimates were between 2 and 4 inches which resulted in isolated flash flooding on Little Georgia Creek.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water from Little Georgia Creek was over Route 720 about 1 foot deep and the road was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large complex of thunderstorms pushed from Tennessee and Kentucky into the western forecast area by late afternoon of June 11th. With moderate instability and a moist air mass in place storms became severe across western Virginia and some storms produced heavy rainfall. Rainfall across parts of Wythe, Pulaski and western Montgomery ranged from 1 to 3 inches in a couple of hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding and runoff along McGavock Run led to 7 to 10 inches of water flowing over Peppers Ferry Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large complex of thunderstorms pushed from Tennessee and Kentucky into the western forecast area by late afternoon of June 11th. With moderate instability and a moist air mass in place storms became severe across western Virginia and some storms produced heavy rainfall. Rainfall across parts of Wythe, Pulaski and western Montgomery ranged from 1 to 3 inches in a couple of hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred along Draper Valley Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Fairly strong upper level winds from the west-northwest and a stationary boundary stretching from Missouri to South Carolina set the stage for severe storms late on the 15th. These storms also produced heavy rain into the early morning of June 16th.|Rainfall totals ranged from 2 to 4 inches across parts of the upper Yadkin and Dan River basins.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding from the Ararat River along parts of Highway 104 to the state line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Fairly strong upper level winds from the west-northwest and a stationary boundary stretching from Missouri to South Carolina set the stage for severe storms late on the 15th. These storms also produced heavy rain into the early morning of June 16th.|Rainfall totals ranged from 2 to 4 inches across parts of the upper Yadkin and Dan River basins.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported on Mill House Road in Woolwine.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Fairly strong upper level winds from the west-northwest and a stationary boundary stretching from Missouri to South Carolina set the stage for severe storms late on the 15th. These storms also produced heavy rain into the early morning of June 16th.|Rainfall totals ranged from 2 to 4 inches across parts of the upper Yadkin and Dan River basins.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water reported over West Ridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Fairly strong upper level winds from the west-northwest and a stationary boundary stretching from Missouri to South Carolina set the stage for severe storms late on the 15th. These storms also produced heavy rain into the early morning of June 16th.|Rainfall totals ranged from 2 to 4 inches across parts of the upper Yadkin and Dan River basins.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Millers Creek Road close due to water over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating combined with a typical summertime moist and unstable air mass to allow for isolated late afternoon convection to develop over the higher elevations of northwest Virginia. Easterly flow at the low levels helped raised precipitable water values and lower storm motion enough to produce isolated flash flooding over the central Shenandoah Valley during the evening as the thunderstorms drifted eastward over lower elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many roads were closed in Woodstock as a result of high water or debris from flash flooding. At least 6 basements were flooded and had to be pumped. IFLOWS gauge at Burnshire Dam reported 5.24 inches of rain in 3 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary across the Tennessee valley provided the necessary lift and instability for showers and thunderstorms to develop across the area. Several areas of thunderstorms continued to continually move across southwest Virginia, resulting in flash flooding across portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was occurring with several inches of water over Lee Highway in Bristol, Virginia, producing street flooding in several areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary across the Tennessee valley provided the necessary lift and instability for showers and thunderstorms to develop across the area. Several areas of thunderstorms continued to continually move across southwest Virginia, resulting in flash flooding across portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported with several inches of water over highways 23/58/421 in Gate City, Virginia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary across the Tennessee valley provided the necessary lift and instability for showers and thunderstorms to develop across the area. Several areas of thunderstorms continued to continually move across southwest Virginia, resulting in flash flooding across portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was occurring with water measured a foot deep flowing across Highway 75.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: September 25-26 saw a slow-moving boundary move into a tropical air mass. This resulted in widespread rain over the entire region, with rainfall totals ranging from 1 to 3 inches. A daily rainfall record for the 26th was set at Roanoke Airport 2.23 (old record 1.82 set in 1956) and Blacksburg 1.74 (old record 0.94 in 1989).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mudslide was reported on Nash Hill Road and water was reported to be rushing over Piney Mill Branch Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary front across the Tennessee valley region continued to aid in the development of very heavy rainfall that contributed to flash flooding that developed into a longer term areal flood event across southwest Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred and eventually became an areal flood event, as several streams flooded out of their banks across much of Wise County. All roads near the streams county-wide had several inches of water over the road, either flowing across the road or water was standing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary front across the Tennessee valley region continued to aid in the development of very heavy rainfall that contributed to flash flooding that developed into a longer term areal flood event across southwest Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding developed into an areal flood event in the Norton, Virginia area. Numerous streets became impassable due to flooding, with water standing at around a foot in height in a few areas in Norton, Virginia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorm produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of Newport News.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to six inches of water was reported on I-64 Exit 255 off-ramp onto Jefferson Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains from a thunderstorm caused flash flooding in the city of Galax, with streets flooded and one home with water in it.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary thunderstorm formed over the northwest portion of Carroll County Virginia. Very heavy rain was produced by this storm, and flash flooding occurred as Brush Creek overflowed its banks and onto portions of Byllesby Road. A resident of Byllesby Road measured 5.70 inches of rain with this thunderstorm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of the Virginia Eastern Shore.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Atlantic road was flooded near Wallops Island. Four and a half inches of rain was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed due to an unstable atmosphere. Locally heavy amounts of rain in a short period of time lead to an isolated area of flash flooding in central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding lead to evacuations of less than 10 people from buildings in Scottsville. Town pumps near the James River Levee were beyond their capacity.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front combined with plenty of instability to trigger showers and thunderstorms on the 3rd. With plenty of moisture in place, some thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain which lead to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Standing water 2.5 feet high was located on Tall Cedars Parkway and Planting Field Drive in South Riding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large complex of thunderstorms pushed from Tennessee and Kentucky into the western forecast area by late afternoon of June 11th. With moderate instability and a moist air mass in place storms became severe across western Virginia and some storms produced heavy rainfall. Rainfall across parts of Wythe, Pulaski and western Montgomery ranged from 1 to 3 inches in a couple of hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch reported 7 inches of water flowing over Peppers Ferry Road in Max Meadows.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant rain advanced north into the region in advance of an area of low pressure to the west while a frontal boundary remained draped over the region. An average of 2 to 5 inches of rain fell from this system onto an already saturated ground from recent snow melt and rainfall. The heavy rain contributed to widespread flash flooding, mudslides, areal flooding, and river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain prompted a stream to leave its banks and cause flash flooding over Route 251. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short line of heavy rain from thunderstorms trained west to east across eastern Dickenson County into western Buchanan County between 1430 and 1530E on the 3rd.  Rain amounts of around 3 inches were likely from near Haysi to near Vicey and Prater.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small streams flooded several roads in the Haysi vicinity.  This included the small feeder branches and runs, such as Doe Branch, that flow into Russell Prater Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the Atlantic provided an easterly flow which pumped in plenty of moisture from the ocean. An upper-level low remained nearly stationary over the region, triggering showers and thunderstorms. With light winds aloft showers and thunderstorms were slow to move. Showers and thunderstorms produced locally heavy amounts of rain in a short period of time and this lead to an isolated flash flood event in northern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Belmont Ridge Road was closed due to flash flooding. The intersection of Evergreen Mills and Belmont Ridge Road was under water. Gum Springs Road was also closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary boundary remained over central on the 28th. An easterly flow off the Atlantic Ocean pumped in plenty of moisture. Showers and thunderstorms developed near the boundary. Due to a light steering flow aloft showers and thunderstorms were slow to move. Therefore, heavy amounts of rain fell in short periods of time across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two feet of water was flowing across the intersection of State Route 617 and State Route 620.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple, slow moving, heavy rain producing thunderstorms progressed across the same regions over a short period of time. The large volume of water in narrow creek basins prompted significant flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding washed out roads along Jerusalem Road and Elk Valley Road near Elk Creek. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slowing moving thunderstorms brought isolated heavy rain reports across southwest Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement personnel reported several roads and streets in and around Castlewood covered by rain from slow moving thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A localized severe thunderstorm produced some wind damage and isolated flash flooding in Russell County, Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred with several inches of water covering area roads and quickly flooded driveways, barns, utility buildings, yards, gardens, fences and basements in the area of the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A southerly flow around high pressure off the East Coast led to an unusually warm and humid air mass for this time of the year. The warm and humid air combined with an approaching cold front to trigger showers and thunderstorms. Heavier showers and thunderstorms produced large amounts of rain in a short period of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Prosperity Avenue was closed due to flash flooding between the 3700 and 3800 Blocks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A corridor of tropical moisture travelled up the Atlantic seaboard, funnelling another area of low pressure that developed along the Carolina coastline through the Mid-Atlantic. Bands of heavy rain began to rapidly move into northern Virginia just after midnight on Thursday morning, September 30. After the initial low pressure passed north of the area late Thursday morning after producing up to 5 inches of rain and numerous reports of flash flooding across portions of northern Virginia, a brief lull in precipitation occurred Thursday afternoon, before the remnant circulation of once Tropical Storm Nicole moved up the Delmarva Peninsula, reinvigorating heavy rainfall. The heavy amounts of rain on the 30th caused flash flooding that continued into the first of October.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Elys Ford Road closed due to flash flooding on Rapidan River.  A rain gage in the area measured 5.09.

After the initial low pressure passed north of the area late Thursday morning after producing up to 5 inches of rain and numerous reports of flash flooding across portions of northern Virginia, a brief lull in precipitation occurred Thursday afternoon, before the remnant circulation of once Tropical Storm Nicole moved up the Delmarva Peninsula, reinvigorating heavy rainfall. The heavy amounts of rain on the 30th caused flash flooding that continued into the first of October.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The underpass at Route 29 and Inlet Road was closed due to flash flooding. A rain gage in the area measured 4.60 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were flooded in the City of Portsmouth.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across the Appalachian Mountains early on the morning of December 1 into an unseasonably warm and moisture atmosphere in the Mid-Atlantic. Widespread rain and thunderstorms developed, some of which produced heavy rain and flash flooding across the area. Rainfall amounts ranged from 1 to over 2 inches across most locations, with the highest report received in Rappahannock County of 3.05 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 600 was closed at Route 643 due to flash flooding on the Robinson River.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 644 was closed due to flash flooding on Popham Run.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across the Appalachian Mountains early on the morning of December 1 into an unseasonably warm and moisture atmosphere in the Mid-Atlantic. Widespread rain and thunderstorms developed, some of which produced heavy rain and flash flooding across the area. Rainfall amounts ranged from 1 to over 2 inches across most locations, with the highest report received in Rappahannock County of 3.05 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 603 was closed at Route 602 due to flash flooding on the Hughes River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered large hail and damaging wind occurred along and ahead of a weak cold front that was moving into southwest Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were reported to have several inches of water over the roads with flash flooding occurring in the central and southwest portions of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary across the area produced isolated flooding reports from slow moving thunderstorms during the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement personnel reported numerous roads flooded countywide from slow moving thunderstorms.  Six families were evacuated in the Fort Blackmore area near Big Stony Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major storm affected the eastern U.S. during the period of November 30 - December 1 as a powerful upper low and surface system moved into the Great Lakes proving an extended period of deep southerly flow across the region.  Precipitable water values were extremely high for very early December, running from 1.3 to 1.6 inches or nearly 200 percent of normal. Precipitation developed late on the 29th and produced moderate rains (0.25 to 0.50) across the western portion of the NWS Blacksburg forecast area|ending at 7 AM on the 30th. Heavier and more widespread precipitation developed on the evening of the 30th into the early morning hours of December 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding prompted Pine Creek to leave its banks and flood Keno Road. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure tracked across the Ohio Valley and into the Great Lakes. Southerly flow on the east side of this system brought abundant Gulf moisture into the mid-Atlantic. Heavy rain developed along a cold front, producing flash flooding and later flooding during the morning of the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 635 near Route 633 was closed due to flash flooding. Observed in the area measured 2.26 inches of rain.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stoney Creek Road was closed as Stoney Creek was out of its banks. Rainfall report near the area received of 1.60 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifteen to twenty roads in the county closed, including many of the major roads.  Cooperative observer measured 1.40 inches of rain south the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure tracked across the Ohio Valley and into the Great Lakes. Southerly flow on the east side of this system brought abundant Gulf moisture into the mid-Atlantic. Heavy rain developed along a cold front, producing flash flooding and later flooding during the morning of the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water running over the the intersection of Old Churchville Road and Franks Mill Road. Observer near the event measured 3.27 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure tracked across the Ohio Valley and into the Great Lakes. Southerly flow on the east side of this system brought abundant Gulf moisture into the mid-Atlantic. Heavy rain developed along a cold front, producing flash flooding and later flooding during the morning of the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The interesection of Ivy Road and Old Ivy Road was closed due to 4 feet of water flowing over the roadway. Cooperative observer near the event measured 2.66 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure tracked across the Ohio Valley and into the Great Lakes. Southerly flow on the east side of this system brought abundant Gulf moisture into the mid-Atlantic. Heavy rain developed along a cold front, producing flash flooding and later flooding during the morning of the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of flash flooding across the county. Mesonet rain gauge 10 miles south of Stuarts Draft recorded 5.79 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system situated over the Ohio Valley combined with another low forming off the southeast coast to bring abundant moisture into the area. A band of thunderstorms developed during the evening of March 12th and tracked northeast into Southwest VA. A southeast flow helped enhance the rainfall over the region and |an existing snow pack in far western Giles County also helped contribute to the water runoff.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several spots along State Route 102 had mud flowing across the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system situated over the Ohio Valley combined with another low forming off the southeast coast to bring abundant moisture into the area. A band of thunderstorms developed during the evening of March 12th and tracked northeast into Southwest VA. A southeast flow helped enhance the rainfall over the region and |an existing snow pack in far western Giles County also helped contribute to the water runoff.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water, 150 yards wide, was reported flowing quickly at a depth of 8 inches across Loop Road. This was just off State Route 102 near Falls Mills, VA. Other streams and creeks in the area were also bank full or out of their banks.

A southeast flow helped enhance the rainfall over the region and |an existing snow pack in far western Giles County also helped contribute to the water runoff.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported along Periwinkle Branch. Water was reported to be rapidly rising across a driveway and within 3 feet of a trailer.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bluestone River rose out of its banks in spots in the Hales Bottom area, north of Bluefield, VA.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused Peak Creek to rise out of its banks in Pulaski and in northwest Pulaski county. This resulted in portions of the downtown Pulaski being flooding, including the Pulaski County 911 communications building.
