EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a low pressure system which produced an EF-0 tornado in Alton, VA. Later on the 28th, heavy rains caused isolated flash flooding in Pittsylvania and Halifax counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused water to flow across Luna Lake Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a low pressure system which produced an EF-0 tornado in Alton, VA. Later on the 28th, heavy rains caused isolated flash flooding in Pittsylvania and Halifax counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from heavy rain caused water to flow across the intersection of route 58 and highway 501.

A southeast flow helped enhance the rainfall over the region and |an existing snow pack in far western Giles County also helped contribute to the water runoff.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding from Peak Creek caused several water rescues to take place across Pulaski County.

A band of thunderstorms developed during the evening of March 12th and tracked northeast into Southwest VA. A southeast flow helped enhance the rainfall over the region and |an existing snow pack in far western Giles County also helped contribute to the water runoff.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused the Bluestone River to rise out of its banks at numerous locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system situated over the Ohio Valley combined with another low forming off the southeast coast to bring abundant moisture into the area. A band of thunderstorms developed during the evening of March 12th and tracked northeast into Southwest VA. A southeast flow helped enhance the rainfall over the region and |an existing snow pack in far western Giles County also helped contribute to the water runoff.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused numerous streams to come out of their banks, resulting in significant flash flooding in Giles County. Some streams that flooded included Little Walker Creek, Big Walker Creek, Sugar Run, and Wabash Creek.||Numerous roads were closed across Giles County, and at least 20 roads were damaged due to flood waters Emergency Management reported 93 homes in the county were affected by flood waters. Two homes were destroyed and 31 received major damage. Flooding along Wolf Creek caused damage to several homes and properties in the town of Narrows. Several houses were also flooded by Walker Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant rain advanced north into the region in advance of an area of low pressure to the west while a frontal boundary remained draped over the region. An average of 2 to 5 inches of rain fell from this system onto an already saturated ground from recent snow melt and rainfall. The heavy rain contributed to widespread flash flooding, mudslides, areal flooding, and river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding that caused most roads in and around the town of Bassett to be closed. The Blackwater Trailer Park had to be evacuated after Blackwater Creek left its banks. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant rain advanced north into the region in advance of an area of low pressure to the west while a frontal boundary remained draped over the region. An average of 2 to 5 inches of rain fell from this system onto an already saturated ground from recent snow melt and rainfall. The heavy rain contributed to widespread flash flooding, mudslides, areal flooding, and river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall prompted flash flooding across much of Franklin County. A total of 20 roads were closed. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant rain advanced north into the region in advance of an area of low pressure to the west while a frontal boundary remained draped over the region. An average of 2 to 5 inches of rain fell from this system onto an already saturated ground from recent snow melt and rainfall. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains helped generate a mudslide east of Concord. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front pushed south into the region and stalled along the crest of the Blue Ridge along a north to south orientation.  During the afternoon and early evening, numerous thunderstorms developed along and near the front. Some of these produced damaging wind and hail along with flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred as the result of runoff from heavy rain collecting in a blocked culvert. Water inundated three homes along Stone Road. Damage values estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front pushed south into the region and stalled along the crest of the Blue Ridge along a north to south orientation.  During the afternoon and early evening, numerous thunderstorms developed along and near the front. Some of these produced damaging wind and hail along with flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains prompted Den Creek to leave its banks and cause a flash flood along Den Hill Road. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front pushed south into the region and stalled along the crest of the Blue Ridge along a north to south orientation.  During the afternoon and early evening, numerous thunderstorms developed along and near the front. Some of these produced damaging wind and hail along with flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred at the intersection of Highway 60 and Route 665 near the Buckingham County High School. The water was deep at the height of a car bumper. Damage values are estimated.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred at the intersection of Highway 60 and Route 24. Damage values are estimated.

During the afternoon and early evening, numerous thunderstorms developed along and near the front. Some of these produced damaging wind and hail along with flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain prompted flash flooding along Route 609.  The road was closed due to the flash flooding. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front pushed south into the region and stalled along the crest of the Blue Ridge along a north to south orientation.  During the afternoon and early evening, numerous thunderstorms developed along and near the front. Some of these produced damaging wind and hail along with flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along Woodson Road as heavy rain caused streams to leave their banks. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front pushed south into the region and stalled along the crest of the Blue Ridge along a north to south orientation.  During the afternoon and early evening, numerous thunderstorms developed along and near the front. Some of these produced damaging wind and hail along with flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred at the intersection of Routes 20 and 652. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two thunderstorm complexes moved around a ridge centered over the southeastern states and into Virginia. The first complex strengthened when it moved east of the Blue Ridge and produced widespread wind damage. The second complex arrived in the evening and produced flash flooding across the mountain empire of Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding of Laurel Fork entered the basement of a home. Damage amounts are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An outflow boundary from morning storms became the focus for scattered thunderstorms during the afternoon across southwest Virginia. Moderate instability combined with large dew points depressions allowed for a few of these storms to produce damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Front Street, 4th Street, Railroad Avenue, 6th Street, Dalton Avenue, and the intersection of Virginia Ave and Farmers Street were all closed due to flooding. Central Avenue was also washed out. Damage amounts are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary across the region triggered isolated slow moving thunderstorms over the area resulting in flooding in a few locations. One person was swept away in flood waters and drowned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement personnel reported heavy rain from a slow moving thunderstorm in Weber City caused a 16 year old male to be swept away into flood waters and drowned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two thunderstorm complexes moved around a ridge centered over the southeastern states and into Virginia. The first complex strengthened when it moved east of the Blue Ridge and produced widespread wind damage. The second complex arrived in the evening and produced flash flooding across the mountain empire of Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding of roads and road closures near the high school with rapidly flowing water in excess of 6 inches on some roads in town. Damage amounts are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary across the region triggered isolated slow moving thunderstorms over the area resulting in flooding in a few locations. One person was swept away in flood waters and drowned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement personnel reported heavy rain from a slow moving thunderstorm caused Alley Valley Road north of Gate City to be washed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary across the region triggered isolated slow moving thunderstorms over the area resulting in flooding in a few locations. One person was swept away in flood waters and drowned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media personnel reported numerous roads closed for flooding from slow moving thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary across the region triggered isolated slow moving thunderstorms over the area resulting in flooding in a few locations. One person was swept away in flood waters and drowned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement personnel reported heavy rain from a slow moving thunderstorm in Weber City resulted in a foot of water across Yuma Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front approached the area in the morning triggering scattered showers and thunderstorms. Some of these showers and storms brought localized heavy rains that  caused flash flooding in small part of Tazewell county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A debris flow closed Route 643 along Mud Fork Creek.  The creek was two feet out of its banks. Several smaller creeks also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weakening cold front across the region interacted with warm and moist air mass to produce slow moving storms over Carroll county. These storms caused flash flooding in Galax.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A foot and a half of water was flowing across Creekview Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual pattern developed early in the 24th with low-topped showers and few embedded thunderstorms that tracked from east to west in the morning and midday hours. Rainfall rates were not especially intense but were prolonged over parts of Campbell County and the City of Lynchburg. The 24-hour rainfall for August 24th of 2.55 (midnight to midnight) at LYH set a record for the date, breaking the old record of 2.21 set in 1967. Other 24-hour amounts ending at 7 AM EDT on the 25th included Lynchburg COOP 3.64, Sugarloaf Mountain IFLOWS 3.53, Sloan Branch IFLOWS 3.19 and Lynchburg (LYH) 2.84.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: City police reported that Sandusky Drive was closed between Rhonda Road and Greenwood Drive due to rapidly flowing water well over 6 inches in depth. A later report said the water from Burton Creek reached 2 feet of depth in the parking lot of Sandusky Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary across the region triggered isolated slow moving thunderstorms over the area resulting in flooding in a few locations. One person was swept away in flood waters and drowned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media personnel reported numerous roads closed countywide for flooding from slow moving thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved west to east along a stationary boundary draped across far northern Virginia and Maryland. Thunderstorms associated with this low pressure produced very high rainfall rates with the aide of a moisture laden atmosphere. Flash flooding and other nuisance flooding was reported across northern Fairfax County during the morning from rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches in less than 3 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Georgetown Pike at Swanks Mill Road was closed due to flash flooding. A rainfall report from the area was received of 3.68 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved west to east along a stationary boundary draped across far northern Virginia and Maryland. Thunderstorms associated with this low pressure produced very high rainfall rates with the aide of a moisture laden atmosphere. Flash flooding and other nuisance flooding was reported across northern Fairfax County during the morning from rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches in less than 3 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lawyers Road near Hunter Mill Road was closed due to high water. A rain gauge near the area measured 2.86 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved west to east along a stationary boundary draped across far northern Virginia and Maryland. Thunderstorms associated with this low pressure produced very high rainfall rates with the aide of a moisture laden atmosphere. Flash flooding and other nuisance flooding was reported across northern Fairfax County during the morning from rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches in less than 3 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Edwards Ferry Road was closed due to flash flooding on Cattail Creek. A rain gauge in the area observed 2.77 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed into the area at peak heating of the day creating high instability along with moderate wind shear. Scattered thunderstorms developed ahead of the front as well as more organized lines closer to the front, producing downburst winds but very little hail. Some training of cells occurred resulting in some flash flooding as well. Every Virginia county in the warning area had a warning issued at one point or another.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nichols Road bridge was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed into the area at peak heating of the day creating high instability along with moderate wind shear. Scattered thunderstorms developed ahead of the front as well as more organized lines closer to the front, producing downburst winds but very little hail. Some training of cells occurred resulting in some flash flooding as well. Every Virginia county in the warning area had a warning issued at one point or another.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bethlehem Road closed by flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed into the area at peak heating of the day creating high instability along with moderate wind shear. Scattered thunderstorms developed ahead of the front as well as more organized lines closer to the front, producing downburst winds but very little hail. Some training of cells occurred resulting in some flash flooding as well. Every Virginia county in the warning area had a warning issued at one point or another.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Callaway Road was impassible due to flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough combined with an upper-level disturbance to trigger showers and thunderstorms over the area overnight on the 13th into the morning of the 14th. With ground already saturatured from numerous rounds of rainfall over the past few days, heavy downpours from thunderstorms created flash flooding the Virginia suburbs of the Washington metropolitan area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The left lane of the inner loop of the Capital Beltway was closed due to deep standing water from Little Accotink Creek overflowing its banks.  Trained spotter in the region measured 2.26 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure in advance of a cold front moving southeastward toward the Mid-Atlantic provided the lift to produce thunderstorms in a highly moist and unstable atmosphere. These thunderstorms dropped locally heavy rainfall, which caused an isolated flash flood in the western suburbs of metropolitan Washington.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Exit off Route 50 in vicinity of Fair Oaks Mall was impassable due to flowing water. A spotter in the area observed 2.50 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The period from August 17-19 became very active hydrologically as a frontal boundary stalled out across the region and a series of upper-air impulses helped to trigger fairly widespread convection. Forecasters recognizing this potentially very wet pattern issued a Flash Flood Watch the afternoon of the 17th. By early evening the same day, thunderstorms were training over Galax, VA and vicinity with rainfall amounts up to 1.5 to 2.5 inches in several hours.  Maximum 24-hour rain gage totals ending at 12Z on the 18th within the warned area included Blackburn Knob IFLOWS 3.82, Grayson Highland IFLOWS 3.12 and Galax Water Plant COOP 2.90.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported on Route 58 near Delheart Road due to heavy rains and a backed up culvert.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the 25th of September, a powerful area of low pressure was located over the southeastern U.S.  Several weak centers of low pressure formed over the Gulf Coast area from the 26th to 28th and pushed northeast along a stationary boundary bringing very high moisture from the Gulf and Atlantic Ocean. This deep moisture was pulled northward into the piedmont of the Carolinas and Virginia. A strong southeast flow developed in the low levels of the atmosphere and initiated a significant upslope component formed as well, with the highest amounts of rain falling along and east of the Blue Ridge. Storm total rainfall was greatest along the crest of the Blue Ridge and east into the foothills. This region received three to five inches. A second around of rain began in earnest during the evening hours of the 29th as remains from Tropical Storm Nicole moved across North Carolina and eastern Virginia. Rainfall rates increased during the overnight hours with the heaviest amounts falling from the Blue Ridge eastward. There was a much sharper western cutoff to this precipitation pattern, with very little falling west of the Blue Ridge and heavy rains to the east. The heaviest rains were concentrated from Rockingham County, NC through Henry County, VA and into southern Franklin County, VA.  Rainfall rates of 1.0 to 1.5 inches per hour occurred in the same region that received the heaviest amounts rain on the 26th through the 28th. This prompted flash flooding within this region. Precipitation continued through much of the 30th as the remains of Nicole shifted northward. Three day rainfall totals exceeded ten inches over parts of Henry County with widespread three to five inch totals noted east of the crest of the Blue Ridge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding along Small Creek where it enters Smith Mountain Lake prompted flooding and closure of Kay Fork Road. Damage values are estimated.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along Big Chestnut Creek. As a result, Rufus Road was flooded and closed. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms in advance of low pressure and an associated cold front produced flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed due to high water, including the intersection of Armistead and Queensway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms in advance of low pressure and an associated cold front produced flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed due to flooding, including Tidewater Drive and Virginia Beach Boulevard, Brambleton Avenue, Little Creek Road, Exit at Interstate 264 West for Brambleton Avenue, East Ocean View, and Azalea Garden Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms in advance of low pressure and an associated cold front produced flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed due to flooding, including Portsmouth Boulevard, County Street, Effingham Street, and the Interstate 264 Exit at Effingham.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms in advance of low pressure and an associated cold front produced flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous streets were flooded city-wide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms in advance of low pressure and an associated cold front produced flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads were closed due to high water. High water was reported on Highway 17.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms in advance of low pressure and an associated cold front produced flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed due to high water.

Scattered thunderstorms developed ahead of the front as well as more organized lines closer to the front, producing downburst winds but very little hail. Some training of cells occurred resulting in some flash flooding as well. Every Virginia county in the warning area had a warning issued at one point or another.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few boulders from a rockslide closed Route 460 on the east side of Richlands.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rock slide closed part of Route 274 about two miles north of Route 58.

Rainfall rates of 1.0 to 1.5 inches per hour occurred in the same region that received the heaviest amounts rain on the 26th through the 28th. This prompted flash flooding within this region. Precipitation continued through much of the 30th as the remains of Nicole shifted northward. Three day rainfall totals exceeded ten inches over parts of Henry County with widespread three to five inch totals noted east of the crest of the Blue Ridge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding along Stony Creek prompted the flooding and closure of Ruritan Road. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed into the area at peak heating of the day creating high instability along with moderate wind shear. Scattered thunderstorms developed ahead of the front as well as more organized lines closer to the front, producing downburst winds but very little hail. Some training of cells occurred resulting in some flash flooding as well. Every Virginia county in the warning area had a warning issued at one point or another.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nininger Creek flooded over Five Forks Road, which was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed during the overnight of the 23rd and dropped heavy rainfall over the far eastern sections of the area. Rainfall was 2 to 3 inches over Charlotte and Halifax counties, with 1 to 2 inches over parts of Campbell and Halifax and Pittsylvania counties. A few of the higher rain gage amounts ending at 7 am on the 24th included Keysville COOP at 2.10, South Boston COOP 2.01, and Danville (DAN) 1.60.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State Route 717 was closed and impassable due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved west to east along a stationary boundary draped across far northern Virginia and Maryland. Thunderstorms associated with this low pressure produced very high rainfall rates with the aide of a moisture laden atmosphere. Flash flooding and other nuisance flooding was reported across northern Fairfax County during the morning from rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches in less than 3 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A bridge on Beulah Road was washed out at Wolftrap Run. Rainfall in the area was measured at 2.91 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms developed during the afternoon within a hot and humid air mass with high temperatures well into the 90s and dew points into 70s across much of the area. This unstable air mass contributed to the strong winds associated with these storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused Cedar Run to flood it banks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along Gills Creek. Red Valley Road was flooding because of this, and the road was closed. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the 25th of September, a powerful area of low pressure was located over the southeastern U.S.  Several weak centers of low pressure formed over the Gulf Coast area from the 26th to 28th and pushed northeast along a stationary boundary bringing very high moisture from the Gulf and Atlantic Ocean. This deep moisture was pulled northward into the piedmont of the Carolinas and Virginia. A strong southeast flow developed in the low levels of the atmosphere and initiated a significant upslope component formed as well, with the highest amounts of rain falling along and east of the Blue Ridge. Storm total rainfall was greatest along the crest of the Blue Ridge and east into the foothills. This region received three to five inches. A second around of rain began in earnest during the evening hours of the 29th as remains from Tropical Storm Nicole moved across North Carolina and eastern Virginia. Rainfall rates increased during the overnight hours with the heaviest amounts falling from the Blue Ridge eastward. There was a much sharper western cutoff to this precipitation pattern, with very little falling west of the Blue Ridge and heavy rains to the east. The heaviest rains were concentrated from Rockingham County, NC through Henry County, VA and into southern Franklin County, VA.  Rainfall rates of 1.0 to 1.5 inches per hour occurred in the same region that received the heaviest amounts rain on the 26th through the 28th. This prompted flash flooding within this region. Precipitation continued through much of the 30th as the remains of Nicole shifted northward. Three day rainfall totals exceeded ten inches over parts of Henry County with widespread three to five inch totals noted east of the crest of the Blue Ridge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding along Madcap Creek prompted flooding and closure of Madcap Road. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed into the area at peak heating of the day creating high instability along with moderate wind shear. Scattered thunderstorms developed ahead of the front as well as more organized lines closer to the front, producing downburst winds but very little hail. Some training of cells occurred resulting in some flash flooding as well. Every Virginia county in the warning area had a warning issued at one point or another.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding from an unnamed creek caused Union Church Road to be closed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Evington Road was closed due to flood waters flowing over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of showers and thunderstorms moved from west to east across southwest Virginia during the afternoon and few stronger embedded cells were able to produce wind gusts up to severe levels. Another cell tracked from eastern Campbell across Appomattox County and produced very heavy rain in a short time, with reports of up to 4 inches of rain and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stonewall Creek was reported out of its banks. A retired NWS employee reported 3.78 inches of rain.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along Snow Creek. Sutton Hollow Road was flooded and closed as a result. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The period from August 17-19 became very active hydrologically as a frontal boundary stalled out across the region and a series of upper-air impulses helped to trigger fairly widespread convection. Forecasters recognizing this potentially very wet pattern issued a Flash Flood Watch the afternoon of the 17th. By early evening the same day, thunderstorms were training over Galax, VA and vicinity with rainfall amounts up to 1.5 to 2.5 inches in several hours.  Maximum 24-hour rain gage totals ending at 12Z on the 18th within the warned area included Blackburn Knob IFLOWS 3.82, Grayson Highland IFLOWS 3.12 and Galax Water Plant COOP 2.90.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local law enforcement reported street closures due to high water.  Givens Street and Shaw street were closed. Water was also reported flowing across Railroad Avenue. The water treatment plant reported 1.80 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were flooded in north Virginia Beach.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A corridor of tropical moisture travelled up the Atlantic seaboard, funnelling another area of low pressure that developed along the Carolina coastline through the Mid-Atlantic.  Bands of heavy rain began to rapidly move into northern Virginia just after midnight on Thursday morning, September 30. After the initial low pressure passed north of the area late Thursday morning after producing up to 5 inches of rain and numerous reports of flash flooding across portions of northern Virginia, a brief lull in precipitation occurred Thursday afternoon, before the remnant circulation of once Tropical Storm Nicole moved up the Delmarva Peninsula, reinvigorating heavy rainfall. Storm total rainfall exceeded 8 inches across many areas. Hundreds of roads were closed due to high water across the area, and high water rescues and roadway washouts were frequent.  There were no reported injuries or deaths. From a historical perspective, Washington Reagan National Airports 4.66 and Washington Dulles International Airports 4.74 on Sep 30 were both the third highest daily rainfall amounts ever recorded in the month of September. Events associated with this episode continued into October 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 628 was closed due to flash flooding.  Rainfall in the area was measured at 6.03 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system over Minnesota pushed a front across our area. Very strong winds aloft set the stage for damaging wind gusts and tornadoes. Enough instability was present ahead of this front to enhance the severe threat. An area of severe thunderstorms and embedded supercells moved into the Piedmont of Virginia late in the evening of the 26th into early on the 27th. These storms produced areas of wind damage and two tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Railroad Avenue and Summit Drive were closed by flooding of Poplar Creek. Damage amounts are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system over Minnesota pushed a front across our area. Very strong winds aloft set the stage for damaging wind gusts and tornadoes. Enough instability was present ahead of this front to enhance the severe threat. An area of severe thunderstorms and embedded supercells moved into the Piedmont of Virginia late in the evening of the 26th into early on the 27th. These storms produced areas of wind damage and two tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding closed North Fork Church Road near Kingswoods Road. Damage amounts are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A corridor of tropical moisture travelled up the Atlantic seaboard, funnelling another area of low pressure that developed along the Carolina coastline through the Mid-Atlantic.  Bands of heavy rain began to rapidly move into northern Virginia just after midnight on Thursday morning, September 30. After the initial low pressure passed north of the area late Thursday morning after producing up to 5 inches of rain and numerous reports of flash flooding across portions of northern Virginia, a brief lull in precipitation occurred Thursday afternoon, before the remnant circulation of once Tropical Storm Nicole moved up the Delmarva Peninsula, reinvigorating heavy rainfall. Storm total rainfall exceeded 8 inches across many areas. Hundreds of roads were closed due to high water across the area, and high water rescues and roadway washouts were frequent.  There were no reported injuries or deaths. From a historical perspective, Washington Reagan National Airports 4.66 and Washington Dulles International Airports 4.74 on Sep 30 were both the third highest daily rainfall amounts ever recorded in the month of September. Events associated with this episode continued into October 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported on Jefferson Davis Highway at Telegraph Road.  A rainfall report of 4.46 was received from the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure was located off the Carolina coast and spread moisture westward into the area which aided in the development of isolated to scattered thunderstorms. Heavy rains caused flash flooding in Bedford County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Johns Creek was reported to have water briefly out of its banks and caused roads to be closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With the afternoon heating, convection formed on boundaries leftover from morning showers and thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Streams around Big Rock, Harman and Grundy overflowed onto roads.  One such example was Slate Creek flowing onto Route 83.  Mudslides were also common. Grundy measured 2.44 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system situated over the Ohio Valley combined with another low forming off the southeast coast to bring abundant moisture into the area. A band of thunderstorms developed during the evening of March 12th and tracked northeast into Southwest VA. A southeast flow helped enhance the rainfall over the region and |an existing snow pack in far western Giles County also helped contribute to the water runoff.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused Little Creek to rise out of its banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The period from August 17-19 became very active hydrologically as a frontal boundary stalled out across the region and a series of upper-air impulses helped to trigger fairly widespread convection. Forecasters recognizing this potentially very wet pattern issued a Flash Flood Watch the afternoon of the 17th. By early evening the same day, thunderstorms were training over Galax, VA and vicinity with rainfall amounts up to 1.5 to 2.5 inches in several hours.  Maximum 24-hour rain gage totals ending at 12Z on the 18th within the warned area included Blackburn Knob IFLOWS 3.82, Grayson Highland IFLOWS 3.12 and Galax Water Plant COOP 2.90.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A number of streets were closed in the City of Galax due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were flooded in the City of Hampton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across the Appalachian Mountains early on the morning of December 1 into an unseasonably warm and moisture atmosphere in the Mid-Atlantic. Widespread rain and thunderstorms developed, some of which produced heavy rain and flash flooding across the area. Rainfall amounts ranged from 1 to over 2 inches across most locations, with the highest report received in Rappahannock County of 3.05 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 628 at Route 630 closed due to flash flooding along Hittles Mill Stream.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary across the region triggered isolated slow moving thunderstorms over the area resulting in flooding in a few locations. One person was swept away in flood waters and drowned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement personnel reported heavy rain from a slow moving thunderstorm caused Manville Road northwest of Gate City to be washed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure tracked across the Ohio Valley and into the Great Lakes. Southerly flow on the east side of this system brought abundant Gulf moisture into the mid-Atlantic. Heavy rain developed along a cold front, producing flash flooding and later flooding during the morning of the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A basement was flooded out and a water rescue was conducted at a residence. A rain gauge in the county measured 2.20 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major storm affected the eastern U.S. during the period of November 30 - December 1 as a powerful upper low and surface system moved into the Great Lakes proving an extended period of deep southerly flow across the region.  Precipitable water values were extremely high for very early December, running from 1.3 to 1.6 inches or nearly 200 percent of normal. Precipitation developed late on the 29th and produced moderate rains (0.25 to 0.50) across the western portion of the NWS Blacksburg forecast area|ending at 7 AM on the 30th. Heavier and more widespread precipitation developed on the evening of the 30th into the early morning hours of December 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along the North Fork of Catawba Creek and prompted the closure of a one lane bridge on Breckinridge Mill Road. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow eastward-moving surface boundary in association with a broad upper level trough over the Ohio Valley progressed across the Blue Ridge during the afternoon and evening. Thunderstorms trained northward along the boundary, repeatedly over the same area in Culpeper County.  Torrential rains produced flash flooding in portions of the county.  A maximum measured rainfall total of 7.9 inches was reported near Winston.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous road closures were reported in Culpeper County.  A rain gage in Culpeper measured 4.58 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a bridge was washed out on Spring Creek Drive.  A nearby spotter observed 6.85 inches of rain.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rescue was performed for vehicle caught in flood waters.  A nearby rain gage recorded 4.37 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two separate rescues were conducted from vehicles trapped in flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep layer southerly flow advected a moist, tropical airmass into the Mid-Atlantic.  As low pressure approached from the west, periods of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across the central Virginia Foothills.  As grounds became saturated, flood and flash flooding resulted in some areas.  A spotter in Albemarle County measured 3.15 inches of rain during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Crabtree Falls Highway near Cub Creek Road was closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level disturbance combined with a moist, unstable airmass to induce scattered thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours.  Very heavy rainfall rates with some of this activity in the Washington, DC, suburbs caused a few flash floods.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was stuck in high water near the intersection of Route 50 and Prosperity Avenue.  A swift water rescue was performed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a cold front moving through the Washington metropolitan area. Heavy rainfall rates prompted flash flooding in parts of Fairfax County. Rainfall amounts of up to 3.23 inches were reported near Vienna.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 123 was closed under the Interstate 495 overpass due to flash flooding.  A nearby rain gage measured 1.28.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level disturbance combined with a moist, unstable airmass to induce scattered thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours.  Very heavy rainfall rates with some of this activity in the Washington, DC, suburbs caused a few flash floods.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water forced the partial closure of Route 50 between 10th Street North and North Queen Street.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Alabama Drive was closed due to flash flooding.  A nearby rain gage measured 1.35 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a cold front moving through the Washington metropolitan area. Heavy rainfall rates prompted flash flooding in parts of Fairfax County. Rainfall amounts of up to 3.23 inches were reported near Vienna.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Center Street and Route 123 have been closed due to flash flooding.  A nearby rain gage measured 2.62 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a cold front moving through the Washington metropolitan area. Heavy rainfall rates prompted flash flooding in parts of Fairfax County. Rainfall amounts of up to 3.23 inches were reported near Vienna.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A swift water rescue was conducted  at the intersection of Hunter Mill Road and Lawyers Road.  A rain gage near the event measured 1.04 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a cold front moving through the Washington metropolitan area. Heavy rainfall rates prompted flash flooding in parts of Fairfax County. Rainfall amounts of up to 3.23 inches were reported near Vienna.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two lanes of Interstate 66 near Mile Marker 64 were closed due to high water.  A nearby rain gage tallied 1.65 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across Albermarle County in association with a surface trough.  An isolated flash flood occur from this moist, unstable atmosphere.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported near the intersection of Stony Point Road and Key West Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving warm front lifted northward through northern Virginia during the afternoon and evening. Over 24 hours of intermittent rain had created saturated grounds across the area and even a report of morning flooding.  Thus, when thunderstorms fired later in the day as instability and wind fields strengthened, high rainfall rates associated with them lead to flash flooding in several locations in the western suburbs of Washington DC, and flooding continued for a while after rains ended.  The highest rainfall amount received was 4.11 inches in Fairfax County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Walney Road was closed just south of Mariah Court due to flash flooding on Flat Lick Stream.  An observer near the event recorded 2.26 inches of rain.

The highest rainfall amount received was 4.11 inches in Fairfax County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Shreve Mill Road was closed between Sycolin Road and the Dulles Greenway due to flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stewart Mill Road was closed near Birdfoot Lane due to flash flooding on Little Difficult Run.  A nearby spotter observed 1.60 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms associated with low pressure produced heavy rains which caused flash flooding across portions of the Virginia Eastern shore.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was covering Routes 316 and 182.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving northwest-to-southeast oriented warm front lifted through Virginia, accompanied by a broad band of light to moderate rain.  During the afternoon and evening, instability on the southern edges of this band helped induce thunderstorms with locally heavy rainfall. Excessive rainfall amounts, aided by terrain-induced lift, caused a couple of flash floods in the central Virginia Foothills.  Rainfall amounts in Nelson County were measured to be as high as 4.28 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Esmont Road was closed near the 7500 block due to water running over the roadway.  A nearby rain gauge recorded 3.88 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thomas Avenue was closed near Lake Drive due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary area of low pressure over the Ohio Valley produced several days of intermittent showers and thunderstorms across the mid-Atlantic leading up to May 16th. On the afternoon and evening of May 16, training thunderstorms over saturated produced in excess of 2 inches of rain across portions of Prince William County and adjacent independent cities. This prompted flash flooding over the southwestern suburbs of the Washington metropolitan area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A high water rescue was underway near the intersection of Lucasville Road and Hidden Spring Drive. Water was 3 feet deep. A rain gage nearby measured 1.90 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary area of upper level low pressure system over the Ohio Valley provided plenty of lift to combine with an usually strong and moist southeasterly low-level flow to produce bands of moderate to heavy showers across the mid-Atlantic. With saturated ground in place and the training nature of the widespread showers, flood and flash flooding was the result across portions of northern Virginia. Rainfall amounts of over 3 inches were common and included a measurement of 4.48 inches from Earlysville, VA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Secretarys Road and Blenheim Roads were closed due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotswood Trail and Octonia Road were closed due to flooding.  A nearby spotter measured 2.14 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The most significant hydrologic event of the month began around the 28th as an upper level low closed off over the lower Mississippi Valley and lifted slowly northeast over the next 24 to 36 hours. Rainfall became widespread and heavy in the mountains of North Carolina in the afternoon hours of the 28th and gradually spread northeast into Virginia.  The prolonged upslope event produced storm total rainfall ranging from 2 to 4 inches in a 12 hour period. Rainfall rates were generally around 0.5 inches per hour during the most intense portion of the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported on Glendale Road just east of Bee Line Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level low pressure remained over the Ohio Valley while high pressure was located over the Atlantic Ocean. A southerly flow between these two systems pumped in plenty of moisture across the area. The deep moisture provided moderate amounts of instability while a cold front was moving in from the west. These two features combined to trigger showers and thunderstorms.  Excessive rainfall rates from these thunderstorms caused flash flooding in King George County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mudslide was caused by flash flooding near Belvedere Drive and Waugh Point Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A road was washed out due to heavy rain near Bully Hill Drive and Chapel Green Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep tropical moisture associated with the remnants of Tropical Depression Lee interacted with a slow-moving cold front to produce widespread showers across the area. High rainfall amounts associated with some of this activity prompted flooding and flash flooding in a few locations. Rainfall totals were a high as 8.90 inches in Nelson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reva Road closed due to flash flooding.  A nearby rain gauge tallied 2.66 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure passed through the Great Lakes on the 10th. A strong cold front associated with this system slowly moved through northern and central Virginia during the afternoon and evening hours. A southeast wind between this system and high pressure over the Atlantic Ocean pumped in copious amounts of moisture across the region. The deep moisture combined with strong lift from the front and limited instability to trigger showers and thunderstorms. Some thunderstorms produced locally heavy amounts of rain in a short period of time which led to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported at the intersection of 802 and 621.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong front moved into the far western sections of the area producing heavy rainfall of 1.5 to over 2 inches in parts of the Tennessee River basin. 24-hour rain gage totals ending at 7AM on March 1st were highest across the Mountain Empire and included 2.24 at Fairwood IFLOWS (FWDV2), 2.08 at Springville IFLOWS (SPIV2), 1.96 at both Jones Knob IFLOWS (JNKV2) and Grayson Highlands IFLOWS (GYHV2), and 1.90 at Troutdale COOP (TROV2). There were sharp rises on several rivers and streams. The Clinch River at Richlands (RLRV2) in western Tazewell County hit 9.60 feet, just below the minor flood stage of 10 feet. This was the highest level on this gage since May 25, 2004 (10.37). Both the North and South Forks of the Holston River in Smyth County rose to near action stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water overflowed drainage channels and covered several roadways in Richlands, including Route 609, Burnette St. and River St.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure both at the surface and the upper levels of the atmosphere passed through the region on the 12th. Showers and thunderstorms developed across the area. Despite relatively dry antecedent conditions, an unusually moist atmosphere combined with significant lift produce high rainfall rates sufficient for flash flooding across the Potomac Highlands and portions of the Shenandoah Valley. Rainfall amounts of up to 3 inches in a several hour period were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Charlie Town Road closed due to flash flood on Mill Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front slowly passed through the region during the morning of the 28th A southerly flow ahead of the front caused deep moisture over the area. The cold front combined with the instability to trigger showers and thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall rates. Slow moving and training convection combined to produce flash flooding in some locations, as rainfall amounts of up to 2.5 inches were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue was performed on New Valley Church Road near Lucketts. Numerous roads between Middleburg and Lucketts were covered with water.  A spotter near the event observed 1.99 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front slowly passed through the region during the morning of the 28th A southerly flow ahead of the front caused deep moisture over the area. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 9 was closed due to flash flooding on north fork Little Catoctin Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue was ongoing at Dry Mill Road in Leesburg.  Numerous roads throughout the county were either closed or partially restricted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe storms developed along a warm front that stretched from Indiana southeast into the Carolinas. An upper level disturbance helped to trigger the storms in the mid-afternoon over southwest Virginia and then developed eastward mainly across the Mountain Empire and the New River Valley. The storms also produced heavy rainfall with several stations in Montgomery County reporting over an inch of rain in a short period, including Christiansburg 1.8S CoCoRaHs 1.61, Christiansburg 1S COOP 1.56, Falling Branch IFLOWS 1.46 and Brush Mtn. IFLOWS 1.26.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 654 was closed by flooding from Toms Creek. 1 to 2 inches of rain fell in an hour or so.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure both at the surface and the upper levels of the atmosphere passed through the region on the 12th. Showers and thunderstorms developed across the area. Despite relatively dry antecedent conditions, an unusually moist atmosphere combined with significant lift produce high rainfall rates sufficient for flash flooding across the Potomac Highlands and portions of the Shenandoah Valley. Rainfall amounts of up to 3 inches in a several hour period were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 220 south was under water near its intersection with Route 84.  A rain gage near the event measured 2.90 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and closed low pressure system over the Ohio Valley remained nearly stationary through the 16th, bringing copious moisture northward up the eastern seaboard. Lift to produce showers and thunderstorms was focused along a warm front that passed north through the mid-Atlantic during the morning. With ground already saturated from several rounds of significant rainfall in the past week, flooding and flash flooding resulted.  Rainfall amounts of over 4 inches were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous high water rescues between 4 and 6 pm across Warren County. Some locations of the rescues included Old Oak Lane, Stonewall Jackson Highway, and Prospect Street.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moffett Branch flowing over the bridge at Moffett Branch Road.  A dog had to be rescued from the stream.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong closed upper level low pressure moved across the Ohio valley, producing a variety of extreme weather across southwest Virginia. In advance of this system,|strong southeast winds produced wind damage across the higher elevations. These southeast winds also provided strong upslope lifting along the Blue Ridge. This helped produce heavy rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches and areas of flash flooding. Enough heating occurred ahead of the cold front on the 16th to trigger severe thunderstorms along and east of the Blue Ridge, resulting in widespread thunderstorm wind damage and two tornadoes. Behind the storms, strong northwest winds knocked down many trees given the very wet soil conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused flooding just northwest of Rocky Mount. Grassy Hill Road was flooded by the Blackwater River with water and debris running across the road. Coles Creek Road was also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong closed upper level low pressure moved across the Ohio valley, producing a variety of extreme weather across southwest Virginia. In advance of this system,|strong southeast winds produced wind damage across the higher elevations. These southeast winds also provided strong upslope lifting along the Blue Ridge. This helped produce heavy rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches and areas of flash flooding. Enough heating occurred ahead of the cold front on the 16th to trigger severe thunderstorms along and east of the Blue Ridge, resulting in widespread thunderstorm wind damage and two tornadoes. Behind the storms, strong northwest winds knocked down many trees given the very wet soil conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused some flooding in the Wirtz area. Deep water was covering an underpass on Virgil H Goode Highway and another underpass on Wirtz Road.

Enough heating occurred ahead of the cold front on the 16th to trigger severe thunderstorms along and east of the Blue Ridge, resulting in widespread thunderstorm wind damage and two tornadoes. Behind the storms, strong northwest winds knocked down many trees given the very wet soil conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Greater than 6 inches of water was flowing across Keisters Branch Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong closed upper level low pressure moved across the Ohio valley, producing a variety of extreme weather across southwest Virginia. In advance of this system,|strong southeast winds produced wind damage across the higher elevations. These southeast winds also provided strong upslope lifting along the Blue Ridge. This helped produce heavy rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches and areas of flash flooding. Enough heating occurred ahead of the cold front on the 16th to trigger severe thunderstorms along and east of the Blue Ridge, resulting in widespread thunderstorm wind damage and two tornadoes. Behind the storms, strong northwest winds knocked down many trees given the very wet soil conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused a mudslide on Highway 52 near Fancy Gap.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms spread eastward from a strong mesoscale system over Kentucky and Tennessee in the early evening and continued for several hours. With moderate instability and sufficient vertical wind shear a few storms became intense enough to produce mainly large hail, but also some winds up to 60 mph. The largest hailstones were about golf-ball size. A few storms also produced heavy rainfall, especially over parts of Montgomery, Giles, Wythe and Bedford counties. Radar estimated amounts were 2 to 4 inches in several hours but the highest rain gage totals were at Radford Coop 1.83, Spruce Run IFLOWS 1.72, Blacksburg 0.4N CCR 1.62, Abbott IFLOWS 1.47.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spruce Run flooded a portion of Route 605 after 1 to 3 inches of rain fell in a few hours along the Giles-Montgomery County line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong closed upper level low pressure moved across the Ohio valley, producing a variety of extreme weather across southwest Virginia. In advance of this system,|strong southeast winds produced wind damage across the higher elevations. These southeast winds also provided strong upslope lifting along the Blue Ridge. This helped produce heavy rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches and areas of flash flooding. Enough heating occurred ahead of the cold front on the 16th to trigger severe thunderstorms along and east of the Blue Ridge, resulting in widespread thunderstorm wind damage and two tornadoes. Behind the storms, strong northwest winds knocked down many trees given the very wet soil conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused Coal Creek to flood Coal Creek Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure both at the surface and the upper levels of the atmosphere passed through the region on the 12th. Showers and thunderstorms developed across the area. Despite relatively dry antecedent conditions, an unusually moist atmosphere combined with significant lift produce high rainfall rates sufficient for flash flooding across the Potomac Highlands and portions of the Shenandoah Valley. Rainfall amounts of up to 3 inches in a several hour period were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two feet of running water was observed on Model Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low pressure approaching from the west triggered shower and thunderstorm activity across the region. These storms were slow moving trained over the same areas producing very heavy rainfall. Radar estimated rainfall of up to 3 inches occurred across portions of the Alleghany Highlands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused a rockslide that blocked River Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A portion of Ivanhoe Road was washed out with over 1 foot of water on it.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dry Branch flooded part of Route 602.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread severe weather impacted the area. A strong upper level trough approaching from the west provided strong winds aloft, and a weak upper level low pressure system moved across during the afternoon hours setting off scattered thunderstorms. These storms quickly became severe. In total, there were 6 tornadoes with numerous reports of damaging winds and large hail. Heavy rainfall from these storms also caused scattered flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains of up to 2 inches flooded a house on Lake Park drive.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rock slide on route 460 in the Shortt Gap area blocked the left lane.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous road closures due to flooding in the Buchanan area. State Routes 640, 643, 644 and 645 were all closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northwesterly flow aloft continued the pattern of storminess over the mountains as disturbances dropped southeast along the periphery of the upper ridge. Storms developed in the early afternoon and dropped mainly hail and heavy rain across several counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Radar-estimated rainfall of 2.5 to 3 inches in less than three hours caused Brush Creek east of Byllesby to come out of its banks by 4 to 6 feet. An IFLOWS rain gage at Woodlawn recorded 1.26 of rain in one hour ending at 700 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level storm system approaching from the west helped to trigger numerous showers and thunderstorms mainly over the Appalachians and Blue Ridge Mountains. The storms developed along a slow-moving frontal boundary, and with abundant moisture in place,some of the storms produced heavy rainfall with flash flooding in several counties along with hail and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From 3 to 5 inches of rain in less than 2 hours caused flash flooding in Fries. Dalton Road Creek was several feet out of its banks at the Fries RV park and at least 17 cars were flooded in the town. At the Fries School water got into some classrooms and into the school library. Several roads in the Fries area were closed by flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level storm system approaching from the west helped to trigger numerous showers and thunderstorms mainly over the Appalachians and Blue Ridge Mountains. The storms developed along a slow-moving frontal boundary, and with abundant moisture in place,some of the storms produced heavy rainfall with flash flooding in several counties along with hail and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains of 3 to 5 inches in less than 2 hours caused flooding of Dixon Branch along Fries Road from near the Country Convenience store to the low water bridge at the New River, with 6 to 8 inches of water flowing over the road. A large rockfall also occurred along Fries Road.

Behind the storms, strong northwest winds knocked down many trees given the very wet soil conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused flooding of low lying areas including public and private roads. Some businesses and homes were also flooded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dry Run caused flooding of Muddy Run Road and Dry Run Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread reports of flash flooding across the county. One family had to be evacuated along Muddy Lane. One basement was also flooded with significant damage. there was also a water rescue on Furrs Mill Road which was flooded by the Maury River. As many as 33 roads were closed through the county at one point due to flooding.

The storms developed along a slow-moving frontal boundary, and with abundant moisture in place,some of the storms produced heavy rainfall with flash flooding in several counties along with hail and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains of 2 to 3 inches in a few hours over north central Giles County produced flooding and mudslides in various locations around the county. Route 460 was partially closed by deep standing water and mudslides were reported on State Route 616 and on Sinking Creek Road. Dry Branch Hollow Road was also close by flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused several creeks to flood over roadways. Franklin Creek flooded the Lexington Turnpike, Stonehouse Creek flooded Fancy Hill Road, Maple Run Creek flooded Flat Woods Road, Maple Run Creek flooded Maple Run Road and Woodson Road was flooded by the Piney River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level storm system approaching from the west helped to trigger numerous showers and thunderstorms mainly over the Appalachians and Blue Ridge Mountains. The storms developed along a slow-moving frontal boundary, and with abundant moisture in place,some of the storms produced heavy rainfall with flash flooding in several counties along with hail and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in the City of Galax were closed due to the heavy rain including Creekview Drive, Givens Road and Eastview Road. Radar estimated that 2 to 3 inches fell in a few hours on the north edge of Galax. Flooding was likely urban runoff, although Mill Creek may have flooded as well.

These storms were slow moving trained over the same areas producing very heavy rainfall. Radar estimated rainfall of up to 3 inches occurred across portions of the Alleghany Highlands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State Route 614 near Burnsville was washed out from heavy rains. Other roads and property were also damaged across the northern part of Bath County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rock slide closed a portion of Little Wilson road northwest of Volney in an area where 1 to 3 inches of rain fell in a few hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level storm system approaching from the west helped to trigger numerous showers and thunderstorms mainly over the Appalachians and Blue Ridge Mountains. The storms developed along a slow-moving frontal boundary, and with abundant moisture in place,some of the storms produced heavy rainfall with flash flooding in several counties along with hail and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 1 to 2 inches in less than two hours caused flooding on Mud Fork Road in the northeast part of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level storm system approaching from the west helped to trigger numerous showers and thunderstorms mainly over the Appalachians and Blue Ridge Mountains. The storms developed along a slow-moving frontal boundary, and with abundant moisture in place,some of the storms produced heavy rainfall with flash flooding in several counties along with hail and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 3 to 6 inches fell in a few hours causing flooding throughout portions of the Fox Creek drainage south of Flat Ridge. An unofficial rain gage amount of 4 inches in 1 hour was reported.  The Little Fox Creek and Middle Fox Creek basins were the most severely impacted down to their confluence with Fox Creek. Several roads were flooded including State Route 762, Flat Ridge Road, Fox Creek Road and Honey Grove Road. Flood damage was particularly severe along Honey Grove Road where the road was completely destroyed in a small section and two large drainage pipes washed out. According to VDOT damage to the road there cost $25,000 to repair. In addition, a camper was reportedly washed away and several private bridges were also damaged.

In advance of this system,|strong southeast winds produced wind damage across the higher elevations. These southeast winds also provided strong upslope lifting along the Blue Ridge. This helped produce heavy rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches and areas of flash flooding. Enough heating occurred ahead of the cold front on the 16th to trigger severe thunderstorms along and east of the Blue Ridge, resulting in widespread thunderstorm wind damage and two tornadoes. Behind the storms, strong northwest winds knocked down many trees given the very wet soil conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused numerous roads to be flooded across the county. This includes Route 8 between Floyd and the Blue Ridge Parkway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across southeast West Virginia and into western Virginia in association with strong surface heating and a disturbance moving east out of Kentucky. Heavy rains from these storms produced flash flooding on McAfee Run in Craig County. Rainfall was 1 to 2 inches in a few hours, with 1.79 inches recorded by the Abbott IFLOWS rain gage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 1 to 2 inches in a few hours caused McAfee run to flood and close Route 621 west of Abbott, with 3 feet of water reported over the road. Location approximately 3/4 of a mile west of Route 311.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The atmosphere quickly became very unstable on the afternoon of May 26th, which resulted in the development of severe thunderstorms, mainly in the mountains and foothills. These storms were primarily large  hail producers. Also, A derecho-like feature crossed Franklin and Henry counties causing some significant damage. In addition, rainfall of 1 to 3 inches fell in a swath from Grayson County northeast all the way to Alleghany County causing isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mudslide occurred on Route 274 between Independence and Fries as 2 to 4 inches of rain fell in several hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong closed upper level low pressure moved across the Ohio valley, producing a variety of extreme weather across southwest Virginia. In advance of this system,|strong southeast winds produced wind damage across the higher elevations. These southeast winds also provided strong upslope lifting along the Blue Ridge. This helped produce heavy rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches and areas of flash flooding. Enough heating occurred ahead of the cold front on the 16th to trigger severe thunderstorms along and east of the Blue Ridge, resulting in widespread thunderstorm wind damage and two tornadoes. Behind the storms, strong northwest winds knocked down many trees given the very wet soil conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains flooded portions of the southwest part of Roanoke. The intersection of Franklin Road and Colonial Avenue flooded, as well as the intersection of Franklin and Brandon Avenue. A few houses were also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong closed upper level low pressure moved across the Ohio valley, producing a variety of extreme weather across southwest Virginia. In advance of this system,|strong southeast winds produced wind damage across the higher elevations. These southeast winds also provided strong upslope lifting along the Blue Ridge. This helped produce heavy rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches and areas of flash flooding. Enough heating occurred ahead of the cold front on the 16th to trigger severe thunderstorms along and east of the Blue Ridge, resulting in widespread thunderstorm wind damage and two tornadoes. Behind the storms, strong northwest winds knocked down many trees given the very wet soil conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred in the Tanglewood and Cave Spring portions of Roanoke County. Dozens of cars were flooded in Tanglewood's mall's parking lot. Other areas of flooded roadways occurred along Electric Road, Ogden Road and Circle Brook Drive in the Tanglewood area. Merriman Road and Starlight Road flooded in Cave Spring. A large section of Cave Spring High School was also flooded along with numerous homes.

In advance of this system,|strong southeast winds produced wind damage across the higher elevations. These southeast winds also provided strong upslope lifting along the Blue Ridge. This helped produce heavy rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches and areas of flash flooding. Enough heating occurred ahead of the cold front on the 16th to trigger severe thunderstorms along and east of the Blue Ridge, resulting in widespread thunderstorm wind damage and two tornadoes. Behind the storms, strong northwest winds knocked down many trees given the very wet soil conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Back Creek Flooded along Bent Mountain Road and Cotton Hill Road. Other areas around Bent Mountain also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong closed upper level low pressure moved across the Ohio valley, producing a variety of extreme weather across southwest Virginia. In advance of this system,|strong southeast winds produced wind damage across the higher elevations. These southeast winds also provided strong upslope lifting along the Blue Ridge. This helped produce heavy rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches and areas of flash flooding. Enough heating occurred ahead of the cold front on the 16th to trigger severe thunderstorms along and east of the Blue Ridge, resulting in widespread thunderstorm wind damage and two tornadoes. Behind the storms, strong northwest winds knocked down many trees given the very wet soil conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Stewartsville Road from block 24 to 12300 was flooded. Also flooding was reported along Saunders Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed along a cold front across the Tennessee valley and moved across West Virginia and Virginia. A substantial fetch of moisture developed off the Atlantic Ocean and helped to allow showers and thunderstorms that formed to be efficient rain producers.  One such cluster of storms moved across the area of Botetourt, Rockbridge and Amherst County region of Virginia. The resultant rainfall caused flash flooding along Back Creek. The flood waters prompted closure of Route 64, Lithia Road.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain prompted flash flooding along Back Creek. The resultant water prompted the subsequent closure of Route 64, Lithia Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front slowly passed through the region during the morning of the 28th A southerly flow ahead of the front caused deep moisture over the area. The cold front combined with the instability to trigger showers and thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall rates. Slow moving and training convection combined to produce flash flooding in some locations, as rainfall amounts of up to 2.5 inches were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A bridge over Route 609 was washed out due to flash flooding.  A rain gage in the area measured 2.02 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front slowly passed through the region during the morning of the 28th A southerly flow ahead of the front caused deep moisture over the area. The cold front combined with the instability to trigger showers and thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall rates. Slow moving and training convection combined to produce flash flooding in some locations, as rainfall amounts of up to 2.5 inches were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A basement was inundated by nearly 3.5 feet of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front slowly passed through the region during the morning of the 28th A southerly flow ahead of the front caused deep moisture over the area. The cold front combined with the instability to trigger showers and thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall rates. Slow moving and training convection combined to produce flash flooding in some locations, as rainfall amounts of up to 2.5 inches were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 628 was washed out due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front caused heavy rain which produced flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported on Jeanne Street and cars were under water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front caused heavy rain which produced flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Vehicles were washed away due to flooding in the Independence-Haygood area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front caused heavy rain which produced flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Shore Drive Westbound was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a cold front moving through the Washington metropolitan area. Heavy rainfall rates prompted flash flooding in parts of Fairfax County. Rainfall amounts of up to 3.23 inches were reported near Vienna.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Forest Heights Court was closed due to flash flooding.  A nearby rain gage measured 1.05 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed the Appalachians during the the afternoon and moved through northern Virginia during the evening.  Instability and moisture helped produce scattered showers and thunderstorms along this front.  Heavy rain associated with one of these cells produced an isolated flash flood in Shenandoah County.  A trained spotter in Dilbeck measured 1.50 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pughs Run was out of its banks onto Wetzerl Road.  The road was impassable and closed.  A nearby observer measured 1.46 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon of the 21st, a thunderstorm complex headed south through eastern Kentucky. Convection along the eastern edge of this system helped to prompt additional development farther east. This process repeated itself through the evening hours leading to multiple thunderstorms moving through the region, with many of the storms producing damaging wind or large hail. Flash flooding also occurred with some of the slower moving storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding along State Route 670, Burnt Chimney Road. Water was flowing across the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite being under the influence by an area of high pressure, enough ridge top convergence of winds took place to help facilitate the development of isolated to scattered thunderstorms. A number of these storms reached severe levels with large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy and persistent heavy rain from slow moving thunderstorms prompted creeks to leave their banks. Willow Springs Road in Ceres was washed out due to water flowing across it. Damage values are estimated.

Convection along the eastern edge of this system helped to prompt additional development farther east. This process repeated itself through the evening hours leading to multiple thunderstorms moving through the region, with many of the storms producing damaging wind or large hail. Flash flooding also occurred with some of the slower moving storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and flash flooding caused the roadway to become damaged on Pollard Street at the intersection of Cleveland Avenue. The intersection needed to be closed through the following day due to the damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon of the 21st, a thunderstorm complex headed south through eastern Kentucky. Convection along the eastern edge of this system helped to prompt additional development farther east. This process repeated itself through the evening hours leading to multiple thunderstorms moving through the region, with many of the storms producing damaging wind or large hail. Flash flooding also occurred with some of the slower moving storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding from heavy rain resulted in one foot of running water at the intersection of Route 460 and Gus w Nicks Boulevard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper level storm system moved across the area during the afternoon, and combined with daytime heating, ignited thunderstorms across northwest North Carolina and up into Virginia, in the vicinity of the Blue Ridge. Enough instability existed for some of these storms to become severe. Enough moisture was present, and storm motion was slow enough, to also bring very heavy rain from these storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain of 2 to 4 inches in a few hours caused creek flooding across the area. This includes the flooding of Walker Creek and the closing of Porter Valley Road and Wassum valley Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abnormally moist atmosphere across the mid-Atlantic allowed showers and thunderstorms to produce exceptional rainfall rates across portions of northern Virginia|as the remnants of Tropical Depression Lee interacted with a nearly stationary boundary near the Mason-Dixon line. Major flooding and flash flooding occurred in numerous areas. The highest rainfall and worst flooding happened in a band from King George County northward into Fairfax County. An AWOS site in Fairfax County measured 13.48 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roadways were closed in eastern Spotsylvania County.  A sinkhole occurred near the intersection of Windsor Drive and Abbey Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level wave moved across the area during the afternoon. The lift created by this wave combined with moderate to strong instability over the region, produced widespread showers and thunderstorms. Enough dry air was present in the low and mid levels to allow for strong downbursts of winds to occur with many of these storms. A few storms also brought large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain of 2 to 4 inches in a few hours caused areas of flash flooding across Ferrum.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Irene tracked up the Mid-Atlantic Coast during the afternoon and evening hours of the 27th.  Heavy rains associated with Irene and her rainbands fell over saturated Stafford County.  Flash flooding resulted in some areas and flooding continued into the 28th as waters rose.  Storm total rainfall reached 2.79 near Stafford.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Harrell Road was closed between Forbes Street and Deacon Road due to flash flooding from Claiborne Run.  A nearby rain gauge totaled 2.40 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough over the east coast, combined with a boundary in our vicinity, provided the focus for scattered shower and thunderstorm development. Instability was moderate, but winds aloft were weak, and thus most storms remained under severe limits, however a few strengthened enough to produce strong winds. These storms did produce brief heavy rainfall, with a few areas experiencing mainly minor flash flooding. A stronger cold front pushed through on the 8th bringing a pattern change to the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain of 2 to 4 inches caused substantial standing water on Alum Spring Road.
