EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple locations along Long Hollow Road just north of the community of Buena Vista were experiencing flash flooding, including eight to twelve inches of water flowing over the road near the intersection with Catalpa Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably warm air, with afternoon temperatures reaching into the 60s and low 70s, and a surge of moisture from the Gulf of Mexico interacted with a slow moving cold front during the afternoon and evening hours of January 30th, resulting in strong low-topped showers and thunderstorms and widespread heavy rainfall. Despite weak CAPE associated with the frontal passage, low level wind shear was in excess of 60 knots across the region, which produced  lines of showers, often with strong winds but little to no lightning. Precipitable water values were observed to be in the 1.0 to 1.5 inch range, which is extremely high for January across the Appalachians and the nearby Piedmont region. To add to the flooding threat, ground conditions were already saturated from recent rain and snow during the days and weeks preceding the event.||Severe weather caused power outages across portions of southwest and central Virginia, with one of the highest concentrations of power outages occurring in Pulaski County, where nearly 1250 homes and businesses were without power during the evening of January 30th. The Virginia Department of Transportation reported as many as 35 roads were closed across mainly southwest Virginia due to flooding or flooding-related problems, and that clean up costs associated with flooding, landslides and debris flow was between 1.5 and 2 million dollars.||The following is a list of total rainfall amounts, in inches, across western and central Virginia:|| - Alleghany County - |    2.48   4 E Covington CCR,|    2.22   Gathright Dam COOP,|    2.10   Covington FP COOP,|    2.00   Rich Patch IFLOWS,|    1.96   Dunlap Creek Near Covington.|| - Amherst County - |    4.10   Pedlar Dam COOP.|| - Appomattox County - |    1.11   Appomattox COOP.|| - Bath County - |    3.16   Cassidy Bridge IFLOWS,|    3.05   Lime Kiln RAWS,|    2.76   Mill Creek,|    2.64   Trappers Lodge IFLOWS,|    2.36   Jordon Top IFLOWS,|    2.32   Pump Storage IFLOWS,|    2.31   Gathright Dam DCP,|    2.30   Williamsville,|    2.23   Hot Springs COOP,|    2.20   Douthat State Park IFLOWS,|    1.88   BaCreek Creek DCP at Sunrise,|    1.40   JaCreekson River Near Bacova,|    1.08   Ingalls Field Airport.|| - Bedford County - |    3.26   Holcomb RoCreek COOP,|    3.07   Bedford COOP,|    2.17   4 WSW Moneta CCR.|| - Bland County - |    1.49   Bland DCP.|| - Botetourt County - |    4.35   Apple Orchard IFLOWS,|    4.15   Lithia IFLOWS,|    3.64   Troutville IFLOWS,|    3.36   Glade Creek IFLOWS,|    3.00   Carvin Creek IFLOWS,|    2.96   Buchanan,|    2.83   Sloan Branch IFLOWS,|    2.76   Daleville IFLOWS/USGS,|    2.48   Tinker Creek IFLOWS,|    2.16   North Fork IFLOWS,|    2.12   Oriskany IFLOWS.|| - Buckingham County - |    1.10   Buckingham COOP.|| - City of Roanoke - |    4.14   Roanoke River at STP IFLOWS,|    4.03   Roanoke,|    3.11   Lower N. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was observed at the intersection of Blue Bend road with Jamestown Road, where a nearby creek flowed out of its banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably warm air, with afternoon temperatures reaching into the 60s and low 70s, and a surge of moisture from the Gulf of Mexico interacted with a slow moving cold front during the afternoon and evening hours of January 30th, resulting in strong low-topped showers and thunderstorms and widespread heavy rainfall. Despite weak CAPE associated with the frontal passage, low level wind shear was in excess of 60 knots across the region, which produced  lines of showers, often with strong winds but little to no lightning. Precipitable water values were observed to be in the 1.0 to 1.5 inch range, which is extremely high for January across the Appalachians and the nearby Piedmont region. To add to the flooding threat, ground conditions were already saturated from recent rain and snow during the days and weeks preceding the event.||Severe weather caused power outages across portions of southwest and central Virginia, with one of the highest concentrations of power outages occurring in Pulaski County, where nearly 1250 homes and businesses were without power during the evening of January 30th. The Virginia Department of Transportation reported as many as 35 roads were closed across mainly southwest Virginia due to flooding or flooding-related problems, and that clean up costs associated with flooding, landslides and debris flow was between 1.5 and 2 million dollars.||The following is a list of total rainfall amounts, in inches, across western and central Virginia:|| - Alleghany County - |    2.48   4 E Covington CCR,|    2.22   Gathright Dam COOP,|    2.10   Covington FP COOP,|    2.00   Rich Patch IFLOWS,|    1.96   Dunlap Creek Near Covington.|| - Amherst County - |    4.10   Pedlar Dam COOP.|| - Appomattox County - |    1.11   Appomattox COOP.|| - Bath County - |    3.16   Cassidy Bridge IFLOWS,|    3.05   Lime Kiln RAWS,|    2.76   Mill Creek,|    2.64   Trappers Lodge IFLOWS,|    2.36   Jordon Top IFLOWS,|    2.32   Pump Storage IFLOWS,|    2.31   Gathright Dam DCP,|    2.30   Williamsville,|    2.23   Hot Springs COOP,|    2.20   Douthat State Park IFLOWS,|    1.88   BaCreek Creek DCP at Sunrise,|    1.40   JaCreekson River Near Bacova,|    1.08   Ingalls Field Airport.|| - Bedford County - |    3.26   Holcomb RoCreek COOP,|    3.07   Bedford COOP,|    2.17   4 WSW Moneta CCR.|| - Bland County - |    1.49   Bland DCP.|| - Botetourt County - |    4.35   Apple Orchard IFLOWS,|    4.15   Lithia IFLOWS,|    3.64   Troutville IFLOWS,|    3.36   Glade Creek IFLOWS,|    3.00   Carvin Creek IFLOWS,|    2.96   Buchanan,|    2.83   Sloan Branch IFLOWS,|    2.76   Daleville IFLOWS/USGS,|    2.48   Tinker Creek IFLOWS,|    2.16   North Fork IFLOWS,|    2.12   Oriskany IFLOWS.|| - Buckingham County - |    1.10   Buckingham COOP.|| - City of Roanoke - |    4.14   Roanoke River at STP IFLOWS,|    4.03   Roanoke,|    3.11   Lower N. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A swift water rescue was performed when a creek overflowed its banks, pinning an automobile against trees along Eanes Ferry Road. After the rescue, the driver of the automobile was treated at the scene and released.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were reported closed or washed out in the Indian Valley area due to flash flooding. Flooding occurred on Indian Creek Road, Homestead Road, Horse Ridge Road and Duncans Chapel Road. Two homes were evacuated as flood waters entered the residences.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably warm air, with afternoon temperatures reaching into the 60s and low 70s, and a surge of moisture from the Gulf of Mexico interacted with a slow moving cold front during the afternoon and evening hours of January 30th, resulting in strong low-topped showers and thunderstorms and widespread heavy rainfall. Despite weak CAPE associated with the frontal passage, low level wind shear was in excess of 60 knots across the region, which produced  lines of showers, often with strong winds but little to no lightning. Precipitable water values were observed to be in the 1.0 to 1.5 inch range, which is extremely high for January across the Appalachians and the nearby Piedmont region. To add to the flooding threat, ground conditions were already saturated from recent rain and snow during the days and weeks preceding the event.||Severe weather caused power outages across portions of southwest and central Virginia, with one of the highest concentrations of power outages occurring in Pulaski County, where nearly 1250 homes and businesses were without power during the evening of January 30th. The Virginia Department of Transportation reported as many as 35 roads were closed across mainly southwest Virginia due to flooding or flooding-related problems, and that clean up costs associated with flooding, landslides and debris flow was between 1.5 and 2 million dollars.||The following is a list of total rainfall amounts, in inches, across western and central Virginia:|| - Alleghany County - |    2.48   4 E Covington CCR,|    2.22   Gathright Dam COOP,|    2.10   Covington FP COOP,|    2.00   Rich Patch IFLOWS,|    1.96   Dunlap Creek Near Covington.|| - Amherst County - |    4.10   Pedlar Dam COOP.|| - Appomattox County - |    1.11   Appomattox COOP.|| - Bath County - |    3.16   Cassidy Bridge IFLOWS,|    3.05   Lime Kiln RAWS,|    2.76   Mill Creek,|    2.64   Trappers Lodge IFLOWS,|    2.36   Jordon Top IFLOWS,|    2.32   Pump Storage IFLOWS,|    2.31   Gathright Dam DCP,|    2.30   Williamsville,|    2.23   Hot Springs COOP,|    2.20   Douthat State Park IFLOWS,|    1.88   BaCreek Creek DCP at Sunrise,|    1.40   JaCreekson River Near Bacova,|    1.08   Ingalls Field Airport.|| - Bedford County - |    3.26   Holcomb RoCreek COOP,|    3.07   Bedford COOP,|    2.17   4 WSW Moneta CCR.|| - Bland County - |    1.49   Bland DCP.|| - Botetourt County - |    4.35   Apple Orchard IFLOWS,|    4.15   Lithia IFLOWS,|    3.64   Troutville IFLOWS,|    3.36   Glade Creek IFLOWS,|    3.00   Carvin Creek IFLOWS,|    2.96   Buchanan,|    2.83   Sloan Branch IFLOWS,|    2.76   Daleville IFLOWS/USGS,|    2.48   Tinker Creek IFLOWS,|    2.16   North Fork IFLOWS,|    2.12   Oriskany IFLOWS.|| - Buckingham County - |    1.10   Buckingham COOP.|| - City of Roanoke - |    4.14   Roanoke River at STP IFLOWS,|    4.03   Roanoke,|    3.11   Lower N. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight inches of water was observed flowing across the 8400 block of Potts Creek Road, forcing the road to be closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary moved northward and stalled over the Mid-Atlantic/I-95 corridor overnight.  An upper level low approached the region and a upper level jet added to enhanced lift in the region.  Heavy rain caused a lot of flash flooding with amounts up to seven inches in less than 6 hours recorded near Washington Dulles Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A road was closed due to flash flooding at 3600 Block of Dick Woods Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak mid level flow existed over a moist lower atmosphere.  Slow moving showers, with embedded thunderstorms, developed near dawn over Buchanan County.  These showers moved along their northwest to southeast axis, causing repetitive showers over the small streams during the morning.  ||Rain amounts of 2 to 2.5 inches of rain were measured around Grundy in 3 to 4 hours.  Radar estimated rain amounts upwards of 3 inches.  A few small streams in the mountainous terrain flooded the narrow hollows between the Kentucky border and the Grundy vicinity. The steep terrain also caused some saturated mountainsides to slide into homes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small streams, such as Lynn Camp Creek, Old Home Creek, Jacks Creek, and Stiltner Creek flooded.  Water was 1 to 2 feet deep in spots on adjacent roads.  The water damaged the roads and the private bridges to residences.||Seven homes were damaged.  Most of the damage was from water in the basements.  One double wide manufactured home was knocked off its foundation from a land slide.  Another slide knocked a tree into a carport, damaged the car and the back of the home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary was located across southwest Virginia.  In advance of this frontal boundary was an extremely moist air mass with precipitable water values around 2.0 inches that had persisted across the region much of the later half of July.  In addition, a persistent upper-level trough was noted across the eastern U.S. with a strong subtropical ridge in the western U.S.  The combination of these factors contributed to yet another afternoon/evening of pulse thunderstorms that persisted well after midnight in areas of local wind convergence.  Rainfall rates were excessive, and exceeded four inches in a four hour or less period across parts of Halifax county causing some small creeks and streams to flow out of their banks.  This event continued into the early morning hours of August 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Halifax County 911 Center reported that Poplar Creek near the intersection of Summit Drive and Railroad Street in South Boston was out of its banks causing Summit Drive in this area to be closed.  The water was at least three inches deep flowing over the road. Damages were confined to minor debris removal.  This event continued into the early morning hours of August 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary was located across southwest Virginia.  In advance of this frontal boundary was an extremely moist air mass with precipitable water values around 2.0 inches that had persisted across the region much of the later half of July.  In addition, a persistent upper-level trough was noted across the eastern U.S. with a strong subtropical ridge in the western U.S.  The combination of these factors contributed to yet another afternoon/evening of pulse thunderstorms that persisted well after midnight in areas of local wind convergence.  Rainfall rates were excessive, and exceeded four inches in a four hour or less period across parts of Halifax county causing some small creeks and streams to flow out of their banks.  This event began during the last hour of the day on July 31, 2013.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Halifax County 911 Center reported that Poplar Creek, near the intersection of Summit Drive and Railroad Street in South Boston, was out of its banks causing Summit Drive in this area to be closed.  The water was at least three inches deep flowing over the road. Damages were confined to minor debris removal.  This event began at 1110 pm EST on July 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front to a warm front remain draped across southern Virginia and southern West Virginia.  This boundary combined with a persistent moist, unstable air mass across the region served as a focusing mechanism for scattered afternoon and evening thunderstorm development across the region once again.  As had been the case much of the summer of 2013, heavy rain and flash flooding were once again the main concerns.  Thunderstorms across southwest Virginia during the evening prompted several flash flood warnings netting several flash flood events as rainfall of two to four inches fell in flash flood prone areas within a couple of hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Carroll County 911 Center reported that several inches of water were flowing over Ivanhoe Road approximately five miles north of Fries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Well south of the prefrontal convection, a small cluster of showers and thunderstorms became anchored over the mountains of southern Buchanan County during the early evening on Labor Day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain estimates of 1.5 to 2 inches in an hour and a storm total of 2 to 2.5 inches in 3 hours fell mainly southwest of Vansant toward Leemaster and Prater.||Small streams, such as Trace Fork Branch and War Fork, flooded and damaged roads.  Water was around a mobile home along Route 83.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front to a warm front remain draped across southern Virginia and southern West Virginia.  This boundary combined with a persistent moist, unstable air mass across the region served as a focusing mechanism for scattered afternoon and evening thunderstorm development across the region once again.  As had been the case much of the summer of 2013, heavy rain and flash flooding were once again the main concerns.  Thunderstorms across southwest Virginia during the evening prompted several flash flood warnings netting several flash flood events as rainfall of two to four inches fell in flash flood prone areas within a couple of hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and the Virginia Department of Highways reported that several creeks in the Ceres area were out of their banks causing the flooding of several roads and adjacent areas.  Virginia Route 626 was flooded from Page Branch where a parked vehicle was partially submerged.  Heninger Branch Creek on the south side of Ceres was also out of its banks rendering Stowers Hill Road impassable.  Finally, Birch Grove Road on the southeast side of Ceres was also flooded.  A spotter near Ceres recorded 3.25 inches of rain in less than an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist air mass persisted across the region.  Precipitable water values remained near 2.0 inches.  A frontal boundary was stalled just to the west of the area.  Just as was the case on the 8th, scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours.  On this day, one area of fairly concentrated thunderstorms developed along the Blue Ridge Mountains across Patrick county and persisted in that area for a couple of hours during the evening.  Rainfall amounts near four inches were observed near Stuart and Critz, which resulted in localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that flash flooding at the intersection of Spring Road and Pleasant View Drive, caused by overflowing Laurel Branch Creek, resulted in a vehicle being inundated which subsequently stalled out.  Several large tree logs, approximately 10 to 15 feet long, stored in the vicinity, were washed about 300 yards downstream from their original location.  Radar-estimated rainfall from the area was three to four inches in less than two hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist air mass persisted across the region.  Precipitable water values remained near 2.0 inches.  A frontal boundary was stalled just to the west of the area.  Just as was the case on the 8th, scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours.  On this day, one area of fairly concentrated thunderstorms developed along the Blue Ridge Mountains across Patrick county and persisted in that area for a couple of hours during the evening.  Rainfall amounts near four inches were observed near Stuart and Critz, which resulted in localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports sent to the Blacksburg, Virginia Facebook and Twitter Pages indicated that both Anglin Branch Creek and Rich Creek were overflowing as a result of heavy rainfall in the area resulting in flash flooding to adjacent areas.  Martin Farm Road was flooded at the Anglin Branch Creek bridge with water flowing over the road.  Dr. Kay Lane near the Animal Clinic was flooded by Rich Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong upper trough was deepening across the central U.S.  A cold front was approaching southwest Virginia from the west.  Very moist tropical air was present across the region once again as this event unfolded, with precipitable water values once again near or in excess of 2.0 inches across the area.  Thunderstorms developed quickly during the afternoon across southwest Virginia, especially across Giles and Wythe counties.  Flash flooding was widespread across much of Giles county, including the cities of Pembroke, Pearisburg, and Rich Creek.  The flash flooding was quite significant in Pembroke where a number of homes and businesses sustained damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: WDBJ7 Television of Roanoke, Virginia and WVVA Television of Bluefield, WV reported that significant flash flooding affected the community of Pembroke in northeastern Giles county.  Nearly three inches of rain fell in an hour causing creeks, streams, and drainage ditches in the area to quickly flash flood the town, which is in a relatively low elevation area compared to surrounding higher terrain and mountains (e.g., Pembroke's elevation is about 1600 feet, while Mountain Lake just a few miles to the east is over 4000 feet and Peters mountain just to the north is near 3500 feet elevation).  Although flooding was reported along Doe Creek, the most significant flash flooding was the result of a clogged drainage ditch that runs under U.S. Highway 460 just east of downtown Pembroke.  U.S. Highway 460 was completely closed during the event as mud, rocks, gravel, tree limbs, roots, and other debris washed out over the road.  A number of homes and businesses in the area suffered extensive damage from the flood waters and resultant mud and debris that damaged the structures.  Several vehicles were also flooded in the area as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms formed in a moist and moderately to strongly unstable air mass situated on the periphery of a large Upper Level High Pressure System over the Ohio Valley. The storms produced mostly wind damage. However, training convective cells produced some major flash flooding across the Tri-Cities area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding observed across Gate City and Speers Ferry with some road closures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary moved northward and stalled over the Mid-Atlantic/I-95 corridor overnight.  An upper level low approached the region and a upper level jet added to enhanced lift in the region.  Heavy rain caused a lot of flash flooding with amounts up to seven inches in less than 6 hours recorded near Washington Dulles Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Taylors Gap Road was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary moved northward and stalled over the Mid-Atlantic/I-95 corridor overnight.  An upper level low approached the region and a upper level jet added to enhanced lift in the region.  Heavy rain caused a lot of flash flooding with amounts up to seven inches in less than 6 hours recorded near Washington Dulles Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was flash flooding reported on Braddock Road near Old Lee Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary moved northward and stalled over the Mid-Atlantic/I-95 corridor overnight.  An upper level low approached the region and a upper level jet added to enhanced lift in the region.  Heavy rain caused a lot of flash flooding with amounts up to seven inches in less than 6 hours recorded near Washington Dulles Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was flash flooding reported near the intersection of National Drive and Airline Parkway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary moved northward and stalled over the Mid-Atlantic/I-95 corridor overnight.  An upper level low approached the region and a upper level jet added to enhanced lift in the region.  Heavy rain caused a lot of flash flooding with amounts up to seven inches in less than 6 hours recorded near Washington Dulles Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Loop Road was flooded at a bridge near Naked Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary moved northward and stalled over the Mid-Atlantic/I-95 corridor overnight.  An upper level low approached the region and a upper level jet added to enhanced lift in the region.  Heavy rain caused a lot of flash flooding with amounts up to seven inches in less than 6 hours recorded near Washington Dulles Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were two feet of water flowing over top Dovel Hollow Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front moved through the region and stalled over the area.  Convergence along the boundary led to heavy showers.  A few breaks in the clouds led to an increase in instability and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain in activity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: University Ave at Business US-29 was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary moved northward and stalled over the Mid-Atlantic/I-95 corridor overnight.  An upper level low approached the region and a upper level jet added to enhanced lift in the region.  Heavy rain caused a lot of flash flooding with amounts up to seven inches in less than 6 hours recorded near Washington Dulles Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A road was washed out in the Branch Mountain area off Patrick Henry Highway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon convection again bubbled up over southwest Virginia in evening hours of the 12th with very heavy rains over the City of Galax, Grayson and Carroll counties where 2 to 3 inch rains fell. Several flooding reports were received. Several gauges in the Galax area had over 2 inches for the period ending 0700 EDT on the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A portion of Highway 94 was washed out resulting in the road closure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist air mass and weak steering currents allowed for diurnal convection to produce localized heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding on Bethesda Road. Flowing water causing road closures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The eastern half of the United States was under cyclonic flow and moisture from the Atlantic and Gulf continued to move into the Mid Atlantic. A warm front moved northward and showers and thunderstorms broke out across the area. Heavy rain produced flash flooding and rapid rises on streams and creeks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a water rescued performed on Old Lee Road at Stronecroft Boulevard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm and moist conditions led to showers and thunderstorms to develop as a upper level trough passed the region. Some thunderstorms led to large hail, damaging winds and heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: East bound Route 7 was closed at West Market Street due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm and moist conditions led to showers and thunderstorms to develop as a upper level trough passed the region. Some thunderstorms led to large hail, damaging winds and heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was 6-8 inches of water flowing over Bridgeview Court near the intersection of Route 7 and Route 9.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms with generous instability developed with an area weak steering flow. Some of the thunderstorms became strong enough to produce up to half-dollar size hail. Also, given the slow motion of the storms, heavy rain was abundant with localized flash flooding in a part of Patrick County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated two to three inches of rain fell in 50 minutes over the southeast part of Patrick County. This amount and rate of rainfall allowed Witt Creek to overflow its banks and flood a potion of Route 8. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm and moist conditions led to showers and thunderstorms to develop as a upper level trough passed the region. Some thunderstorms led to large hail, damaging winds and heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a portion of dry Mill Road between Woodburn and Thomas Mill Roads washed away near Goose Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm and moist conditions led to showers and thunderstorms to develop as a upper level trough passed the region. Some thunderstorms led to large hail, damaging winds and heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Logmill Road was closed between Mountain Road and Highway 15 due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Easterly flow led to upslope conditions along the Blue Ridge Mountains and thunderstorms stayed stationary leading to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The sheriff reported flash flooding near 5600 Block of Sugar Hollow Road at Moormans River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front slowly pushed across the area during the afternoon and evening and interacted with deep moisture from Hurricane Arthur tracking up the east coast. This triggered widespread thunderstorms activity with some high winds, hail and heavy rainfall. A Flash Flood Watch was issued early on the 3rd and showers and thunderstorms by mid-afternoon prompted the issuance of several Flood Advisories (FLS) mainly in urban areas including Roanoke and Buena Vista. A Small Stream FLS was issued by late afternoon across parts of Wythe and Grayson counties where radar estimated over 3 inches of rainfall in some basins.  An Urban Flood Warning was issued for the City of Galax, where there were reports of some urban-type flooding.  As the area of heavy rainfall shifted further east a Flash Flood Warning (FFW) was issued for parts of Patrick, Henry, Floyd and Franklin counties at 513 PM. Later information was received that a road was completely washed out by flood waters in eastern Floyd County in an area of 2 to 4 inch rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Shooting Creek Road was damaged by runoff from heavy rains. A VDOT crew was repairing the road the next day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across southern portions of the Virginia Eastern Shore.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced 3 to 5 inches of rain in a small area around Cape Charles, VA. Flooding was reported on many streets in Cape Charles. Several cars were flooded by 2 to 3 feet of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and scattered thunderstorms associated with low pressure along the North Carolina Coast produced locally heavy rainfall and resulted in flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many roads were flooded at Old Dominion University. The intersection of Early and Llewellyn Avenue and underpass of 21st Street and Colley Avenue were flooded. Also, 45th Street was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and scattered thunderstorms associated with low pressure along the North Carolina Coast produced locally heavy rainfall and resulted in flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread street flooding and road closures in Churchland area and downtown. Effingham Street was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wedge cold front was stalled across southwest Virginia into north central North Carolina.  Temperatures behind the wedge front were well below seasonal normals with maximum temperatures only in the 50s.  Meanwhile...a very deep closed upper low (467mb at 500mb) was shifting slowing eastward from the central U.S. into the eastern U.S.  A deep conveyor belt of moisture was spreading northward from the Gulf of Mexico up and over the shallow wedge of cool air.  Light to moderate rain had persisted across the region for a couple of days, but rainfall amounts had been mostly around 1 to 1.5 inch. However, as the wedge boundary began to retreat during the afternoon, strong thunderstorms with very heavy rain formed across Southside Virginia and the Virginia and North Carolina Piedmont and spread across the region in several bands, dumping local rainfall amounts in excess of 2.0 inches in a few hours.  This result in localized flash flooding mainly across Charlotte and Campbell counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Charlotte County 911 Center reported that Robin Road was flooded and closed approximately six miles east-northeast of Brookneal where it crosses Turnip Creek as a result of flood waters from Turnip Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wedge cold front was stalled across southwest Virginia into north central North Carolina.  Temperatures behind the wedge front were well below seasonal normals with maximum temperatures only in the 50s.  Meanwhile...a very deep closed upper low (467mb at 500mb) was shifting slowing eastward from the central U.S. into the eastern U.S.  A deep conveyor belt of moisture was spreading northward from the Gulf of Mexico up and over the shallow wedge of cool air.  Light to moderate rain had persisted across the region for a couple of days, but rainfall amounts had been mostly around 1 to 1.5 inch. However, as the wedge boundary began to retreat during the afternoon, strong thunderstorms with very heavy rain formed across Southside Virginia and the Virginia and North Carolina Piedmont and spread across the region in several bands, dumping local rainfall amounts in excess of 2.0 inches in a few hours.  This result in localized flash flooding mainly across Charlotte and Campbell counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Campbell County 911 Center reported that Morris Church Road was flooded and closed approximately five miles west of Red House.  This flooding appeared to be the result of Little Falling River or one of its tributaries overflowing their banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wedge cold front was stalled across southwest Virginia into north central North Carolina.  Temperatures behind the wedge front were well below seasonal normals with maximum temperatures only in the 50s.  Meanwhile...a very deep closed upper low (467mb at 500mb) was shifting slowing eastward from the central U.S. into the eastern U.S.  A deep conveyor belt of moisture was spreading northward from the Gulf of Mexico up and over the shallow wedge of cool air.  Light to moderate rain had persisted across the region for a couple of days, but rainfall amounts had been mostly around 1 to 1.5 inch. However, as the wedge boundary began to retreat during the afternoon, strong thunderstorms with very heavy rain formed across Southside Virginia and the Virginia and North Carolina Piedmont and spread across the region in several bands, dumping local rainfall amounts in excess of 2.0 inches in a few hours.  This result in localized flash flooding mainly across Charlotte and Campbell counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Campbell County 911 Center reported that Dog Creek Road was flooded and closed as a result of flood waters from Dog Creek just before it flows into the Roanoke River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clusters of showers and thunderstorms moved north during the overnight hours of the 11th into the 12th.  Rains estimated at 1.5 to 2 inches of fell in a few hours over wet terrain.  Minor flash flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Feeder streams into Knox Creek, including Laurel Fork, flooded and closed roads.  No structures were flooded.  Mud and debris slides also occurred in this steep terrain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low pressure system passed east across the northern Great Plains, drawing deep moisture along the Appalachian Chain from the Gulf of Mexico.  An upper level disturbance moved across the central Appalachians early in the day, pushing a line of showers with heavy rain across the forecast region.  While a break in rainfall developed across the mountains and foothills behind the line of convection, the line stalled east of Danville and Lynchburg, where prolonged periods of heavy rain fell throughout the afternoon.  A cold front entered the Mountain Empire and southeast West Virginia during mid-afternoon, triggering another round of heavy showers and isolated thunderstorms that quickly filled in ahead of the boundary.  For the entire event, one to three inch rainfall amounts were common across the entire forecast region.  ||In addition to some reports of flash flooding, river flooding was also observed from Halifax through Buckingham Counties.  The Roanoke River at Randolph was among those most affected, with the river rising to the moderate flood stage of 24.9 feet.||Below are locations which received at least three inches of rainfall for the event and their total rainfall amounts.||North Carolina|...Caswell County...|    4.42   Yanceyville 4 SE COOP||...Watauga County...|    4.19   Sandy Flats IFLOWS|    4.18   2 NE blowing Rock CCR|    3.92   1 WSW Foscoe CCR|    3.75   Blackburn Knob IFLOWS|    3.70   Boone 1 SE COOP|    3.60   Howards Knob IFLOWS|    3.47   Boone|    3.47   Foscoe IFLOWS|    3.20   Parkway School IFLOWS|    3.11   Triplett ||Virginia|...Appomattox County...|    3.53   Appomattox COOP||...Buckingham County...|    3.84   Buckingham COOP||...Campbell County...|    3.68   3 E Brookneal CCR|    3.44   Brookneal COOP|    3.24   1 WSW Lynchburg CCR|    3.20   Lynchburg Airport|    3.12   Concord||...Charlotte County...|    5.68   4 SE Saxe CCR|    4.98   Charlotte Courthouse COOP||...Floyd County...|    3.03   6 S Copper Hill CCR||...Halifax County...|    4.43   Randolph|    3.74   South Boston COOP||...Tazewell County...|    3.25   Springville IFLOWS.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of water was observed flowing over Gidsville Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: U.S. Highway 360 was closed near Daniels Creek Trail as six to eight inches of water was observed flowing over the bridge at this location.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Summit drive was flooded at Poplar Creek in South Boston.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of water was observed flowing over U.S. Highway 360 near Bethel Road. Six inches of water were also observed flowing over Terry Bridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front sagged south into southern West Virginia by dawn on the 4th.  A strong low pressure for early June moved east through the Midwest, along the frontal boundary, during the day on the 4th.  Dew points were in the upper 60s and lower 70s near and south of the front.  The disturbance passed to the east by early on the 5th. ||Several rounds of showers and thunderstorms passed through eastern Kentucky and West Virginia during the afternoon and evening hours on the 4th.   The last round of the showers and thunderstorms sank down into northern Buchanan County after 0000E on the 5th.  These lingering bands of showers and storms became oriented northwest to southeast along their movement.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 2 to 3.5 inches of rain fell in less than 3 hours.  The hardest hit basins in this steep mountain terrain were along Upper Elk Creek and Guesses Fork.  Small private bridges to homes were washed out.  Roads were damaged.  A few homes had minor basement flooding.||The axis of this small heavy rain area crossed the state border.  Flash flooding also occurred in a small section of McDowell County, West Virginia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper level trough tapped into Gulf and Atlantic moisture which led to heavy rain across the Mid Atlantic. Tropical-like conditions resulted in showers and thunderstorms to persist before a cold front moved through later in the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Old Charles Town Road was flooded at Opequon Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper level trough tapped into Gulf and Atlantic moisture which led to heavy rain across the Mid Atlantic. Tropical-like conditions resulted in showers and thunderstorms to persist before a cold front moved through later in the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The South Fork Catoctin Creek was flooded at Waterford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper level trough tapped into Gulf and Atlantic moisture which led to heavy rain across the Mid Atlantic. Tropical-like conditions resulted in showers and thunderstorms to persist before a cold front moved through later in the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around a foot of flowing water closed Kirby Road in McLean.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple, heavy rain producing thunderstorms moved across portions of southwest Virginia during the afternoon hours. Some locations received generous rainfall and heavy rainfall rates on the order of 4 to 6 inches per hour. The community of Chilhowie receive such a storm that produced flash flooding that closed roads and damaged at least one building.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from a thunderstorm produce up to three inches of rain. This amount of water caused flash flooding that prompted street closures along and near the main thoroughfare of the Lee Highway/Route 11/Main Steet. Specific locations closed include Route 11 near Walton Avenue, the intersection of Deer Valley and Taddler Branch, Route 11 at Pine Avenue, and portions of Hood Street. A business was inundated with flood waters along east Main Street. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved across the region in advance of an approaching cold front. This system helped to generate showers and storms across the area. One of these storms increased to severe levels and produced damaging winds that blew large tree limbs down in Big Island. Other showers and storms produced up to two inches of rain on average in a short period of time near the border of Craig and Montgomery Counties. Flash flooding ensued in both counties with a localized 4.5 inch rainfall total at the site of the Craig County flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall totaling 4.5 inches fell on a property along Cumberland Gap Road with the heaviest rainfall occurring between 700 and 730 pm EDT. The resultant runoff caused the property to be flooded. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted north across the region during the day. Showers and storms developed within the unstable air to its south by the afternoon. Some of these storms increased to severe levels. A thunderstorm complex moved along the front during the evening hours and brought an additional round of severe weather to parts of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding resulted in the closure of US Route 29S. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved across the region in advance of an approaching cold front. This system helped to generate showers and storms across the area. One of these storms increased to severe levels and produced damaging winds that blew large tree limbs down in Big Island. Other showers and storms produced up to two inches of rain on average in a short period of time near the border of Craig and Montgomery Counties. Flash flooding ensued in both counties with a localized 4.5 inch rainfall total at the site of the Craig County flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain prompted flash flooding along Mt Tabor Road. An estimated eight inches of water was flowing across the road, and gravel was also washing onto the road. Damage values are estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Mid-Atlantic was in between a cold front approaching form the Appalachian Mountains and Hurricane Arthur off the Delaware Coast. Warm and humid conditions were across the region and showers and thunderstorms led to heavy rain. Unstable conditions led to severe thunderstorms that produced damaging winds and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were parking lots and yards flooded by flowing water off Bookerdale Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms associated with a cold front produced locally heavy rainfall and resulted in flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding in portions of Suffolk. Flooding was reported on Clay Street with water flowing into homes. Also, a car was partially submerged in high water in the Pleasant Hill area. The occupants were rescued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front was approaching the Mid-Atlantic from the Ohio Valley while low pressure developed along the front to the southwest. Showers and thunderstorms formed ahead of the front in a very moist atmosphere. Flash flooding occurred around the Washington DC metro mainly in Fairfax County VA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was six inches of water flowing across Birdfoot Court at Stuart Mill Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: East 8th Street was closed due to high water at North Commerce Avenue.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was six to eight inches of flowing water near the intersection of Buck Mountain Road and Simmons Gap Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front was approaching the Mid-Atlantic from the Ohio Valley while low pressure developed along the front to the southwest. Showers and thunderstorms formed ahead of the front in a very moist atmosphere. Flash flooding occurred around the Washington DC metro mainly in Fairfax County VA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream gauge on Accotink Creek at Annandale reached a flood state of 9.5 feet. It crested at 9.84 at 22:00 EST. Woodburn Road was flooded at Accotink Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving and persistent storms across parts of central and southern Grayson County produced rainfall of 1 to 3 inches with isolated amounts up to 5 inches in a few hours. The IFLOWS rain gage at Bethel (BTHV2) measured 5.20 inches in 4 hours ending at 0400 LST (2300Z) on May 12. The gage is located in the South Branch of Elk Creek near where flash flooding was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Big Ridge Road was flooded by waters from South Fork Elk Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective complex moved southeast and reached into southwest Virginia during the early evening hours on the 13th.||More thunderstorms formed during the overnight hours and moved southeast into Virginia during the predawn hours on the 14th.  This caused some flash flooding near dawn.||Finally, thunderstorms formed in northern Ohio ahead of a cold front and mid level disturbance during the midday and early afternoon on the 14th.  These storms formed into a squall line and moved southeast, reaching Virginia during the early evening hours of the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small streams quickly rose and temporarily closed roads. Examples included Long Branch near Patterson and Dismal Creek near Whitewood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm over northeast Tazewell County produced 2 or more inches of rain a few hours and caused some pockets of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported to be flowing across several roads in the Abbs Valley Area including portions of Abbs Valley Road, Route 161 and Bo Street rendering them impassable and closed in those locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper low and associated weak cold front pushed across the mountains during the day and produced some heavy downpours and isolated flash flooding. There were some impressive rainfall reports including a date record for June 2 at Roanoke ASOS (ROA) of 3.11 inches, easily breaking the date record of 2.11 inches set in 1959. This ranked as the 6th wettest June day in the climate records for Roanoke, dating back to 1912. The IFLOWS gage at New Castle (NECV2) in Craig County measured 3.93 inches in 3 hours and 3.03 in 1 hour (ending at 8 PM local daylight time). This 1-hour value is in excess of a 200-year event (.005 Annual Exceedance  Probability) at this duration and location.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant street flooding was reported across the city of Roanoke. 24th Street NW was closed at Shaffers Crossing along with other locations. Manhole covers were blown off some drains and flooding reported in Brookside Park.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Route 311 and Route 616 were closed due the heavy rainfall in and around New Castle. Minor flooding in an apartment complex was also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous streets were flooded and many were closed in portions of Virginia Beach. Flooding occurred at Oceana Naval Air Station also. Two to three inches of rain fell in these areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moved through the region in the morning hours and showers and thunderstorms formed in a humid air mass. Heavy rain led to flash flooding which led to many areas in the Shenandoah Valley flooded through the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was water entering a home near Woodstock.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Potent low pressure passed by to our west, and the warm front associated with the low moved through our area during this time. Warm and moist air near and south of the boundary led to an unstable atmosphere, while forcing from the warm front provided the lift. Thunderstorms developed and produced copious amounts of rainfall east of the Blue Ridge Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Cambridge Street and Warrenton Road was closed due to high water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream gauge on Passage Creek at Buckton reached a flood stage of 9 feet. It peaked at 9.10 feet at 18:15 EST. Fields near the creek began to flood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and thunderstorms with embedded severe thunderstorms moved through the region ahead of an approaching cold front. Southerly flow ahead of the front resulted in modest instability and shear. Some storms produced copious amounts of rainfall that led to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a road closed at the intersection of Edsall Road and Industrial Drive due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Remnants of Tropical Storm Bill moved into the Mid-Atlantic causing moisture to increase. Showers and thunderstorms led to heavy rain across the Interstate 95 corridor and flash flooding occurred. Some rivers also went to flood into June 21, 2015.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Richmond Highway or route 1 was closed near Fairfax County Parkway due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front slowly approached and moved south through the Mid Atlantic late in the day. Ahead of the front, southerly flow ushered in a warm and moist air mass. Numerous showers and thunderstorms with embedded strong to severe storms formed to the southwest and progressed to the northeast prior to the cold frontal passage. This activity produced copious amounts rain and led to flash flooding across the Central Foothills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 1500 block of route 616 was closed due to water over the bridge. VDOT reopened Carpenters Mill Road the following morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Double Branch Road near Walkers Mill Road was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged heavy rainfall event with slow-moving boundary produced significant small stream and subsequent river flooding in the mountains of southwest VA beginning overnight Sunday, April 19th. Rainfall amounts totaled 1 to 3 inches through 7:00AM EDT Monday, April 20th with isolated amounts up to 4 inches (4.00 measured at Galax, VA Water Plant COOP). Severe weather broke out later in the day on Monday. Heavy rain (2-2  inches) fell in one hour in Wythe County, VA Monday evening causing flash flooding and road washouts. One of the more impressive stream responses occurred on Reed Creek in Wythe County where the gage at Grahams Forge (GRHV2) crested at 9.14 feet (discharge of 11600 cfs) on the afternoon of the 20th (Flood Stage = 7 feet). This was the 2nd highest stage since continuous records began there in the late 1920s and in terms of flood frequency equates to roughly a 33-year event (Annual Exceedance Probability, AEP of 0.03) per the latest USGS Flood Frequency Report. The highest stage recorded at this gage occurred in April 1977 at 10.01 feet during a period of major flooding in southwest Virginia. Local emergency management official said the flooding was historic in that area. Over 50 roads were reported to have been closed in Wythe County by flood waters during the event with substantial road damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mudslide was reported on Flower Gap Road near intersection with William Drive. Other flood reports corroborate localized flash flooding in the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed due to water flowing across them in southeast Grayson County. Mainly along and near Gladys Fork and Chestnut Creek. The USGS gage at Chestnut Creek in Galax (CCKV2) crested at 8.0 feet (Action stage is 6 feet) at 12 midnight (EDT).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused Big Branch Creek to climb out of its banks and flood Big Branch Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fort Valley Road was flooded and closed near Passage Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure was positioned across the Mid-Atlantic. A warm and humid airmass led to slow moving, scattered showers and thunderstorms. Some strong storms led to abundant rainfall that led to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A creek was out of its banks and two to three feet of flowing water was over the intersection of Amicus and Selt Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure was located off the east coast while a warm and moist air mass was in place across the Mid-Atlantic. Showers and thunderstorms developed and moved very slow resulting in heavy rainfall. Flash flooding was reported in Albemarle County, VA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Coles Rolling Road was closed at the 500 block due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moved through the region in the morning hours and showers and thunderstorms formed in a humid air mass. Heavy rain led to flash flooding which led to many areas in the Shenandoah Valley flooded through the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous streets flooded and closed in Woodstock including Main Street and multiple sections on Route 11. There was a car stalled out in water near the intersection of Main Street and Indian Springs Road. There was water in multiple businesses in Woodstock.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of thunderstorms over central Patrick County remained nearly stationary for several hours producing intense rainfall over several small watersheds in the upper Dan River basin. Dual-Pol radar estimated over 4 inches from the storm and Busted Rock #1 IFLOWS gage located near Talbott Reservoir measured a total of 5.57 of which 3.79 fell in a 3-hour period between 600 and 900 PM EDT (22z-01z). This amount/duration represents somewhere between a 10 to 25-year annual recurrence interval (ARI) per NOAA Atlas 14. Several other gages in the area also reported in excess of 3 inches for the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reported 6 to 8 inches of water flowing across Highway 58 where it crosses Big Ivy Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water from Big Cherry Creek flooded a portion of Shotgun Road. The water was estimated to be a least one foot deep.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong moisture advection over the Mid-Atlantic led to dew points into the upper 70s and isolated spots reporting 80. Showers and thunderstorms formed ahead of an advancing cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a road closed due to being washed out. There was a five foot drop off in the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong moisture advection over the Mid-Atlantic led to dew points into the upper 70s and isolated spots reporting 80. Showers and thunderstorms formed ahead of an advancing cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Whiting Road was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Remnants of Tropical Storm Bill moved into the Mid-Atlantic causing moisture to increase. Showers and thunderstorms led to heavy rain across the Interstate 95 corridor and flash flooding occurred. Some rivers also went to flood into June 21, 2015.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 1 was closed due to high water over Neabsco Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall developed across portions of the southern Appalachian mountains as clearing ahead of a slow-moving surface low over the Cumberland Gap allowed instabilities to rise into the 2000 J/Kg range along with good upper divergence. Developing storms and cell mergers produced rainfall rates of 1.5/hr with totals up to 3-4 in isolated storms. A Flash Flood Warning was issued for Tazewell County at 737 PM EDT where radar had showed 1 to 2 inches of rain had fallen with more expected. Total rainfall amounts reached 2.5 to 3 inches in a 3-hour period ending around 02z (10 PM on the 5th) over parts of northeastern Tazewell County which produced substantial flash flooding and debris flows in several locations. The worst flooding occurred along Laurel Fork near the town of Pocahontas where 25 homes, 5 businesses and 2 mobile homes were damaged or destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Laurel Creek flooded about half of the town of Pocahontas. 25 homes, 5 businesses and 2 mobile homes were damaged or destroyed. Total damage estimates reached $3.5 million, primarily due to a single business that was uninsured and destroyed. Multiple roads across northeast Tazewell County were reported to be closed due to flooding and mudslides as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Localized heavy rainfall from afternoon convection produced flash flooding and mud slides near Damascus.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water across roadways and mud slides were reported near Damascus.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms associated with a trough of low pressure produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Officer was stranded in high water at Shore Drive and Pleasure House Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall developed across portions of the southern Appalachian mountains as clearing ahead of a slow-moving surface low over the Cumberland Gap allowed instabilities to rise into the 2000 J/Kg range along with good upper divergence. Developing storms and cell mergers produced rainfall rates of 1.5/hr with totals up to 3-4 in isolated storms. A Flash Flood Warning was issued for Tazewell County at 737 PM EDT where radar had showed 1 to 2 inches of rain had fallen with more expected. Total rainfall amounts reached 2.5 to 3 inches in a 3-hour period ending around 02z (10 PM on the 5th) over parts of northeastern Tazewell County which produced substantial flash flooding and debris flows in several locations. The worst flooding occurred along Laurel Fork near the town of Pocahontas where 25 homes, 5 businesses and 2 mobile homes were damaged or destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple roads and portions of Route 460 between Tazewell and Bluefield were closed due to flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Big Branch Creek flooded its banks, crossing over Big Branch Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very wet pattern developed in the days leading up to and through Christmas beginning around the 21st.  A deep southerly flow between a trough over the western U.S. and powerhouse ridge off the east coast brought extremely high moisture and warmth across much of the eastern U.S. during this period. Precipitable water readings were 2 to 3 times normal late December values for several days and numerous record high temperatures occurred across the entire region. Rainfall was generally light to moderate on the 21st and 22nd with 0.25 up to around 1.00 each day. Heavier rains developed on the 23rd as low pressure tracked out of the Gulf coast toward the southern Appalachians. Rainfall of 1 to 2.5 ending at 12z (7 AM EST) on the 24th prompted the first of several river Flood warnings along the lower Dan and Roanoke river basins.  Heavy rains continued into the 24th with several bands of more intense rainfall across mountains and then across the Piedmont. A swath of 1 to 2+ inches of rain fell across portions of Pittsylvania, Halifax and Charlotte counties in a 6-hour period ending at 18z (1 PM EST) on the 24th producing flash flooding. Numerous roads were reported closed by VA Department of Transportation by mid-afternoon on the 24th across all three of these counties. River flooding developed along the Dan and lower Roanoke rivers as a result of the runoff with several gauges reaching moderate flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least six or seven roads were closed across Halifax County from Paces up through Nathalie.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding along Georges Creek took out a private bridge, cutting off access to a mobile home park near Gretna. In addition, as many as 26 roads across the county were closed due to flooding during the day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the most high-impact flood/flash flooding episodes in recent years in the Blacksburg Hydrologic Service Area (HSA) developed over a several day period but culminated September 29th. An unusual weather pattern became established around September 25th with very slow-moving and strong high pressure building across New England and low pressure over the southeastern U.S. combining to bring strong easterly flow into the southern Mid-Atlantic along with abundant moisture. Rainfall ending 12z on the 25th was generally confined to the southern portions of the HSA with up to 1 inch in parts of the North Carolina piedmont into southside Virginia. The rains became much heavier and widespread over the next two days with 1 to 4 inches ending at 12z on the 26th and another 1 to nearly 5 inches ending at 12z on the 27th. Over the next five days rainfall was nearly constant in some areas with pulses of heavier rainfall but with the heaviest amounts concentrating across the VA Blue Ridge mountains, mainly in Patrick, Floyd, Roanoke, Henry and Franklin counties. The maximum 5-day rainfall totals ending at 12Z (8 AM) on the 30th ranged from 10 to 16 inches in parts of Patrick and Floyd counties. Some of the higher totals equate to anywhere from a 100 to 500-year event per NOAA Atlas 14. The extremely wet soils set the stage for the severe flash flooding early on September 29th into the afternoon. Several bands of intense rainfall tracked across parts of the same counties mentioned above and also including Montgomery County over a 6 to 12 hour period from 0200 LST to 1400 lST (06z-18z) prompting the issuance of two Flash Flood Warnings for parts of eight counties and several cities at 943 AM (EDT) and 1019 (EDT) AM.  It was difficult to differentiate between the onset of flash flooding from the longer duration flooding that was developing or underway as well. No matter the type, by mid-morning numerous reports of flooding and several high water rescues had been reported across a wide area, but most notably in parts of Patrick, Floyd, Montgomery, Roanoke and Henry counties.  Local states of emergency were declared in Floyd and Patrick counties due to the widespread flood impacts with water rescues, some homes damaged and dozens of roads closed due to flooding or trees brought down in the saturated soil.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported across Route 11 in Radford. The automated rain gage at the Radford River gage (RDFV2) measured 2.42 in one hour ending 0600 LST, which is very close to the 100-year recurrence interval (0.01 annual exceedance probability) for this location and duration.

The maximum 5-day rainfall totals ending at 12Z (8 AM) on the 30th ranged from 10 to 16 inches in parts of Patrick and Floyd counties. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding occurred across the county but was concentrated in Route 8 corridor. Several  swift water rescues were made and numerous roads were closed and many damaged. A van was swept off of Meadows Creek Road and the driver, a college student, was rescued. In addition, 13 homes were destroyed, 12 homes received major damage, 15 homes minor damage, and 42 other homes affected, for a total loss of $2.3 million dollars. The worst flooding appeared to be in the Sowers Mill Dam Road and Little River Road areas. According to county officials additional commercial and agricultural losses ran about $400,000. Road damage totaled an additional $400,000 per the Virginia Department of Transportation. Local officials described it as one of the worst weather disasters in county history. The Little River which runs through much of Floyd County was responsible for much of the damage. Residents in the Sowers Mill Dam Road area said the river rose 20 to 25 feet during the flood. The river gage on the Little River further downstream at Graysontown along the Pulaski-Montgomery county line reached a stage of 12.68 feet (flood stage = 8 ft), the 3rd highest at the current datum and highest since Hurricane Agnes in 1972.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported along Morningside Drive west of Sanville. Blackberry Creek IFLOWS gage (BBBV2) rose from around 2 feet at 5AM to crest at 8.2 feet (Minor Flood Stage = 6 ft) by early early afternoon. Some crawl spaces were flooded along Blackberry Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 1 to 2 inches by 8 AM (EST) across western Franklin County continued through early afternoon with an additional 1.5 to 3 inches in the far western sections. At least 8 roads mainly in the western sections of the county were reported to be closed by afternoon. These included Runnet Bag Road, Coles Creek Road, Madcap Road, Ruritan Road, Wades Gap Road, Boones Mill Road, Five Mile Mountain Road, Dillons Mill/Western Comer Road. The IFLOWS stream gage on Maggodee Creek (MGDV2) reached Action Stage of 5 feet by 1215 PM (EST) and crested at 1245 PM at 6.2 feet, just below Flood Stage of 7 feet.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding and flash flooding was widespread across Patrick County. Numerous creeks and rivers were reported out of banks with dozens of road closures across the county for much of the day. An apartment complex was evacuated due to a mudslide and multiple swift water rescues were carried out. Polebridge Creek west of Sanville was reported out of its banks and Big Ivy Creek flooded a portion of Route 58 southeast of Meadows of Dan. The Smith River gage at Woolwine (SMWV2) reached its highest crest on record (data only back to 1995) at 16.11 feet (6300 cfs) at 500 AM (EST) on the 29th (old record 12.20 ft. on 9/28/2004). This is a revised value based on a post-flood analysis by VA Department of Environmental Quality. The historic (1921) Bob White covered bridge over the Smith River near Woolwine was washed away as the river rose. Total damages in Patrick County were estimated at $4 million about half from road and infrastructure damage and half from agricultural losses.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall was generally 1 to 2 inches across the City of Salem during the day. Several roads were reported closed in the City of Salem. A voluntary evacuation was made from Ramey Mobile Home Park along Mason Creek which crested at 7.5 ft (Flood Stage = 7 ft) at the upstream gage (MSCV2) in Roanoke County at 1400 LST.  Other road closures that continued into the evening included the low water bridge over the Roanoke River at Mill Lane, Texas Street at Carter Way,  East Riverside at Front Avenue, Eddy Street, Colorado Street, Apperson Drive, Mill Lane at Mountain Avenue, West Salem Mobile Home Park and West Riverside Mobile Home Village.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of roads flooded and some badly damaged across Montgomery County. The biggest impacts were in the western half of the county where 3 to 5 inches of rain fell in a 6-hour period between 0700 LST and 1300 LST. The asphalt on Laurel Mill Ridge road was reportedly washed away. Meadow Creek Road had at least one foot of water rushing over it. Duck Pond Road was closed from Oak Lane to Smithfield. Radford Road was closed, Route 8 in Riner was partially flooded and an earth retaining wall gave way. Toms Creek was flooding a portion of Mt. Zion Road near Brooksfield Road. Plantation was closed due to 6 to 12 inches of water over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain event as low pressure moved through the Mid-Atlantic ahead of a slow moving cold front. Southerly flow ahead of the low pressure tapped into a moisture rich atmosphere over the Gulf of Mexico. While thunderstorms were isolated due to weaker shear and instability, the heaviest of the precipitation was able to bring down gusty winds from aloft. This also led to flooding across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream gauge on Limestone Branch near Leesburg reached a flood stage of 7 feet. It peaked at 9.13 feet at 22:30 EST. Greenfield Farm Lane and another access road began to flood and field flooding near the stream became widespread. A home near route 15 along the stream began to flood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved across the Mid-Atlantic. Showers formed in a very moist atmosphere across the region. Heavy rainfall produced flooding across the Interstate 95 corridor in the afternoon and heavy rain across Central Virginia in the evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several vehicles were stranded in high water under a railroad overpass on Old Ivy Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Old Ivy and Route 846 were flooded at railroad underpass.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of flooding were reported on James Madison University in the City of Harrisonburg which include Edith J. Carrier Arboretum, Godwin Transit Center, Duke Dog Alley, Bluestone and Main Streets and Bridgeforth Stadium.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple road closures occurred in Leesburg including westbound and eastbound of route 15 bypass and portions of route 7 eastbound at route 9.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The entrance to the physical plant offices for the Virginia School for the Deaf and the Blind, on New Hope Road, were closed due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Kirby Avenue and A Street were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure moved from the deep south to the Great Lakes. Strong warm air advection coupled with moisture led to showers and thunderstorms across the area. Activity strengthened in the afternoon and multiple rounds of heavy rain moved across the area. Many rivers reached flood stage across the Mid-Atlantic.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Salem Church Road was flooded and closed near Jackson Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure moved from the deep south to the Great Lakes. Strong warm air advection coupled with moisture led to showers and thunderstorms across the area. Activity strengthened in the afternoon and multiple rounds of heavy rain moved across the area. Many rivers reached flood stage across the Mid-Atlantic.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream gauge at Cameron Run exceeded the flood stage at Huntington at 19:01 EST. This caused flooding of Fenwick Drive with over a foot of flowing water at the end of the road. The stream fell below flood stage around 20:30 EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms developed across parts of Halifax and Charlotte counties during the very early morning hours of June 6th within an area of higher residual instability and deeper moisture. Radar estimates showed 1 to 3.5 inches fell over several hours in a narrow swath across southeast Halifax into far southern Charlotte County. The highest rain gage report from the area (valid 12z, Jun 6) was at South Boston COOP (SOBV2) with 1.78.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported along portions of Route 58 west of South Boston including up to two feet of water covering the intersection of Sandy Beach (Route 703) and Philpott Road (Route 58).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of low pressure moving along a stalled frontal boundary over the Mid Atlantic region produced periodic showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain that caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads had high water throughout the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of low pressure moving along a stalled frontal boundary over the Mid Atlantic region produced periodic showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain that caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads throughout the city of Petersburg had several feet of water on them.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Summer convection produced flash flooding in Wise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water briefly went over a roadway and entered a home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Summer convection produced flash flooding in Wise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water covered Railroad Avenue and entered a home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Summer convection produced flash flooding in Wise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water covered Stephens Road and entered a home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and humid day led to showers and thunderstorms developing along the higher terrain west of the Blue Ridge Mountains. Thunderstorms that developed were slow moving and that led to heavy rain over far northern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A creek came out of its banks and spread over Wren Lane. About 18 inches of water was observed on Wren Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary lingered over the region with a cold front slowly approaching the region. An unstable air mass over northern Virginia allowed for scattered showers and thunderstorms to form. Some thunderstorms produced very heavy rainfall that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The river gauge at Muddy Creek in Mount Clinton, VA reached flood stage and peaked at 9/84 feet at 16:15 EST. A barn and surrounding fields began to flood near Mount Clinton. Flooding was also reported on Custers Road and Muddy Creek Road where significant flood depth was noted on the Muddy Creek Road side. Both roads were impassible.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved into the Mid-Atlantic region and showers and thunderstorms formed on the warm, unstable side of the boundary. Some thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were 10 inches of water flowing over Woodburn Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved into the Mid-Atlantic region and showers and thunderstorms formed on the warm, unstable side of the boundary. Some thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was two feet of water flowing over a bridge on Hunter Mill Road near Hunter Station Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front remained draped across the region, placing most of the area in a moist and unstable air mass. A shortwave moving through combined with this air mass to trigger showers and thunderstorms. Heavy rain produced flooding in Rockingham County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were roads flooded along route 11 in Tenth Legion.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain and caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State Route 30 in front of Kings Dominion was inundated with at least 6 inches of flowing water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approached the region while Tropical Storm Bonnie was off the Outer Banks of North Carolina. Full sunshine and easterly flow across the area led to instability and showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall that led to flooding across Central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A road was closed near the intersection of Freshwater Cove Lane and Poplar Flatts Road due to flooding. About one foot of flowing water was observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approached the region while Tropical Storm Bonnie was off the Outer Banks of North Carolina. Full sunshine and easterly flow across the area led to instability and showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall that led to flooding across Central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Old Roseland Road was closed near Roseland Road due to flooding. Water was several feet deep.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary lingered over the region with a cold front slowly approaching the region. An unstable air mass over northern Virginia allowed for scattered showers and thunderstorms to form. Some thunderstorms produced very heavy rainfall that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 11 North/6100 block of Valley Pike was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary lingered over the region with a cold front slowly approaching the region. An unstable air mass over northern Virginia allowed for scattered showers and thunderstorms to form. Some thunderstorms produced very heavy rainfall that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flooding Heritage Park and up to a footbridge on Linville Creek in Broadway, VA. The nearby stream gauge on Linville Creek peaked just below 7 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary lingered over the region with a cold front slowly approaching the region. An unstable air mass over northern Virginia allowed for scattered showers and thunderstorms to form. Some thunderstorms produced very heavy rainfall that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was three feet of water flowing over Carters Bridge on Scottsville Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary lingered over the region with a cold front slowly approaching the region. An unstable air mass over northern Virginia allowed for scattered showers and thunderstorms to form. Some thunderstorms produced very heavy rainfall that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were two water rescues on Freshwater Cove Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary lingered over the region with a cold front slowly approaching the region. An unstable air mass over northern Virginia allowed for scattered showers and thunderstorms to form. Some thunderstorms produced very heavy rainfall that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many roads including Alberine Road, Presidents Road, Rolling Road, Esmont Road, Secretarys Road, Plank Road and Glendower Road closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The synoptic setup for this event featured an upper level ridge over the central U.S. with several strong short-waves topping the ridge and dropping southeast across the Ohio Valley toward the central Appalachians. Satellite imagery showed a deep tap of tropical moisture into West Virginia and a strengthening upper level jet providing additional lift. A warm front was located just north of the area and became a focus for convection in the early morning hours of the 23rd. During the late morning to early afternoon convection continued to train across the same general area of southeast WV and far western VA with hourly rainfall rates of 1.50 to 2 for several hours.||Radar and rain gauge measurements showed as much as 4 to 8 inches (perhaps higher locally) fell in a band across central Alleghany County. The bulk of the rain fell in less than 12 hours between 600 AM and 600 PM EDT. The Governor of Virginia declared a state of emergency in the City of Covington and Alleghany County.||The phenomenal runoff from creeks, streams and overland flow produced an extreme hydrologic response on larger rivers including the Jackson River. The river gage at Covington (CVGV2) rose over 10 feet in 5 hours to reach Flood Stage (17 feet) for the first time since September 2004 (during the remains of Hurricane Jeanne).  A River Flood Warning (FLW) was issued at 609 PM as the river was near 15 feet and the crest was only 4.5 hours later at 22.33 feet just below the Major Flood Stage of 23 feet. This was highest stage reached at the Covington gage since the November 1985 flood (23.31 feet) and 2nd highest since the construction of Gathright Dam in 1979. Gathright Dam was built to reduce flooding on the Jackson River but so much rain fell in the watershed below the dam that flooding still occurred at Covington. Numerous homes and several businesses in Covington suffered severe flood damage from the Jackson River.  At the same time Dunlap Creek (DLPV2), which drains 162 mi2 of western Alleghany County and empties into the Jackson River in Covington was also rising at an extreme rate, climbing from a stage of around 3 feet (445 cfs) at 200 PM to a record stage of 16.49 feet (30,300 cfs) in a little over 6 hours.  The previous record at this gage was 15.65 feet (27,400 cfs) set in June 1972 with the remains of Hurricane Agnes. Hydrological peak stage records at this gage date back to 1929. According to USGS flood frequency reports this flood was likely in excess of a 200-year (0.005 AEP) event on Dunlap Creek. There was extensive flooding along Dunlap Creek with roads and homes flooded and some requiring evacuations. Flooding continued downstream and a few hours later a River Flood Warning was issued for the upper James River including the forecast points at Lick Run (LIRV2) and Buchanan (BNNV2) both of which easily reached flood stage. At Lick Run the crest of 22.84 feet was the 10th highest on record (continuous records since 1925) and the highest since January 1996 (25.03 feet).  Per USGS data the 48,000 cfs discharge at Lick Run was roughly a 10-year (.10 AEP) flood event. At Buchanan the 42,900 cfs was merely somewhere between a 2- to 5-year event (0.5 to 0.2 AEP).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding due the heavy rainfall was reported along a portion of Timberlake Road near Forest. The nearby Lynchburg Airport ASOS (LYH) climate site reported 3.54 inches for June 23rd which was a new record for the date. The old record was 1.73 inches set in 1967. It was also the 2nd wettest June day on record at Lynchburg with data back to 1893.
