EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approached the region while Tropical Storm Bonnie was off the Outer Banks of North Carolina. Full sunshine and easterly flow across the area led to instability and showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall that led to flooding across Central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roseland Road and Virginia 56 were impassable due to flowing water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front brought thunderstorms with widespread showers and pockets of heavy rainfall from mid to late morning on the 27th and continuing into the early evening. Rainfall under the most intense storms was estimated by radar at 1 to 2.5 inches with locally higher amounts up to 3 inches, most of which fell in under 3 hours. An NWS COOP gage near Glasgow measured 3.55 inches for the 24-hours ending at 12z (800 EDT) on the 28th most of which fell in several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several landslides and reports of flooding around Clifton Forge. A tree and mud slid down a hillside onto Oak Street in Clifton Forge and four to five trees along with mud and rocks slid down onto Verge Road also in Clifton Forge. Wilson Creek flooded portion of Route 629 (Douthat State Park Road) and Dry Run Creek flooded parts of Route 60 in Cliftondale Park.

Rainfall under the most intense storms was estimated by radar at 1 to 2.5 inches with locally higher amounts up to 3 inches, most of which fell in under 3 hours. An NWS COOP gage near Glasgow measured 3.55 inches for the 24-hours ending at 12z (800 EDT) on the 28th most of which fell in several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A portion of Bears Trail road near the Bland County School Board office was washed out by flowing water from Hunting Camp Creek. A nearby unofficial rain gauge near Bland reported 3.12 inches of rain on the 27th with nearly 2.25 inches falling from 5:30 PM EDT to 7:00 PM EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary lingered over the region with a cold front slowly approaching the region. An unstable air mass over northern Virginia allowed for scattered showers and thunderstorms to form. Some thunderstorms produced very heavy rainfall that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The river gauge at Tye River at Lovingston, Va reached flood stage and peaked at 13.63 feet at 00:00 EST. Roseland Road began to flood as well as nearby agricultural fields near the river.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough slowly moved into the Potomac Highlands and Shenandoah Valley and stalled. Surface convergence led to showers and thunderstorms to develop and not move across the region. This led to heavy rain and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Baynes Road was flooded and closed at Cattle Scales Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough slowly moved into the Potomac Highlands and Shenandoah Valley and stalled. Surface convergence led to showers and thunderstorms to develop and not move across the region. This led to heavy rain and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was water flowing across the roadway at the intersection of Hermitage Road and Long Meadow Road. The depth was estimated to be 6 to 8 inches and cars were not able to drive through.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough slowly moved into the Potomac Highlands and Shenandoah Valley and stalled. Surface convergence led to showers and thunderstorms to develop and not move across the region. This led to heavy rain and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was flowing water over the main road to Wintergreen Resort. The water depth was estimated to be six inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough slowly moved into the Potomac Highlands and Shenandoah Valley and stalled. Surface convergence led to showers and thunderstorms to develop and not move across the region. This led to heavy rain and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a car stranded in four feet of standing water in the 2300 block of Long Meadow Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 1700 Block of Dam Town Road was blocked by high water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mine Road was closed at Cameron Street due to high water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One foot of water was observed flowing over Route 681 from a tributary of Oldfield Creek near the intersection with Route 221.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported flowing across Old Virginia Avenue in Rich Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure formed over the southern Plains on the 2nd of February and tracked into the Great Lakes pulling a cold front across the region by early on the 4th. This system brought heavy rain, which first pushed into the northwest NC mountains during the early morning hours of the 3rd. The rain advanced northeast into Virginia through the mid-morning hours. In Patrick County, the rainfall was particularly intense for several hours with rates 0.5 to 1.0 per hour.  A report was received of a car washed into Jill Creek near Woolwine by flood waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car was washed into Jill Creek along Route northwest of Woolwine.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated slow-moving thunderstorm (which also produced some large hail) dropped radar estimated rainfall of 2 to 2.5 inches in a few hours which caused some roads to flood in the Scottsburg area of Halifax County. A TV media website said one of their spotters measured over 3 inches in one hour from the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast media website showed portions of MacDonald and Green Level roads under what appeared to be at least 6 inches of moving water.

An NWS COOP gage near Glasgow measured 3.55 inches for the 24-hours ending at 12z (800 EDT) on the 28th most of which fell in several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dunlap Creek was reported out of its banks and flowing over Highway 159 with at least six inches of water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Urban flooding was first reported from the City of Covington around 145 PM EDT (1245 EST) as two flood-prone underpasses were flooded. More serious flooding began around 230 PM EDT (130 PM EST) with numerous roads closed and eventually homes flooded. There was one boat rescue in Covington of a family trapped in a home with rising water. The rapidly rising Jackson River caused much of the flood damage in the city with up to 60 homes seriously damaged. A concrete plant lost $1.2 million in equipment and VDOT estimated $50 thousand in road damages within the city. There were also at least three landslides reported in the city.

Satellite imagery showed a deep tap of tropical moisture into West Virginia and a strengthening upper level jet providing additional lift. A warm front was located just north of the area and became a focus for convection in the early morning hours of the 23rd. During the late morning to early afternoon convection continued to train across the same general area of southeast WV and far western VA with hourly rainfall rates of 1.50 to 2 for several hours.||Radar and rain gauge measurements showed as much as 4 to 8 inches (perhaps higher locally) fell in a band across central Alleghany County. The bulk of the rain fell in less than 12 hours between 600 AM and 600 PM EDT. The Governor of Virginia declared a state of emergency in the City of Covington and Alleghany County.||The phenomenal runoff from creeks, streams and overland flow produced an extreme hydrologic response on larger rivers including the Jackson River. The river gage at Covington (CVGV2) rose over 10 feet in 5 hours to reach Flood Stage (17 feet) for the first time since September 2004 (during the remains of Hurricane Jeanne).  A River Flood Warning (FLW) was issued at 609 PM as the river was near 15 feet and the crest was only 4.5 hours later at 22.33 feet just below the Major Flood Stage of 23 feet. This was highest stage reached at the Covington gage since the November 1985 flood (23.31 feet) and 2nd highest since the construction of Gathright Dam in 1979. Gathright Dam was built to reduce flooding on the Jackson River but so much rain fell in the watershed below the dam that flooding still occurred at Covington. Numerous homes and several businesses in Covington suffered severe flood damage from the Jackson River.  At the same time Dunlap Creek (DLPV2), which drains 162 mi2 of western Alleghany County and empties into the Jackson River in Covington was also rising at an extreme rate, climbing from a stage of around 3 feet (445 cfs) at 200 PM to a record stage of 16.49 feet (30,300 cfs) in a little over 6 hours.  The previous record at this gage was 15.65 feet (27,400 cfs) set in June 1972 with the remains of Hurricane Agnes. Hydrological peak stage records at this gage date back to 1929. According to USGS flood frequency reports this flood was likely in excess of a 200-year (0.005 AEP) event on Dunlap Creek. There was extensive flooding along Dunlap Creek with roads and homes flooded and some requiring evacuations. Flooding continued downstream and a few hours later a River Flood Warning was issued for the upper James River including the forecast points at Lick Run (LIRV2) and Buchanan (BNNV2) both of which easily reached flood stage. At Lick Run the crest of 22.84 feet was the 10th highest on record (continuous records since 1925) and the highest since January 1996 (25.03 feet).  Per USGS data the 48,000 cfs discharge at Lick Run was roughly a 10-year (.10 AEP) flood event. At Buchanan the 42,900 cfs was merely somewhere between a 2- to 5-year event (0.5 to 0.2 AEP).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was first reported in Alleghany County at 215 PM EDT (115 PM EST) as Indian Draft Road (Route 600) was closed. Numerous additional reports and social media reports continued to be received through the afternoon. Numerous small streams flooded including Wilson Creek which overflowed Route 629 (Douthat Park Road). The most serious flooding was along Dunlap Creek with runs through the southwestern portions of the county joining the Jackson River just north of Covington. More than 25 homes were badly damaged in the county most of them along Dunlap Creek which set a new flood of record (see Episode for details). Water was reported over Route 60 from Dunlap Creek in several areas. Two water rescues by boat were performed and several landslides were reported including one that was reported to have closed Pitzer Ridge Road (Route 657) east of Route 18. Three Botetourt County firefighters were injured during flood rescue operations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front brought thunderstorms with widespread showers and pockets of heavy rainfall from mid to late morning on the 27th and continuing into the early evening. Rainfall under the most intense storms was estimated by radar at 1 to 2.5 inches with locally higher amounts up to 3 inches, most of which fell in under 3 hours. An NWS COOP gage near Glasgow measured 3.55 inches for the 24-hours ending at 12z (800 EDT) on the 28th most of which fell in several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tributary of the Maury River flooded part of Route 501 close the intersection with Route 130. Up to two feet of water was seen flowing over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving summertime afternoon thunderstorms produced two inches or more of rainfall, resulting in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roadways flooded, and water entered a few businesses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms produced rainfall of 1.5 to 3 inches with isolated higher amounts in a few hours across parts of Franklin, Roanoke and Craig counties leading to flash flooding in the Bent Creek watershed and some minor runoff problems elsewhere. A mesonet station near Poages Mill in Roanoke County measured 5.88 inches and a CoCoRaHS station off Cotton Mill Rd. had 4.82 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along upper reaches of Back Creek with the water 3 to 4 feet out of its banks near the Country Way General store. Flash flooding was also observed along Martins Creek with damage to several driveways. In addition, a mudslide and rockslide was reported on Bent Mountain Road near Mount Chesnut Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary remained overhead on the 30th of July. Hot and humid conditions led to an unstable atmosphere. The instability along with the boundary caused a few severe thunderstorms to develop. Thunderstorms merged across Montgomery, Howard and Baltimore counties and led very heavy rainfall that led to flash flooding. Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in Ellicott City, MD the night of July 30th. Thunderstorms also formed across the Central Foothills in Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a mudslide on US 522 one mile south of Woodville. The southbound lane was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain and caused flash flooding across portions of eastern and southeast Virginia. Rainfall totals ranged from five to as much as eleven inches in areas where flash flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law Enforcement reported multiple road closures due to standing water, including the intersection of Parksley Road and Route 13. Vehicles were trapped in high water. An Assisted Living Home was inundated with water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain and caused flash flooding across portions of eastern and southeast Virginia. Rainfall totals ranged from five to as much as eleven inches in areas where flash flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple streets and yards were under water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary remained overhead on the 30th of July. Hot and humid conditions led to an unstable atmosphere. The instability along with the boundary caused a few severe thunderstorms to develop. Thunderstorms merged across Montgomery, Howard and Baltimore counties and led very heavy rainfall that led to flash flooding. Catastrophic flash flooding occurred in Ellicott City, MD the night of July 30th. Thunderstorms also formed across the Central Foothills in Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Turkey Ridge Road was flooded and closed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bel Pre Road was closed from Jubilee Road to Brandy Road due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southerly flow ushered in hot and humid conditions around high pressure centered in the Atlantic. High amounts of instability led to some thunderstorms, and some were severe with strong winds. Thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall capable of flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: North River Road was closed at Grindstone Road due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain and caused flash flooding across portions of eastern and southeast Virginia. Rainfall totals ranged from five to as much as eleven inches in areas where flash flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were widespread reports of high water and road closures from Onley to Accomac.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a cold front moving through the Mid Atlantic and Post Tropical Cyclone Matthew tracking northeast just off the North Carolina and Virginia coasts, produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across southeast Virginia from Saturday evening, October 8th into early Sunday morning, October 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were impassable or closed, and some small creeks or streams were out of their banks due to heavy rain causing flash flooding across the western and central portion of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a cold front moving through the Mid Atlantic and Post Tropical Cyclone Matthew tracking northeast just off the North Carolina and Virginia coasts, produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across southeast Virginia from Saturday evening, October 8th into early Sunday morning, October 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were impassable or closed, and some small creeks or streams were out of their banks due to heavy rain causing flash flooding across much of the city.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were impassable or closed, and some small creeks or streams were out of their banks due to heavy rain causing flash flooding across much of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain and caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was covering Olney Road. Vehicles were stuck in water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain and caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets were flooded in Old Town Portsmouth with vehicles trapped.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The afternoon and evening of the 27th was very active as diurnal heating, very moist air (PWATS 1.8-2.0 inches) and convergence along several boundaries combined to produce numerous severe thunderstorms and pockets of heavy rainfall. Several rounds of storms rolled across far northern Rockbridge County in the area between Brownsburg and Fairfield dropping radar estimated totals of 2 to 4 inches in several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The area in Brownsburg had several roads closed, and in Fairfield there was about 4 inches of rain and water was over route 11 north at the Augusta Co-op and also on Sterrett Road. The Fairfield Rescue Squad building flooded due to the runoff from businesses above it. The squad had approximately 2 inches of water throughout the building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia. Rainfall totals ranged between 2 and 7 inches across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 2800 Block of Shore Drive was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia. Rainfall totals ranged between 2 and 7 inches across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed due to high water near Fairfield Shopping Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia. Rainfall totals ranged between 2 and 7 inches across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were flooded or closed at CNIC-Little Creek/Fort Story Joint Base.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia. Rainfall totals ranged between 2 and 7 inches across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous streets were closed or impassible due to flooding. Street lights were inoperable in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low was over Kentucky for an extended period of time and southerly flow  led to persistent moisture advection across the Mid-Atlantic region. Showers and thunderstorms moved from south to north and led to multiple rounds of heavy rain. Flooding occurred across the Mid-Atlantic region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Valley Mill Road was closed due to flooding. Law enforcement was on site directing traffic away from roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low was over Kentucky for an extended period of time and southerly flow  led to persistent moisture advection across the Mid-Atlantic region. Showers and thunderstorms moved from south to north and led to multiple rounds of heavy rain. Flooding occurred across the Mid-Atlantic region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 50 westbound was closed near Swift Shoals road due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding was reported in portions of Henrico county around Lakeside and the surrounding area. Also, portions of Interstate 95 were flooded at Wilmer Road and Staples Mill Road. Water up to 3 feet deep was reported at Martin Street and Edgemore Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of and along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain and flash flooding across portions of central and eastern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Route 202 were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of low pressure and a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Knee high water was reported at Sparrow Intermediate School.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across the Mid-Atlantic region and southerly flow transported moisture into the region. Breaks in sunshine led to increased instability and showers and thunderstorms formed and produced very heavy rain that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bethel Church Road was closed near River Road due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across the Mid-Atlantic region and southerly flow transported moisture into the region. Breaks in sunshine led to increased instability and showers and thunderstorms formed and produced very heavy rain that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: South Court Street was flooded and closed due to heavy rain. A couple inches of water was entering one structure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across the Mid-Atlantic region and southerly flow transported moisture into the region. Breaks in sunshine led to increased instability and showers and thunderstorms formed and produced very heavy rain that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Main Street was closed near College Street due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across the Mid-Atlantic region and southerly flow transported moisture into the region. Breaks in sunshine led to increased instability and showers and thunderstorms formed and produced very heavy rain that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was flooding along Route 11 near the 3500 Block near the Economy Inn Hotel. Lanes were closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across the Mid-Atlantic region and southerly flow transported moisture into the region. Breaks in sunshine led to increased instability and showers and thunderstorms formed and produced very heavy rain that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: North Liberty Street was flooded near a small stream out of its banks north of Harrisonburg. Jefferson Street near Madison Street was also closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across the Mid-Atlantic region and southerly flow transported moisture into the region. Breaks in sunshine led to increased instability and showers and thunderstorms formed and produced very heavy rain that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 2000 Block of Silver Lake Road was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across the Mid-Atlantic region and southerly flow transported moisture into the region. Breaks in sunshine led to increased instability and showers and thunderstorms formed and produced very heavy rain that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Massanutten Drive was flooded and closed near Strony Run in the 3000 Block.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across the Mid-Atlantic region and southerly flow transported moisture into the region. Breaks in sunshine led to increased instability and showers and thunderstorms formed and produced very heavy rain that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were six to eight inches of water estimated flowing down the 1700 Block Englewood Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed along a warm front on the 24th. The showers and storms produced very heavy rainfall with one to two inches of rain in a short time. This rain fell on already saturated soils resulting in flash flooding. One storm briefly pulsed up and produced hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in and around Clintwood were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a persistent surface high pressure area centered off the Atlantic coast circulating warm and very moist air into the region, showers once again blossomed during the late afternoon of June 15th and into the early morning hours of the 16th, partially in response to an approaching upper trough. Radar estimated rainfall amounts ranged from 2 to 4 inches across parts of Grayson, Henry, Pittsylvania, Amherst and Halifax counties most of which fell in about a 1 to 3 hour period under the most intense thunderstorm cores.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported flowing across Riverside Road (Route 274), partially washing it out. Large rocks were left blocking the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a persistent surface high pressure area centered off the Atlantic coast circulating warm and very moist air into the region, showers once again blossomed during the late afternoon of June 15th and into the early morning hours of the 16th, partially in response to an approaching upper trough. Radar estimated rainfall amounts ranged from 2 to 4 inches across parts of Grayson, Henry, Pittsylvania, Amherst and Halifax counties most of which fell in about a 1 to 3 hour period under the most intense thunderstorm cores.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Urban flash flooding was observed in parts of the Roanoke metro area with numerous flooded roadways throughout the city and reports of people trapped in flooded cars.  Numerous stranded and abandoned vehicles were located along Salem Avenue in Roanoke with water up to car mirrors in some locations. A swift water team performed a rescue from a car at the corner of Loudon Ave. and 19th Street in Roanoke. Flash flooding was also reported via Twitter at the Shaffers crossing underpass, a very flood prone area. The Roanoke Airport ASOS (ROA) measured 1.58 from the storm and Roanoke 8N COOP (ROAV2) 1.62. Despite the impacts, for a 1-hour period the rainfall was only about a 5-year annual recurrence interval (0.20 Annual Exceedance Probability).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a persistent surface high pressure area centered off the Atlantic coast circulating warm and very moist air into the region, showers once again blossomed during the late afternoon of June 15th and into the early morning hours of the 16th, partially in response to an approaching upper trough. Radar estimated rainfall amounts ranged from 2 to 4 inches across parts of Grayson, Henry, Pittsylvania, Amherst and Halifax counties most of which fell in about a 1 to 3 hour period under the most intense thunderstorm cores.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in Henry County were closed due to high water including Pulaski Road and Phospho Springs Road. The flooding was possibly from Reds Creek overflow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Evening convection redeveloped on the 16th with the Blue Ridge foothills and southside VA counties (Henry, Pittsylvania, Franklin  and Halifax) once again receiving the bulk of the rainfall.  Rainfall was estimated by radar at 1 to 2.5 inches in a few hours. Several reports were received of flooding issues in the Bassett area north of Martinsville. Lesser amounts produced minor flooding in Tazewell County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was submerged in water and one lane closed of the Route 220 bypass at the Stanleytown Elementary School as a result of flooding from Little Reed Creek. Water also rose to the level of basement window on a two-story home on Fairystone Parkway.  Blackberry Creek was reported to be flooding along Blackberry Road, although the gauge on the creek was out of service. A large section of Route 58 was badly damaged as a hole six feet deep and 12 feet wide opened along the westbound lanes due to the heavy rain and runoff. A small stream runs under the highway at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across the Mid-Atlantic region and southerly flow transported moisture into the region. Breaks in sunshine led to increased instability and showers and thunderstorms formed and produced very heavy rain that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mcgaheysville Road was closed near Stony Run due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved northward across the Mid-Atlantic region and southerly flow transported moisture into the region. Breaks in sunshine led to increased instability and showers and thunderstorms formed and produced very heavy rain that led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were multiple road closures due to high water near Richmond Avenue and Greenville Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of low pressure moved across the area as an upper level low closed off over the southeastern U.S. Signiifcant rainfall began early on April 22nd over far southwest Virginia and the rainfall persisted on and off over the next four days with mainly moderate rates (0.10 to 0.25 per hour) as the upper low drifted very slowly eastward from the lower Mississippi Valley toward the southeastern states. 24-hour totals ending 12z (0700 EST) on the 23rd ranged from less than 0.50 inches over the James River basin up to 1.25 to 1.75 across parts of the Roanoke, New and Dan basins.  The heaviest rains April 23-24 fell across the western and central river basins with amounts  ranging from 2 to 5 inches. Another 1 to 3 inches with isolated higher amounts fell mainly across the foothills and piedmont in the next 24-hours. Storm total rainfall for the four-day period ending at 12z (0700 EST) on the 25th ranged from 3 to 9+ inches with highest amounts in parts of the Blue Ridge mountains and foothills in Patrick, Carroll and Henry counties. Busted Rock #2 IFLOWS (BUEV2) led the way with 9.53 over the 4-day period. Widespread small stream flooding resulted with numerous larger rivers that approached or exceeded flood stage including portions of the Clinch, New, Roanoke and Dan rivers. Return frequency intervals for the flooding were generally in the 5-year to 10-year range (0.20-0.10 annual exceedance probability), but close to 20-year (0.05 AEP) in the lower Dan River. Numerous roads were closed by flooding in at least a dozen counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the midst of ongoing longer-term flooding several additional roads were closed in the Chilhowie to Marion corridor after higher rainfall rates, up to 0.75 to 1.25 inches per hour moved across the area. Roads closed included Carlock Road north of Chilhowie, Fox Valley Road, Porter Valley Road, Old Lake Road and Scratch Gravel Road. This additional rainfall aggravated the ongoing flooding from several days of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms across eastern Smyth and western Wythe counties dropped radar estimated amounts of 2 to 3 inches in several hours over a small area. Flash flooding was reported at the Rural Retreat Fairgrounds in western Wythe county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report forwarded by the broadcast media described flash flooding inundating portions of the Rural Retreat fairgrounds. Water overflowed a culvert to flood some trailers and tents. An estimated 2 of rain fell in about 30 minutes, with up to 3 inches total.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread convective event developed across the entire region ahead of an outflow boundary that shifted southeast out of the Ohio Valley. An unstable air mass and more than sufficient wind shear helped the storms strengthen generating damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roadways experiencing high water across the northern portion of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated storm produced 2 to 3.5 inches of rain in about one hour during the evening of the August 21st over the town of Bedford and several small stream basins in central Bedford County. The Bedford COOP (BDFV2) site located just north of the core of heaviest rainfall, had a 24-hour total of 3.30 ending at 12z on the 22nd. This was the 9th highest 1-day August rainfall at this site with sporadic records dating back to 1893.|Several flood reports from the area were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tributary of the South Fork of Little Otter Creek overflowed and closed a portion of Liberty Street near West Federal Street and Jeter Street at West Washington Street. Some minor flooding also occurred near the intersection of 4th Street and Bedford Avenue closing the road for a period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Copious moisture spreading northward from the Gulf of Mexico combined with a weak boundary to produce a complex of thunderstorms during the afternoon of August 11th in northern Virginia. This complex moved eastward through the late afternoon and evening, causing numerous instances of flash flooding. Stream flooding continued through the following morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One foot deep water running across Old Tavern Road near US 17.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Copious moisture spreading northward from the Gulf of Mexico combined with a weak boundary to produce a complex of thunderstorms during the afternoon of August 11th in northern Virginia. This complex moved eastward through the late afternoon and evening, causing numerous instances of flash flooding. Stream flooding continued through the following morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Kahns Road flooded and closed due to torrential rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Copious moisture spreading northward from the Gulf of Mexico combined with a weak boundary to produce a complex of thunderstorms during the afternoon of August 11th in northern Virginia. This complex moved eastward through the late afternoon and evening, causing numerous instances of flash flooding. Stream flooding continued through the following morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding caused a road closure near Bradley Forest Road and Brentsville Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Copious moisture spreading northward from the Gulf of Mexico combined with a weak boundary to produce a complex of thunderstorms during the afternoon of August 11th in northern Virginia. This complex moved eastward through the late afternoon and evening, causing numerous instances of flash flooding. Stream flooding continued through the following morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding forced the closure of Artemus Road and Pageland Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Copious moisture spreading northward from the Gulf of Mexico combined with a weak boundary to produce a complex of thunderstorms during the afternoon of August 11th in northern Virginia. This complex moved eastward through the late afternoon and evening, causing numerous instances of flash flooding. Stream flooding continued through the following morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Swift water rescue reported due to vehicle trapped in floodwaters near Lee Highway (US 29) and Sudley Road (VA 234).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Copious moisture spreading northward from the Gulf of Mexico combined with a weak boundary to produce a complex of thunderstorms during the afternoon of August 11th in northern Virginia. This complex moved eastward through the late afternoon and evening, causing numerous instances of flash flooding. Stream flooding continued through the following morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding near the intersection of Route 55 and Route 723 caused a road closure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Copious moisture spreading northward from the Gulf of Mexico combined with a weak boundary to produce a complex of thunderstorms during the afternoon of August 11th in northern Virginia. This complex moved eastward through the late afternoon and evening, causing numerous instances of flash flooding. Stream flooding continued through the following morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Old Tavern Road was flooded and closed one-half mile from The Plains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated storm produced 2 to 3.5 inches of rain in about one hour during the evening of the August 21st over the town of Bedford and several small stream basins in central Bedford County. The Bedford COOP (BDFV2) site located just north of the core of heaviest rainfall, had a 24-hour total of 3.30 ending at 12z on the 22nd. This was the 9th highest 1-day August rainfall at this site with sporadic records dating back to 1893.|Several flood reports from the area were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to two feet of standing water was observed along Route 460 westbound near the intersection with Hulls Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms were scattered across the mountains of southwest Virginia from mid-afternoon into the evening. With a very moist air mass in place some of the storms produced pockets of heavy rainfall and some flash flooding. A slow-moving cell just south of Grayson Highlands State Park produced rainfall of 3 to 4 inches in about two-hours or close to the 100-year annual recurrence interval (0.01 annual exceedance probability). Rainfall was more in the 2 to 3 inch range in several hours over western Craig County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Briar Run was reported out of its banks and flooded portions of Brian Run Lane and Peace Haven Lane. Wilson Creek flooded a portion of Route 817.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy downpours over the City of Martinsville and surrounding portions of Henry County dropped 2 to 4+ inches of rain over a period of hours during the early morning of May 22nd and caused some flash flooding. 24-hour rainfall reports included Jones Creek IFLOWS (JOEV2) 4.73 inches and Martinsville COOP (MARV2) 3.17 inches both located in the City of Martinsville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent heavy rains caused flooding along Jones Creek which flooded portions of Liberty Street within the City of Martinsville. This appeared to be beyond typical urban runoff issues as a natural stream flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front associated with a negatively tilted shortwave upper trough approached the region on October 23rd. Precipitable water rose to near excessive levels for the time of year with 1.44 on the 12z/23 RNK and 1.57 on the 12z GSO soundings, with sea-level values of 1.75 to 2. These are roughly 3 standard deviations above the late October climatology and near all-time maxima for the date. Enhanced rainfall rates due to decent instability (for late October) were also expected to develop.  Moderate rainfall of 1 to 2 inches had already fall ahead of a cold front that approached in the mid-afternoon. Flood impacts began to occur quickly as the higher rate rainfall moved into the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall and caused Wolf Creek to flood closing portions of Wolf Creek Road and Buckhorn Road. The Wolf Creek gage at Narrows downstream did not flood however.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front associated with a negatively tilted shortwave upper trough approached the region on October 23rd. Precipitable water rose to near excessive levels for the time of year with 1.44 on the 12z/23 RNK and 1.57 on the 12z GSO soundings, with sea-level values of 1.75 to 2. These are roughly 3 standard deviations above the late October climatology and near all-time maxima for the date. Enhanced rainfall rates due to decent instability (for late October) were also expected to develop.  Moderate rainfall of 1 to 2 inches had already fall ahead of a cold front that approached in the mid-afternoon. Flood impacts began to occur quickly as the higher rate rainfall moved into the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent heavy rainfall caused flooding on several creeks and streams with roads flooded in the Sugar Grove area. Stream gauges in the county did not reach flood stage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The evening of May 18th saw one of the more impressive flash flood events of the month as several strong to severe thunderstorms tracked across eastern Carroll County, VA. Several rounds of very heavy rainfall were observed across the Big Reed Island Creek watershed between Dugspur and Hillsville with various radar estimates of about 4 to 6+ inches of rain in about 3 hours.  No rain gages were available in this area to provide a check on the radar estimates, but both Dual-Pol and Multi-Radar/Multi-Sensor rain estimates were roughly 5-6 inches.  Several flooding reports and mudslides reports were received very quickly. Emergency management officials in the county later reported that the flash flooding was the worst in living memory according to several residents in the area.  An approximate 1.5 mile stretch of Highway 221 was shut down due to 3 separate mud slides and 2 areas where Big Reed Island Creek was over the road to a depth of 4-5 feet at its peak.Fortunately, there were no injuries and only a single box culvert sustained significant damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed due to water flowing over the roads, creeks out of their banks, or mudslides.  This included portions of U.S. 221, VA 673 or Pilgrims|Trail and Route 100. In addition, Brick Haven Road was flooded by Big Reed Island Creek. Multiple mudslides were reported along Buck Horn Road and along Floyd Pike (Route 221) including one near the 6000 block of Floyd Pike (Route 221).

These are roughly 3 standard deviations above the late October climatology and near all-time maxima for the date. Moderate rainfall of 1 to 2 inches had already fall ahead of a cold front that approached in the mid-afternoon. Flood impacts began to occur quickly as the higher rate rainfall moved into the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were flooded in the Pearisburg area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall was moderate to heavy across much of south central and southwest Virginia from May 23-25. Storm total rain amounts ranged widely, from 1 to 6+ inches. Rainfall rates were not particularly high through most of the event but the continuous nature of the rains eventually led to flooding. All of the river flooding was in the minor category and several non-forecast points also rose above flood stage including Dunlap Creek (DLPV2) in Alleghany County, VA, Craig Creek Route 614 (CCIV2) in Craig County, Johns Creek at New Castle (JCRV2), Cowpasture River near Clifton Forge (COWV2),  Kerrs Creek near Lexington IFLOWS (KCKV2) and the New River at Allisonia (ALSV2).   Despite the fact that the gaged locations indicated mainly minor flooding, several county emergency officials reported many instances of substantially worse flooding. The most significant reports came out of Pulaski, Wythe, Grayson, and Carroll counties in VA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was observed flowing over Anthony Drive (Route 692) from flooded Spencer Creek. Photos appeared to show water well over six inches deep. A nearby rain gauge, Sanville IFLOWS (SAVV2), showed that rainfall rates increased sharply around 18:00 EST with 0.63 inches falling in 15 minutes. This followed an abrupt one inch of rain in the previous 24-hours which left soils wet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low interacted with a frontal boundary near the Mid-Atlantic region and low pressure formed along the boundary. High moisture content and thunderstorms led to widespread flooding across the Mid-Atlantic region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rain caused flooding of Russell Road near Stringtown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front stalled out across the Mid-Atlantic region and showers developed across the region. High moisture content and slow storm motion led to high rainfall rates and flooding especially across the Central Foothills of Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Durrett Ridge Road flooded and closed due to Swift Run being out of its banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low interacted with a frontal boundary near the Mid-Atlantic region and low pressure formed along the boundary. High moisture content and thunderstorms led to widespread flooding across the Mid-Atlantic region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream gauge on Cameron Run at Alexandria/Eisenhower exceeded the flood stage of 8 feet. It peaked at 8.25 feet at 16:23 EST. Water overflowed the banks on both sides of Cameron Run upstream of the railroad culverts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream gauge on Cameron Run at Huntington exceeded the flood stage of 6.5 feet. It peaked at 8.38 feet at 01:15 EST. A foot and a half of water covered the end of Fenwick Drive. Lesser amounts covered the road further south down to the area in front of house number 5706. Several homes on Fenwick are surrounded by water but the houses themselves were not threatened above ground. Water also began to cover both ends of Arlington Terrace. Backwater on Quander Brook may begin to flood a service road near Fort Hunt Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms associated with areas of low pressure along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous road closures were reported in and around the Laurel area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms associated with areas of low pressure along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported at the 4800 Block of West Broad Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms developed across the Piedmont and foothills of central Virginia, ahead of a weak cold front drifting southward from the Ohio River region.  While instability appeared marginal across the region, a weak upper level disturbance aloft provided additional support for these storms to briefly intensify to severe levels.  Precipitable water values ahead of the front were observed around 1.5 inches which contributed to heavy downpours with locally observed amounts of 2 to 3 inches in a few hours time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported at several locations around Lynchburg including Sussex Avenue, Wards Ferry Road, Twin Oaks Drive and Greenwood Drive  which was flooded by overflow from Blackwater Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms associated with areas of low pressure along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Right and center lanes were closed on Interstate 195 North near Broad Street due to standing water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms along a stationary boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of the Virginia Northern Neck.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were flooded over portions of eastern Lancaster county, especially around the town of Kilmarnock. Radar estimates indicated that up to three inches of rain had fallen in the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Old Courthouse Road was flooded and closed near Besley Road due to rapid overtopping of Wolftrap Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure and its associated cold front passed through during the early morning hours of April 16th. Heavy rain of 2 to 4 inches fell in portions of the state, producing flooding throughout northern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The USGS stream gauge on Accotink Creek near Annandale rapidly exceeded flood stage, causing flooding of Woodburn Road and Prosperity Avenue. This event continued as an areal flood for a few more hours after the time noted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure and its associated cold front passed through during the early morning hours of April 16th. Heavy rain of 2 to 4 inches fell in portions of the state, producing flooding throughout northern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Swinks Mill Road flooded and closed due to rapidly rising water over the road on Scotts Run.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure and its associated cold front passed through during the early morning hours of April 16th. Heavy rain of 2 to 4 inches fell in portions of the state, producing flooding throughout northern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Braddock Road flooded and closed due to rapidly rising water in the vicinity of Backlick Run.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak frontal boundary located near the I-64 corridor provided the focus for repeated thunderstorm activity through the evening across several counties. A broad area of low pressure over the southeastern U.S. pulled very high moisture into the region allowing the slow-moving storms to be efficient rainfall producers. Rainfall amount were generally 2 to 4 inches, with isolated higher totals indicated by radar in the heavier cores occurring over a several hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding closed the intersection of Copper Cove and Valleyview Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The synoptic pattern remained little changed from the previous day with deep moisture in place.  Several bands of very heavy rainfall pushed north from the Carolinas in the late afternoon and evening as weak area of low pressure over the southeast lifted slowly northward. The slow-moving storms were highly efficient rainfall producers that affected number of areas in southside Virginia, most notably the Martinsville and Danville areas. Rainfall totals were generally 2 to 4 inches occurring over a several hour period with isolated higher amounts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were flooded across the City of Martinsville and several homes were flooded. The roof of a department store partially collapsed due to the weight of water. A local state of emergency was declared by the City Council in the aftermath due to the massive cleanup required. Local sources stated that 4 to 5 inches of rain fell in approximately one hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of thunderstorms developed along a stationary front and produced torrential rains across parts of Patrick, Henry and Franklin counties. Rainfall was estimated at 2 to 3 inches in a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 220 was flooded in at least four places just south of Bassett Forks near where Reed Creek enters the Smith River. One car was submerged in flood waters in the median and the driver rescued without injury. Several trees were brought down by mudslides along the highway. At a mobile home park near Blackberry Park Circle several rescues by boat were required. Numerous approach roads were flooded hindering rescue operations. Multiple vehicles were damaged as drivers attempted to drive through high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The synoptic pattern remained little changed from the previous day with deep moisture in place.  Several bands of very heavy rainfall pushed north from the Carolinas in the late afternoon and evening as weak area of low pressure over the southeast lifted slowly northward. The slow-moving storms were highly efficient rainfall producers that affected number of areas in southside Virginia, most notably the Martinsville and Danville areas. Rainfall totals were generally 2 to 4 inches occurring over a several hour period with isolated higher amounts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Part of Epworth Road near Cana was washed away by the heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Morning thunderstorms rolled across Tazewell County dropping radar estimated 2 to 4 inches of rain near the Town of Tazewell and lesser amounts toward Richlands over a several hour period causing numerous flood problems.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Kirby Road and Hillcreek Road in Richlands both closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms in the mid- to late afternoon moved dropped through southern Henry County dropping 2 to 3 inches of rain in a few hours and a report of flooded roads.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County Emergency Management reported that part of Joseph Martin Highway in Ridgeway was closed due to flash flooding.

Rainfall amount were generally 2 to 4 inches, with isolated higher totals indicated by radar in the heavier cores occurring over a several hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to two feet of rapidly of flowing water was over the intersection of Hazelwood Terrace and Beagle Club Road along with a small debris flow and small tree pushed into the roadway. Spotter reported 4.32 inches of rain in less than 4 hours at the time of the report. Turner Branch Road in the Blue Ridge area was washed out and closed and a motorist was rescued from the flood waters.

The Peters Creek Road off-ramp from Route 581 was also closed. An automated rain gauge in the Garden City area of Roanoke had about 3.5 inches of rain in 6 hours.

Rainfall amount were generally 2 to 4 inches, with isolated higher totals indicated by radar in the heavier cores occurring over a several hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported covering portions of Route 501 between Rustburg and Gladys.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak frontal boundary located near the I-64 corridor provided the focus for repeated thunderstorm activity through the evening across several counties. A broad area of low pressure over the southeastern U.S. pulled very high moisture into the region allowing the slow-moving storms to be efficient rainfall producers. Rainfall amount were generally 2 to 4 inches, with isolated higher totals indicated by radar in the heavier cores occurring over a several hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported to be running over Valley View Road from an unnamed creek and into the basement of a nearby home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The synoptic pattern remained little changed from the previous day with deep moisture in place.  Several bands of very heavy rainfall pushed north from the Carolinas in the late afternoon and evening as weak area of low pressure over the southeast lifted slowly northward. The slow-moving storms were highly efficient rainfall producers that affected number of areas in southside Virginia, most notably the Martinsville and Danville areas. Rainfall totals were generally 2 to 4 inches occurring over a several hour period with isolated higher amounts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of flooded roadways from Pittsylvania County, mainly east of Danville where the heaviest rain occurred. Radar estimated up to 3 inches fell near the Halifax border. Flowing water was reported across Falls Creek Road in Ringgold and the intersection of Highway 29 and Fall Creek Road near Blair was also flooded. Water was also reported over the intersection of Reeves Mill Road and East Hightower near Kentuck.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms within the warm and humid air mass dropped heavy rainfall across portions of Bedford, Amherst, and Campbell counties with flash flooding in a few locations reported. The radar estimated rainfall was 1.5 to 3 inches in several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Beck Creek Road and Tent Mountains Farm Road were flooded and closed.  A rescue was conducted for one man in a home surrounded by rising flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated storm dropped 1.5 to 2 inches of rain a few hours producing flash flooding along portions of Brush Creek.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brush Creek was reported out of its banks with water over Brush Creek Road in spots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving or stationary storms during the afternoon over a small part of Roanoke County and City produced severe flash flooding mainly confined to the Mudlick Creek basin, a small tributary of the Roanoke River. Radar estimates 4 to 6 inches of rain fell across parts of the 20 square mile basin, but later rain gauge reports indicated 6 to 7+ inches fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extensive flooding occurred from Mudlick Creek along Grandin and Garst Mill Roads with water getting into many homes. Post-flood survey indicated a recurrence interval of about 10 years (0.1 annual exceedance probability) on Mudlick Creek as the stream rose roughly 10 feet above baseflow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving or stationary storms during the afternoon over a small part of Roanoke County and City produced severe flash flooding mainly confined to the Mudlick Creek basin, a small tributary of the Roanoke River. Radar estimates 4 to 6 inches of rain fell across parts of the 20 square mile basin, but later rain gauge reports indicated 6 to 7+ inches fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of flash flooding in Roanoke County.  Most of the reports were between 230 and 500 PM EST.  Several roads were closed or damaged and at least 20 homes partially flooded. Garst Mill Park was flooded to a depth of several feet. The main cause of flooding was from Mudlick Creek which rose approximately 10 feet in elevation to an estimated flow of 2400 cubic feet per second per a post-flood survey.  The survey indicated that the flood was approximately a 10-year recurrence interval (0.1 annual exceedance probability).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms developed in the late afternoon dropping very heavy rain across southern Bath County and produced localized flash flooding near Bacova Junction. Rainfall was estimated by radar at approximately 4 to 5 inches in about 2 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 687 near Bacova Junction was closed in several spots with water and debris running across the road. The valley bottom was flooded up to near the houses and several culverts and parts of the road were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of thunderstorms developed along a stationary front and produced torrential rains across parts of Patrick, Henry and Franklin counties. Rainfall was estimated at 2 to 3 inches in a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several feet of water was reported over Commerce Street in Stuart.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The synoptic pattern remained little changed from the previous day with deep moisture in place.  Several bands of very heavy rainfall pushed north from the Carolinas in the late afternoon and evening as weak area of low pressure over the southeast lifted slowly northward. The slow-moving storms were highly efficient rainfall producers that affected number of areas in southside Virginia, most notably the Martinsville and Danville areas. Rainfall totals were generally 2 to 4 inches occurring over a several hour period with isolated higher amounts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were flooded in Halifax County where a swath of 2 to 3.5 inches of rain fell in several hours. Flowing water was reported across Howard Anderson Road in the 6000 block. and also over the intersection of Philpott Road and Sandy Beach Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Evening thunderstorms dropped 2 to 3 inches of rain over several hours in some spots causing isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Beck Creek Road and Tent Mountain Farm Road were flooded and closed. A man was rescued from his home along Beck Creek Road as water was rising around the structure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Morning thunderstorms rolled across Tazewell County dropping radar estimated 2 to 4 inches of rain near the Town of Tazewell and lesser amounts toward Richlands over a several hour period causing numerous flood problems.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were flooded in the town of Tazewell with water running across them. A number of homes had flooded basements and at least six evacuations or water rescues were conducted at or near Maplewood Lane, Walnut Street, Texas Street, Mitchell Street, and Third Street. Most of the flood reports were from 930 to 1030 AM EST. In addition, the North Fork of the Clinch River was reported out of its banks and flooding Professional Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upslope winds on the east side of the Blue Ridge just north of an approaching warm front aided in producing torrential rainfall and catastrophic flooding in parts of Central Virginia. Rainfall amounts of 4-10 inches occurred north and west of Charlottesville. Later in the evening, heavy rain developed in northern Virginia, with 1-3 inches in the southern and western suburbs of Washington DC, as well as again near Harrisonburg. This produced another round of flooding and some flash flooding that actually continued into June 1st. June Storm Data will contain those details when available.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotswood Trail flooded and closed at Lambs Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upslope winds on the east side of the Blue Ridge just north of an approaching warm front aided in producing torrential rainfall and catastrophic flooding in parts of Central Virginia. Rainfall amounts of 4-10 inches occurred north and west of Charlottesville. Later in the evening, heavy rain developed in northern Virginia, with 1-3 inches in the southern and western suburbs of Washington DC, as well as again near Harrisonburg. This produced another round of flooding and some flash flooding that actually continued into June 1st. June Storm Data will contain those details when available.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dunnes Shop Road flooded and closed in multiple areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving or stationary storms during the afternoon over a small part of Roanoke County and City produced severe flash flooding mainly confined to the Mudlick Creek basin, a small tributary of the Roanoke River. Radar estimates 4 to 6 inches of rain fell across parts of the 20 square mile basin, but later rain gauge reports indicated 6 to 7+ inches fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Electric Road was reported closed in the 2500 block due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms tracked across parts of western Botetourt County dropping 2 or more inches of rain in a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A portion of VA Highway 655 also known as Fincastle Road, washed out due runoff from heavy rain.  This occurred where a bridge crosses over a small creek which flows into Catawba Creek. The road was closed by VDOT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Nighttime storms with heavy downpours formed across portions of the Blue Ridge and foothills including the Roanoke metro area. Several reports of flash flooding in and around Roanoke were received. Radar estimated up to 2 to 3 inches fell in just a few hours in parts of Roanoke City and adjacent parts of Roanoke County. These estimates were closely verified by rainfall reports at 12z (0700 AM local time) on the 12th that included 2.86 inches at Roanoke 5.5 SW CCR (VA-RN-3), 2.82 inches at Hidden Valley MS (HVMV2), 2.69 inches at Cave Spring 2.4 SSW CCR (VA-RN-1), 2.56 inches at Peters Creek IFLOWS (PTRV2) and 2.49 inches at Strauss Park RG (SPKV2).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was observed in parts of Roanoke City. Ore Branch flooded near the Ramada Inn on Franklin Road with some hotel customers moved to different locations. Water was also reported flowing over Franklin Road, Brambleton Road and in the Raleigh Court area. A home basement was flooded along Northwest Hershberger Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Nighttime storms with heavy downpours formed across portions of the Blue Ridge and foothills including the Roanoke metro area. Several reports of flash flooding in and around Roanoke were received. Radar estimated up to 2 to 3 inches fell in just a few hours in parts of Roanoke City and adjacent parts of Roanoke County. These estimates were closely verified by rainfall reports at 12z (0700 AM local time) on the 12th that included 2.86 inches at Roanoke 5.5 SW CCR (VA-RN-3), 2.82 inches at Hidden Valley MS (HVMV2), 2.69 inches at Cave Spring 2.4 SSW CCR (VA-RN-1), 2.56 inches at Peters Creek IFLOWS (PTRV2) and 2.49 inches at Strauss Park RG (SPKV2).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency calls were first received just after midnight related to flash flooding mainly along and near Electric Road. Water was reported flowing over Electric Road and the road was closed, but Roanoke County police rescued five stranded drivers in the general area.  Brambleton Road in the County was also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Florence made landfall on the far southeast North Carolina coast on September 14th and tracked very slowly across South Carolina before slowly re-curving across far western North Carolina and southwest Virginia as Tropical Depression and on into the Ohio Valley. Multiple incidents of strong winds, flash flooding and flooding occurred with Florence. The following counties were included in a subsequent Presidential Disaster Declaration: Botetourt, Franklin, Halifax, City of Martinsville, Patrick, and Pittsylvania. Several more counties were still working through the validation process: Charlotte, Craig, and City of Danville. The first rainfall of any significance reached southern Virginia on the 15th  with about 1 to 3 inches falling by 12z (700 AM) on the 16th. Much heavier rainfall began to spread further northward during the afternoon and evening of the 16th prompting numerous Flash Flood Warnings and causing significant flood impacts.  The highest observed rain amounts in Virginia within the HSA were over parts of southwest Floyd and northwest Patrick counties with over 8 inches in 24 hours (ending at 700 AM on the 17th) and 9 to 10 inches storm total. Willis 2.7 SE CoCoRaHS (VA-FL-6) had 9.59 inches in the 72-hour period ending 700 AM on the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pulaski County was included in the Presidential Major Disaster declaration with significant damage to roads and other structures. The time and spatial occurrence was based on the highest runoff from the CREST hydrologic model.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Florence made landfall on the far southeast North Carolina coast on September 14th and tracked very slowly across South Carolina before slowly re-curving across far western North Carolina and southwest Virginia as Tropical Depression and on into the Ohio Valley. Multiple incidents of strong winds, flash flooding and flooding occurred with Florence. The following counties were included in a subsequent Presidential Disaster Declaration: Botetourt, Franklin, Halifax, City of Martinsville, Patrick, and Pittsylvania. Several more counties were still working through the validation process: Charlotte, Craig, and City of Danville. The first rainfall of any significance reached southern Virginia on the 15th  with about 1 to 3 inches falling by 12z (700 AM) on the 16th. Much heavier rainfall began to spread further northward during the afternoon and evening of the 16th prompting numerous Flash Flood Warnings and causing significant flood impacts.  The highest observed rain amounts in Virginia within the HSA were over parts of southwest Floyd and northwest Patrick counties with over 8 inches in 24 hours (ending at 700 AM on the 17th) and 9 to 10 inches storm total. Willis 2.7 SE CoCoRaHS (VA-FL-6) had 9.59 inches in the 72-hour period ending 700 AM on the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Patrick County was declared a Major Disaster under the Presidential Declaration. Calls to 911 dispatch about flooding began shortly 1250 AM EST with water reported near some homes Riverside Drive along Poorhouse Creek in Stuart. At the same time water was also over the road on portions of  Jeb Stuart Highway (Route 58) just north of Stuart. Several other roads were later reported closed with up to 1.5 feet of water flowing across Jacks Creek Road. The river gage on the Smith River near Woolwine (SMWV2) gage showed a rise in less than six hours to a crest of 12.35 feet, Minor flood stage is 9 feet and Moderate flood stage 11 feet. This was the 2nd highest reading at this gage since data started there in 1995 and was roughly a 5-10 year annual recurrence interval (0.20 to 0.10 annual exceedance probability).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Florence made landfall on the far southeast North Carolina coast on September 14th and tracked very slowly across South Carolina before slowly re-curving across far western North Carolina and southwest Virginia as Tropical Depression and on into the Ohio Valley. The following counties were included in a subsequent Presidential Disaster Declaration: Botetourt, Franklin, Halifax, City of Martinsville, Patrick, and Pittsylvania. Willis 2.7 SE CoCoRaHS (VA-FL-6) had 9.59 inches in the 72-hour period ending 700 AM on the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed across Floyd County with the first report along Thunderstruck Road. Other reports of roads flooded and closed included Woods Gap Road, Franklin Pike, Poor Farm Road, Shooting Creek Road, Twin Falls Road, Spring Dale Road, and Spangler Mill Road. The road at Spangler Mill was reported damaged. County officials urged people in about 300 households in floodplains to evacuate. National Guard units rescued one person from a vehicle stranded in a flooded roadway around 500 AM local time.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Charlotte County was included in the Presidential Major Disaster declaration with significant damage to roads and other structures. A report was received of 10 to 12 inches of water flowing over Route 631 from Tanyard Branch. Bluestone Creek also spilled out of its banks and flooded a portion of Route 92. Sunnyside Road was also closed due to flooding from a nearby stream. Runoff per the CREST Hydrologic model was highest in far eastern parts of the county.

There were several flash flood reports across the county with roads closed across Halifax County including Highway 119 near the VA-NC state line, Railroad Avenue in South Boston and Summit Drive in South Boston.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rock Island Creek exceeded its banks by almost five feet in depth. Water was also reported over several roads in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Florence made landfall on the far southeast North Carolina coast on September 14th and tracked very slowly across South Carolina before slowly re-curving across far western North Carolina and southwest Virginia as Tropical Depression and on into the Ohio Valley. Multiple incidents of strong winds, flash flooding and flooding occurred with Florence. The following counties were included in a subsequent Presidential Disaster Declaration: Botetourt, Franklin, Halifax, City of Martinsville, Patrick, and Pittsylvania. Several more counties were still working through the validation process: Charlotte, Craig, and City of Danville. Willis 2.7 SE CoCoRaHS (VA-FL-6) had 9.59 inches in the 72-hour period ending 700 AM on the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding closed Sycamore Creek Road (3200 Block) as water was flowing across the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving frontal boundary along with moisture convergence along the Blue Ridge and some modest jet stream support aloft triggered numerous thunderstorms from the late afternoon through late evening hours. These slow-moving storms produced very heavy rainfall from the Blue Ridge out across several piedmont counties. Rainfall totals ranged from 3 to 5 inches with isolated higher amounts approaching 6 inches in northern Franklin and southern Bedford counties, all of it occurring generally within a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of flash flooding in Danville. A home was collapsed on Mt. Carmel Baptist Street with the residents being rescued by boat. Another person was rescued from rising waters along Riverside Drive even as others passed through the floodwaters. Up to 69 vehicles were damaged or destroyed at Woodall Chevrolet in Danville along with some building damage as water from local runoff and possibly from an unnamed stream just to the west of the dealers rose.  A nearby NAPA auto parts store was also flooded.  Four vehicles were fully or partially submerged along Timberlake Drive and Northmont Boulevard with no injuries or rescues.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving frontal boundary along with moisture convergence along the Blue Ridge and some modest jet stream support aloft triggered numerous thunderstorms from the late afternoon through late evening hours. These slow-moving storms produced very heavy rainfall from the Blue Ridge out across several piedmont counties. Rainfall totals ranged from 3 to 5 inches with isolated higher amounts approaching 6 inches in northern Franklin and southern Bedford counties, all of it occurring generally within a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported flowing over Highway 122. A private bridge over the East Fork Beaverdam Creek was badly damaged from the flooded creek, shown in a video on local media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving frontal boundary along with moisture convergence along the Blue Ridge and some modest jet stream support aloft triggered numerous thunderstorms from the late afternoon through late evening hours. These slow-moving storms produced very heavy rainfall from the Blue Ridge out across several piedmont counties. Rainfall totals ranged from 3 to 5 inches with isolated higher amounts approaching 6 inches in northern Franklin and southern Bedford counties, all of it occurring generally within a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several reports of flash flooding in Roanoke County including water flowing across Cotton Hill Road and Penn Forest Boulevard. Back Creek Road was flooded and closed. In addition, Mud Lick Creek overflowed in the Garst Mill area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms associated with tropical cyclone Florence produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding and lingering flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed in southwest Mecklenburg county. Flowing water was reported across numerous secondary roads which became impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Florence made landfall on the far southeast North Carolina coast on September 14th and tracked very slowly across South Carolina before slowly re-curving across far western North Carolina and southwest Virginia as Tropical Depression and on into the Ohio Valley. Multiple incidents of strong winds, flash flooding and flooding occurred with Florence. The following counties were included in a subsequent Presidential Disaster Declaration: Botetourt, Franklin, Halifax, City of Martinsville, Patrick, and Pittsylvania. Several more counties were still working through the validation process: Charlotte, Craig, and City of Danville. The first rainfall of any significance reached southern Virginia on the 15th  with about 1 to 3 inches falling by 12z (700 AM) on the 16th. Much heavier rainfall began to spread further northward during the afternoon and evening of the 16th prompting numerous Flash Flood Warnings and causing significant flood impacts.  The highest observed rain amounts in Virginia within the HSA were over parts of southwest Floyd and northwest Patrick counties with over 8 inches in 24 hours (ending at 700 AM on the 17th) and 9 to 10 inches storm total. Willis 2.7 SE CoCoRaHS (VA-FL-6) had 9.59 inches in the 72-hour period ending 700 AM on the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roanoke County was included in the Presidential Major Disaster declaration with significant damage to roads and other structures.  Route 744E from Bottom Creek Road to Bent Mountain Road was closed due to a  washout. Radar estimated 4 to 6 inches of rain over the southwest part of the county in the 24- hours ending 1200z (700 AM local time) and several IFLOWS rain gages had 4+ inches including 4.40 inches at Witt's Orchard (WITV2) and 4.21 inches at Poor Mtn. (POOV2). The areal extent of flooding was adjusted per runoff from the CREST hydrologic model.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving frontal boundary along with moisture convergence along the Blue Ridge and some modest jet stream support aloft triggered numerous thunderstorms from the late afternoon through late evening hours. These slow-moving storms produced very heavy rainfall from the Blue Ridge out across several piedmont counties. Rainfall totals ranged from 3 to 5 inches with isolated higher amounts approaching 6 inches in northern Franklin and southern Bedford counties, all of it occurring generally within a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were reported to have been flooded in northern Franklin County. Little Ellie Creek flooded Sample Road near Peters Pike Road. Foul Ground Creek flooded Brooks Mill Road and a vehicle was swept away in the water but no injuries were reported. Doe Run flooded Ashpone Tavern Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving frontal boundary along with moisture convergence along the Blue Ridge and some modest jet stream support aloft triggered numerous thunderstorms from the late afternoon through late evening hours. These slow-moving storms produced very heavy rainfall from the Blue Ridge out across several piedmont counties. Rainfall totals ranged from 3 to 5 inches with isolated higher amounts approaching 6 inches in northern Franklin and southern Bedford counties, all of it occurring generally within a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Riverbend Road in Altavista and Johnson Creek Road were flooded and closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary boundary through the Mid-Atlantic into the Mid-Mississippi Valley spawned thunderstorms in the afternoon and evening of August 31st that carried over into the early morning hours of September 1st . Storms were mainly across the foothills and southside Virginia with radar estimated rainfall of 1 to 2.5 inches in a few hours.  Top rain gage reports ending at 0700 EDT on the 1st included 2.28 at Woolwine 3.7 NNE CCR (VA-PR-6), 1.98 at Woolwine COOP (WLWV2), 1.74 at Smith R. Fieldale IFLOWS (SRVV2), 1.50 at Martinsville COOP (MARV2), and 1.11 at Meadows Church IFLOWS (MEAV2). Dissipation of the storms prior to daybreak allowed for enough heating during the day to destabilize the region again for another round of thunderstorms during the afternoon in the same areas near the stationary boundary. The late afternoon storms on the 1st dropped 2-3 inches in a few hours across parts of eastern Campbell, western Charlotte and southern Appomattox counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powder Mill Creek flooded Powder Creek Lane and School Board Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms associated with tropical cyclone Florence produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding and lingering flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Plantersville Road was closed due to flash flooding. Numerous secondary roads in the area were also flooded and impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms associated with tropical cyclone Florence produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding and lingering flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bible Way Road was closed near Victoria between Courthouse Road and Lees Mill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms associated with tropical cyclone Florence produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding and lingering flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Plantersville Road was washed out between Thompson Road and Braxton Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms associated with tropical cyclone Florence produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding and lingering flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: East and west bound lanes of Route 58 were washed out near Pools Mill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms associated with tropical cyclone Florence produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding and lingering flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant flash flooding was reported. Floodwaters were about halfway up a ranch home.
