The following counties were included in a subsequent Presidential Disaster Declaration: Botetourt, Franklin, Halifax, City of Martinsville, Patrick, and Pittsylvania. Several more counties were still working through the validation process: Charlotte, Craig, and City of Danville. The first rainfall of any significance reached southern Virginia on the 15th  with about 1 to 3 inches falling by 12z (700 AM) on the 16th. Much heavier rainfall began to spread further northward during the afternoon and evening of the 16th prompting numerous Flash Flood Warnings and causing significant flood impacts.  The highest observed rain amounts in Virginia within the HSA were over parts of southwest Floyd and northwest Patrick counties with over 8 inches in 24 hours (ending at 700 AM on the 17th) and 9 to 10 inches storm total. Willis 2.7 SE CoCoRaHS (VA-FL-6) had 9.59 inches in the 72-hour period ending 700 AM on the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Henry County was part of Presidential Major Disaster declaration with significant damage to roads and other structures. There were nearly a dozen calls to the county 911 for flooding, including several road washouts and motorists trapped in a flooded vehicle. Residents of Blackberry Mobile Home Park also reported flooding. The time of occurrence is based on reports and the time of highest runoff from the CREST hydrologic model.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving frontal boundary along with moisture convergence along the Blue Ridge and some modest jet stream support aloft triggered numerous thunderstorms from the late afternoon through late evening hours. These slow-moving storms produced very heavy rainfall from the Blue Ridge out across several piedmont counties. Rainfall totals ranged from 3 to 5 inches with isolated higher amounts approaching 6 inches in northern Franklin and southern Bedford counties, all of it occurring generally within a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several reports of flash flooding in the county including water over Highway 58 near Cloverdale Lumber. County Road 729 southeast of Keeling was washed out and a vehicle stuck in the water and another vehicle was stuck in high water along Little Sandy Creek. On Twitter the public tweeted that a bridge on Birch Creek Road off Route 360 was flooded. News reports said 13 roads were closed in the county, some sustaining heavy damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving frontal boundary along with moisture convergence along the Blue Ridge and some modest jet stream support aloft triggered numerous thunderstorms from the late afternoon through late evening hours. These slow-moving storms produced very heavy rainfall from the Blue Ridge out across several piedmont counties. Rainfall totals ranged from 3 to 5 inches with isolated higher amounts approaching 6 inches in northern Franklin and southern Bedford counties, all of it occurring generally within a few hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State Route 755, Persimmons Road was closed by flooding. The nearby South Fork Roanoke River gage at Shawsville  (SHA 2) crested at just over Minor flood stage of 5 feet, altough it is not clear if this flooding was related.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Convective coverage was more widespread on the afternoon of the 8th and into the early morning of the 9th in association with a slow-moving frontal boundary and very high moisture. The most notable storms occurred over Galax City and nearby parts of western Carroll County during the late evening hours. Radar estimated 4 to 6 inches fell in several hours across parts of Galax with more than 6 inches in the Pipers Gap area of western Carroll County. The top five gage reports ending 12z on the 9th included Pipers Gap IFLOWS (PPGV2) 5.57,  Galax Water Plant COOP (GAAV2) 5.50, and Woodlawn IFLOWS (WDLV2) 5.12. At the Pipers Gap gage, 2.44 fell in 1-hour during the most intense portion of the storms, roughly a 25-year (.04 AEP) recurrence interval.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred in downtown Galax, with Main Street closed and several businesses badly flooded. Water was rapidly flowing through Blevins  Building Supply store and was described as a 'river' running through it. Damage to the store and inventory was estimated to exceed $1 million. Eight cars were reported stalled out in the flood waters and a Carroll County squad car was totaled as a result. Evacuations were required from a nursing home facility and several other businesses suffered damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Convective coverage was more widespread on the afternoon of the 8th and into the early morning of the 9th in association with a slow-moving frontal boundary and very high moisture. At the Pipers Gap gage, 2.44 fell in 1-hour during the most intense portion of the storms, roughly a 25-year (.04 AEP) recurrence interval.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: U.S. Route 58 and Fieldview Road in western Carroll County was flooded and closed with water over the road. Flash flooding was also reported in several creeks in the Faddis Hill area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Florence made landfall on the far southeast North Carolina coast on September 14th and tracked very slowly across South Carolina before slowly re-curving across far western North Carolina and southwest Virginia as Tropical Depression and on into the Ohio Valley. Multiple incidents of strong winds, flash flooding and flooding occurred with Florence. The following counties were included in a subsequent Presidential Disaster Declaration: Botetourt, Franklin, Halifax, City of Martinsville, Patrick, and Pittsylvania. Several more counties were still working through the validation process: Charlotte, Craig, and City of Danville. The first rainfall of any significance reached southern Virginia on the 15th  with about 1 to 3 inches falling by 12z (700 AM) on the 16th. Much heavier rainfall began to spread further northward during the afternoon and evening of the 16th prompting numerous Flash Flood Warnings and causing significant flood impacts.  The highest observed rain amounts in Virginia within the HSA were over parts of southwest Floyd and northwest Patrick counties with over 8 inches in 24 hours (ending at 700 AM on the 17th) and 9 to 10 inches storm total. Willis 2.7 SE CoCoRaHS (VA-FL-6) had 9.59 inches in the 72-hour period ending 700 AM on the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Martinsville City was included as part of the Presidential Major Disaster declaration with significant damage to roads and other structures. The time of occurrence is based on the highest runoff from the CREST hydrologic model.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calvary Road (Route 119) near Alton was flooded by swift-moving water and closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving frontal boundary along with moisture convergence along the Blue Ridge and some modest jet stream support aloft triggered numerous thunderstorms from the late afternoon through late evening hours. These slow-moving storms produced very heavy rainfall from the Blue Ridge out across several piedmont counties. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extensive flooding occurred in the Rich Creek with the downtown area flooded. Some mudslides were reported along Route 460 between Narrows and Rich Creek. State Line Road was flooded and closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving frontal boundary along with moisture convergence along the Blue Ridge and some modest jet stream support aloft triggered numerous thunderstorms from the late afternoon through late evening hours. These slow-moving storms produced very heavy rainfall from the Blue Ridge out across several piedmont counties. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spruce Street in Martinsville was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex, broken line of thunderstorms developed during the afternoon ahead of an approaching cold front producing very heavy rainfall and some embedded severe storms. Trees were blown trees onto power lines, which caused a number of power outages.  Henry County and the city of Martinsville suffered the most tree damage and power outages. Rainfall was extremely intense within the very moist environment with precipitable water over 2 inches and several boundary collisions enhancing the rainfall. The highest amounts occurred in the City of Lynchburg and adjacent parts of Campbell County where radar estimated 4 to 6 inches of rain in several hours which was confirmed by several rain gages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme rainfall of 4 to 6 inches in several hours produced widespread flash flooding in the City of Lynchburg. The first reports began around 515 PM local time (415 PM EST) and continued for several hours with numerous roads closed by water running over them, vehicles flooded, water rescues and several properties flooded or threatened.  Several apartment complexes and nearby cars were flooded. The runoff into College Lake caused water to overflow the dam (which is also Lakeside Road) to a depth of at least 12 to 18 inches and into Blackwater Creek. The overtopping is considered a partial failure of the dam but a  complete failure of the structure was possible. This resulted in a Flash Flood Warning for a dam failure and subsequent evacuation of about 120 homes in the downstream watershed of Blackwater Creek. According to local City officials flood damage exceeded $18 million in roads, property and water control structure damages, the biggest to College Lake Dam.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary boundary through the Mid-Atlantic into the Mid-Mississippi Valley spawned thunderstorms in the afternoon and evening of August 31st that carried over into the early morning hours of September 1st . Storms were mainly across the foothills and southside Virginia with radar estimated rainfall of 1 to 2.5 inches in a few hours.  Top rain gage reports ending at 0700 EDT on the 1st included 2.28 at Woolwine 3.7 NNE CCR (VA-PR-6), 1.98 at Woolwine COOP (WLWV2), 1.74 at Smith R. Fieldale IFLOWS (SRVV2), 1.50 at Martinsville COOP (MARV2), and 1.11 at Meadows Church IFLOWS (MEAV2). Dissipation of the storms prior to daybreak allowed for enough heating during the day to destabilize the region again for another round of thunderstorms during the afternoon in the same areas near the stationary boundary. The late afternoon storms on the 1st dropped 2-3 inches in a few hours across parts of eastern Campbell, western Charlotte and southern Appomattox counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Little Falling River overflowed Morris Church Road (Route 646) southwest of Red House. The road was closed by State Police.

The time of occurrence and spatial extent of flooding is based on the highest runoff from the CREST hydrologic model. Flash flooding was worst across the southern parts of the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water got into a home near the 16000 block of Wyndale Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Danville City was included in the Presidential Major Disaster declaration with some damage to roads and other structures. Danville ASOS (DAN) had 2.09 inches of rain on the 17th. the 3rd highest ever for the date with data back to 1916.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Grayson County was included in the Presidential Major Disaster declaration with significant damage to roads and other structures. The automated ran gage at Galax (GAXV2) measured 3.23 inches in the 24-hours ending 1200z (700 AM local time). The time of occurrence is based on the highest runoff from the CREST hydrologic model. Flash flooding was worst across the southeastern parts of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms along a stationary boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of the Virginia Eastern Shore.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was covering numerous roads in Exmore. Debris was floating down Virginia Avenue. Radar estimates indicated that up to three to four inches of rain had fallen in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms along a stationary boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of the Virginia Eastern Shore.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous homes were flooded and water rescues were reported in Exmore. Radar estimates indicated that up to three to four inches of rain had fallen in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A southerly flow pumped in plenty of moisture from the Atlantic while a slow moving cold front approached from the west. Copious amounts of moisture ahead of the boundary led to showers and thunderstorms. Torrential downpours combined with convection training over the same areas led to some flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported on multiple roadways near Rixeyville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered strong to severe severe thunderstorms during the afternoon that produced hail up to the size of quarters and isolated flash flooding in Pittsylvania County. Radar estimated that heaviest rain, 3 to 5 inches in several hours, fell in the southeast along the Halifax County line, although hail may have affected these estimates. Runoff from the CREST model also showed a maximum in that same area, but no flood reports were received from there.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Road closed due to flash flooding from Bearskin Creek near the intersection of Irish and Bearskin Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex, broken line of thunderstorms developed during the afternoon ahead of an approaching cold front producing very heavy rainfall and some embedded severe storms. Trees were blown trees onto power lines, which caused a number of power outages.  Henry County and the city of Martinsville suffered the most tree damage and power outages. Rainfall was extremely intense within the very moist environment with precipitable water over 2 inches and several boundary collisions enhancing the rainfall. The highest amounts occurred in the City of Lynchburg and adjacent parts of Campbell County where radar estimated 4 to 6 inches of rain in several hours which was confirmed by several rain gages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 880N at Stateline Bridge Road was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex, broken line of thunderstorms developed during the afternoon ahead of an approaching cold front producing very heavy rainfall and some embedded severe storms. Trees were blown trees onto power lines, which caused a number of power outages.  Henry County and the city of Martinsville suffered the most tree damage and power outages. Rainfall was extremely intense within the very moist environment with precipitable water over 2 inches and several boundary collisions enhancing the rainfall. The highest amounts occurred in the City of Lynchburg and adjacent parts of Campbell County where radar estimated 4 to 6 inches of rain in several hours which was confirmed by several rain gages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports of flash flooding from the Timberlake area of Campbell County. Sunburst Road was flooded and impassable with more than a foot of water over it. Three feet of was over Timberlake and Woodhaven Road with a vehicle trapped. Buffalo Creek was well outof its banks and flooding Route 460. A swift was rescue was reported in this area. In addition, water was observed flowing over the spillway of Timberlake Dam. In the aftermath up to eight roads in the county were reported with some type of structural damage. Two homes were also reported to have been damaged.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A TV viewer reported flooding at Bridge Street and Memorial Boulevard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A humid air mass remained in place, while a frontal boundary was slowly approaching from eastern Kentucky. Nighttime convection resulted in flash flooding in southwestern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding on Lee Hwy between Halls Bottom Rd and Oak Park Dr.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Neighborhood roadways were flooded. Rainfall total of 2.19 inches was measured in 45 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Colley Avenue was closed due to flooding at the underpass. One vehicle was caught in the flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong storms with heavy rainfall developed in the late afternoon across parts of the New River Valley including Pulaski, Montgomery and the City of Radford. Water was reported over several roadways including on the Virginia Tech campus and over a dozen buildings on the Radford University campus that were flooded. Rain gage reports ending at 7 AM on the 31st included Radford 0.9 WNW CoCoRaHS (VA-RDC-1) 3.00, Radford DCP (RDFV2) 2.55, Blacksburg 0.4 N CoCoRaHS (VA-MN-6) and 2.44, Blacksburg IFLOWS (BLGV2) 2.29. Most of the rain fell in a much shorter time period however, generally in about 1 hour between 4 and 5 PM EST.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding closed several streets in Radford with water over 2 feet deep reported on 2nd Street. In addition, up to 15 building on the Radford University campus had some water damage, with 12 of those described as significant damage. Two roads in Radford were also damaged, Wadsworth and Fairfax Streets.

Water was reported over several roadways including on the Virginia Tech campus and over a dozen buildings on the Radford University campus that were flooded. Rain gage reports ending at 7 AM on the 31st included Radford 0.9 WNW CoCoRaHS (VA-RDC-1) 3.00, Radford DCP (RDFV2) 2.55, Blacksburg 0.4 N CoCoRaHS (VA-MN-6) and 2.44, Blacksburg IFLOWS (BLGV2) 2.29. Most of the rain fell in a much shorter time period however, generally in about 1 hour between 4 and 5 PM EST.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed including North Fork Road and several around the Virginia Tech campus.

Trees were blown trees onto power lines, which caused a number of power outages.  Henry County and the city of Martinsville suffered the most tree damage and power outages. Rainfall was extremely intense within the very moist environment with precipitable water over 2 inches and several boundary collisions enhancing the rainfall. The highest amounts occurred in the City of Lynchburg and adjacent parts of Campbell County where radar estimated 4 to 6 inches of rain in several hours which was confirmed by several rain gages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several reports of roads washed out or overtopped in the Forest area  including Spring Lake Road, Bethel Church Road, Terry Place and Goose Hollow Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal low pressure moved up the Atlantic seaboard. Copious moisture spread northward across the southern and western suburbs of Washington DC in the state of Virginia. Rainfall totals of 3 to 6 inches were widespread, causing fairly widespread flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Accotink Creek was rain-swollen and flowing over Woodburn Road after torrential rains. A driver drove into the high rushing water and had to be rescued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed over the higher terrain producing some flooding and minor wind damage in an unstable atmosphere ahead of a squall line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water covered parts of Route 23.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal low pressure moved up the Atlantic seaboard. Copious moisture spread northward across the southern and western suburbs of Washington DC in the state of Virginia. Rainfall totals of 3 to 6 inches were widespread, causing fairly widespread flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Burke Lake Road flooded and closed near the outlet to Burke Lake due to torrential rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal low pressure moved up the Atlantic seaboard. Copious moisture spread northward across the southern and western suburbs of Washington DC in the state of Virginia. Rainfall totals of 3 to 6 inches were widespread, causing fairly widespread flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Prosperity Avenue flooded and closed due to torrential rain swelling area creeks north of Woodburn Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal low pressure moved up the Atlantic seaboard. Copious moisture spread northward across the southern and western suburbs of Washington DC in the state of Virginia. Rainfall totals of 3 to 6 inches were widespread, causing fairly widespread flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rapid flooding in the 10300 block of Lawyers Road forced the closure of the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal low pressure moved up the Atlantic seaboard. Copious moisture spread northward across the southern and western suburbs of Washington DC in the state of Virginia. Rainfall totals of 3 to 6 inches were widespread, causing fairly widespread flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Burke Centre Parkway was flooded due to torrential rainfall and had to be closed near Burke Commons Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain on saturated soils during the evening of June 21st caused flooding. The heavy rains intensified overnight, causing both flooding and flash flooding early on the 22nd. Widespread flooding persisted throughout Northern Virginia throughout the day n the 22nd. Additional heavy rain during the evening of the 22nd caused more flooding which continued into the 23rd, and the combination of all the rain events created stream flooding that continued through the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Garth Road washed out due to rapidly rising and moving waters at Swift Run.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain on saturated soils during the evening of June 21st caused flooding. The heavy rains intensified overnight, causing both flooding and flash flooding early on the 22nd. Widespread flooding persisted throughout Northern Virginia throughout the day n the 22nd. Additional heavy rain during the evening of the 22nd caused more flooding which continued into the 23rd, and the combination of all the rain events created stream flooding that continued through the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Octonia Road flooded and closed with extremely high water and a large amount of debris.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amicus Road flooded and closed east of Celt Road due to extreme flooding of Swift Run.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal low pressure moved up the Atlantic seaboard. Copious moisture spread northward across the southern and western suburbs of Washington DC in the state of Virginia. Rainfall totals of 3 to 6 inches were widespread, causing fairly widespread flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rain prompted flooding of Broad Run, forcing a water rescue on Evergreen Mills Road near Belmont Ridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal low pressure moved up the Atlantic seaboard. Copious moisture spread northward across the southern and western suburbs of Washington DC in the state of Virginia. Rainfall totals of 3 to 6 inches were widespread, causing fairly widespread flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sudley Road (State Route 234) flooded due to Youngs Branch going out of its banks. Two vehicles were trapped in swift rushing water from Youngs Branch, prompting water rescues.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal low pressure moved up the Atlantic seaboard. Copious moisture spread northward across the southern and western suburbs of Washington DC in the state of Virginia. Rainfall totals of 3 to 6 inches were widespread, causing fairly widespread flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Swift water rescue on Featherbed Lane near Manassas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms in advance of and along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was reported at Pemberton Road and Mayland Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms in advance of and along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was reported on roads, as well as 1.5 inches of rain occurring in the past 25 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms in advance of and along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was reported near Huguenot Trail and Route 288.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms in advance of and along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Vehicle was stuck in water on Cox Road in Innsbrook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms in advance of and along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Street flooding was reported on Interstate 64 at Exit 220.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms in advance of and along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported at Pump Road and Ridgefield Parkway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms in advance of and along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported running across the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain on saturated soils during the evening of June 21st caused flooding. The heavy rains intensified overnight, causing both flooding and flash flooding early on the 22nd. Widespread flooding persisted throughout Northern Virginia throughout the day n the 22nd. Additional heavy rain during the evening of the 22nd caused more flooding which continued into the 23rd, and the combination of all the rain events created stream flooding that continued through the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rapid and extreme flooding along Muddy Run east of Haywood, causing the closure of West Hoover Road and Towles Road. 911 operators reported that the flooding was causing problems for deputies and that these areas typically do not flood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered heavy afternoon thunderstorms produced 1-2 inches of rain, causing flooding in a few different locations in northern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A portion of US Highway 522 was flooded and closed due to rapidly rising water near Huntly.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surging warm front spread moderate to heavy rain across the region. Dry conditions prior to the event served to limit the amount of flooding, but 1.5-2 inches of rain was enough to cause some street flooding in more urbanized areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rain caused rapidly rising standing water in the unit block of West Glebe Road. The water reportedly reached three feet or more in depth, forcing closure of the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upslope winds on the east side of the Blue Ridge just north of an approaching warm front aided in producing torrential rainfall and catastrophic flooding in parts of Central Virginia. Rainfall amounts of 4-10 inches occurred north and west of Charlottesville. Later in the evening, heavy rain developed in northern Virginia, with 1-3 inches in the southern and western suburbs of Washington DC, as well as again near Harrisonburg. This produced another round of flooding and some flash flooding that actually continued into June 1st. June Storm Data will contain those details when available.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A driver had to be rescued when the vehicle became stranded in two to three feet of standing water on US Highway 29 near Plank Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple water rescues ongoing in the Syria area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains on May 21st in western Rockingham County caused significant flooding. Those floodwaters moved downstream on the 22nd, causing stream flooding. Meanwhile, afternoon showers and thunderstorms produced around an inch of rain, producing some urban flooding in the DC metropolitan area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant flash flooding was reported in the Yankeetown and Fulks Run areas, with water in vehicles, numerous roads closed, and most small streams out of their banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper ridge off the east coast and an upper low over the central U.S. combined to bring enhanced moisture into the region. Weak low pressure along a frontal boundary draped near the Virginia-North Carolina border provided additional convergence and lift to produce widespread showers and thunderstorms mainly over the piedmont and Blue Ridge foothills. Rainfall ranged from 1 to 3 inches across parts of Patrick, Franklin and Henry counties most of which fell in about a 3-hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blackberry Creek flooded portions of Route 698 west of Bassett.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upslope winds on the east side of the Blue Ridge just north of an approaching warm front aided in producing torrential rainfall and catastrophic flooding in parts of Central Virginia. Rainfall amounts of 4-10 inches occurred north and west of Charlottesville. Later in the evening, heavy rain developed in northern Virginia, with 1-3 inches in the southern and western suburbs of Washington DC, as well as again near Harrisonburg. This produced another round of flooding and some flash flooding that actually continued into June 1st. June Storm Data will contain those details when available.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream gage on Mechums River near White Hall rapidly exceeded the 11 foot flood stage during the time indicated. The yard of a home and the driveway of the same home flooded. The peak level observed was 17.42 feet at 10:30pm EST May 30th, which was the highest recorded at this site since 2004.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream gage on the North Fork Rivanna River near Earlysville rapidly exceeded the 14 foot flood stage during the times indicated. The peak value was estimated at 21.89 feet. Significant flooding occurred in northern Albemarle County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed around a stalled boundary. A slow storm motion combined with copious amounts of moisture led to heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The gauge at Cameron Run in Alexandria rapidly surpassed flood stage of 9.5 feet and crested at 12.41 feet. Most of the Lower Holmes Run Trail along Cameron Run was flooded. Backwater flooding affected the areas along Backlick Run. Water overflowed the banks on both sides of Cameron Run upstream of the railroad culverts.  ||The gauge at Fourmile run rapidly passed flood stage of 12 feet and crested at 12.26 feet. Water flooded the north bank into grassy areas and parking lots. ||The gauge at Cameron Run and Eisenhower Avenue rapidly surpassed flood stage of 8 feet, cresting at 12.25 feet.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two cars were swept off Old Ballard Road at Ivy Creek. The occupant of one vehicle escaped and was rescued. The second vehicle was observed to repeatedly toss and overturn in the raging floodwaters. The two occupants of that vehicle could not be rescued and were found dead.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture encroached upon the area from the Gulf of Mexico, where subtropical storm Alberto was developing. Scattered mainly diurnal convection produced isolated flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads flooded. Flooding across a trailer park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture encroached upon the area from the Gulf of Mexico, where subtropical storm Alberto was developing. Scattered mainly diurnal convection produced isolated flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intersection of Highways 23 and 83 in Pound was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture encroached upon the area from the Gulf of Mexico, where subtropical storm Alberto was developing. Scattered mainly diurnal convection produced isolated flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding on several roadways. Several mudslides in the southern part of the county near Holston Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A southerly flow pumped in plenty of moisture from the Atlantic while a slow moving cold front approached from the west. Copious amounts of moisture ahead of the boundary led to showers and thunderstorms. Torrential downpours combined with convection training over the same areas led to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ongoing flooding intensified to flash flooding along Moores Creek. A pedestrian bridge connecting Sunset Avenue and Sunset Avenue Extension was washed away. Water was reported to be four to five feet up on the outside of a home near the creek, and floodwaters pushed into Azalea Park, washing away parts of the playground and damaging fencing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surging warm front spread moderate to heavy rain across the region. Dry conditions prior to the event served to limit the amount of flooding, but 1.5-2 inches of rain was enough to cause some street flooding in more urbanized areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Floodwaters from Rocky Branch rapidly rose and covered Red Church Road east of Luray.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surging warm front spread moderate to heavy rain across the region. Dry conditions prior to the event served to limit the amount of flooding, but 1.5-2 inches of rain was enough to cause some street flooding in more urbanized areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported to have rapidly risen over the curb in North Arlington near 22nd and Harrison Street. Trash cans were visible floating down the street in the floodwaters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the passage of a coastal low, bands of moisture continued to pull northward across the same areas that had already experienced heavy rain. Heavy rainfall fell in some areas, with widespread flooding throughout the period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rain overwhelmed a building drainage system, forcing a pipe to burst, causing a partial roof collapse at a restaurant, and water coming through the wall of another business, flooding about a third of the floor of that business.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the passage of a coastal low, bands of moisture continued to pull northward across the same areas that had already experienced heavy rain. Heavy rainfall fell in some areas, with widespread flooding throughout the period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported after torrential rains on multiple levels of the Ballston Quarter parking garage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported with two feet of water over the road near the intersection of Oak Park Road and Lillards Ford Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rinacas Corner Road at Batman Road was closed due to flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Shenandoah river road at Route 340 was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary remain stalled over the region and tropical moisture was in place. This caused locally heavy rainfall which led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was getting into houses on Junior Avenue. Two water rescues occurred with people trapped in vehicles due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary remain stalled over the region and tropical moisture was in place. This caused locally heavy rainfall which led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place on VA-602. Multiple roads were flooded and closed in town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Cyclone Michael tracked from South Carolina northeast and off the Mid Atlantic Coast from Thursday morning, October 11 into early Friday morning, October 12. Showers and scattered thunderstorms associated with the Tropical Cyclone produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia, the Virginia Northern Neck, and the Middle Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water from flash flooding was reported entering homes, businesses, and government buildings across the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported across Game Farm Road in the northern part of the county.

Showers and scattered thunderstorms associated with the Tropical Cyclone produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia, the Virginia Northern Neck, and the Middle Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported near the intersection of Jefferson Davis Highway and Page Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After Hurricane Michael made landfall near Mexico Beach, Florida with maximum sustained winds of 155 mph and a minimum central pressure of 919 mb on Wednesday October 10th, it weakened to a tropical storm as it tracked northeastward through Georgia and South Carolina. The tropical storm then tracked across North Carolina and southeast Virginia Thursday and Thursday night, October 11th, emerging back into the Atlantic Ocean early Friday morning, October 12th. Ahead of the tropical storm, the strong low level wind field combined with some instability ahead of the storm to generate bands of showers and thunderstorms, one of which became severe. As the system passed south of the region, heavy rain then caused instances of flooding, and strong winds brought down trees. Across Virginia, maximum sustained winds reached 35 mph, peak wind gusts reached 46 mph, and some rainfall totals were observed in excess of 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Harrell Road was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Michael made landfall along the Florida panhandle as major hurricane (Category 4 on the Saffir-Simpson scale) on Wednesday afternoon, October 10th, 2018, then tracked northeastward with the northern portion of the storm circulation tracking across portions of Southside, Virginia Thursday afternoon, the 11th. A deep flow of tropical moisture into the Appalachians and central mid Atlantic region ahead of the storm began to generate excessive rainfall across portions of the region as early as Wednesday evening, mainly along the Interstate 77 corridor, causing some degree of flash flooding and otherwise saturating the ground even before the arrival of the rainfall directly associated with Michael.||As the storm circulation approached on Thursday, a cold front moving in from the west and interacted with the storm and enhanced rainfall especially east of Interstate 81. Widespread rainfall amounts of 4 to 8 inches were reported, along with local amounts over 10 inches, mainly from the mountains of North Carolina up through Southside Virginia. This resulted in significant flash flooding with flash flood emergencies issued for the city of Roanoke, as well as Roanoke County, and southern Pittsylvania county including the city of Danville.  Unfortunately, there were five fatalities as vehicles were swept away by flash flood waters in Pittsylvania County, Danville, and Charlotte County, Virginia.||The massive volume of water also then generated rapid rises on rivers including the New, Roanoke, and Dan. Major flooding was reported at several river gage locations along with a couple of record crests. There were a few landslides reported as well, blocking roads and in one case destroying a shed.||In addition, as the northern portion of the storm circulation moved across the Piedmont, bands of heavier rains/convection developed and mixed strong winds down to the surface.  Many trees were blown down in the water logged soil especially across Pittsylvania, Halifax and Charlotte counties of Virginia where rainfall was heaviest.  Despite some initial reports of tornado sightings, damage surveys revealed no conclusive evidence of tornadic circulations and judged damage was caused by straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pittsylvania County was included in a Presidential Major Disaster declaration due mainly to the severe flooding associated with Tropical Storm Michael. Rainfall of 4 to 8 inches in several hours triggered widespread flash flooding across the county with numerous roads closed and extensive damage.  A man lost his life when his automobile was washed off Sandy Creek Road near the 600 block during intense flooding along Sandy Creek.  Media reports indicate the incident occurred around 330 PM local time, with one witness observing that water was flowing rapidly at least two feet above the road surface.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Charlotte County was included in a Presidential Major Disaster declaration due mainly to the severe flooding associated with Tropical Storm Michael. There was widespread flash flooding across the county with numerous roads closed and damaged. Two people lost their lives after being swept off a bridge into floodwaters. The fatalities occurred after a car stranded on a Mt. Harmony Road bridge around 728 PM local Thursday. The Charlotte County Sheriff's office stated that the vehicle originally had three occupants who were said to be clinging to the bridge railings. A 17-year-old male was able to be rescued, while the two other adults, one male the other female were swept away in the flood waters.

A deep flow of tropical moisture into the Appalachians and central mid Atlantic region ahead of the storm began to generate excessive rainfall across portions of the region as early as Wednesday evening, mainly along the Interstate 77 corridor, causing some degree of flash flooding and otherwise saturating the ground even before the arrival of the rainfall directly associated with Michael.||As the storm circulation approached on Thursday, a cold front moving in from the west and interacted with the storm and enhanced rainfall especially east of Interstate 81. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roanoke County was included in a Presidential Major Disaster declaration due mainly to the severe flooding associated with Tropical Storm Michael. Extremely high sustained rain rates (2-4 inches per hour) became concentrated across parts of the Roanoke area between 1100 AM to 200 PM local time. At 243 PM a rare Flash Flood Emergency was issued for Roanoke City, City of Salem and Roanoke County after consultation with local Emergency management amidst reports of numerous water rescues in the area. Radar and rain gages showed 3 to 6 inches of rain during this period from the southern part of Roanoke City into the adjacent portions of Roanoke County. There were numerous reports of flash flooding across mainly the South County area where the heaviest rains fell, 5 to 6 inches in some locations. Mudlick Creek flooded across Cresthill Drive to a depth of at least one foot. Several small mudslides occurred and numerous roads were closed. There was also reports of high water rescues in several areas including a motorist stranded on Ferguson Valley Road along Back Creek. The USGS gage on Back Creek near Dundee (BCKV2) crested at 23.09 feet (17,000 cfs) in the evening of the 11th at the 2nd highest stage and discharge since records began in 1971 and only slightly below the record flood in November 1985 of 25. 1 feet.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains of 3 to 6 inches caused numerous creeks to escape their banks forcing the closure of several primary and secondary roads. The river gage on the Smith River near Woolwine (SMWV2) showed a rise in less than six hours to a crest of 12.15 feet, Minor flood stage is 9 feet and Moderate flood stage 11 feet. This was the 4th highest reading at this gage since data started there in 1995 and was roughly a 5-year annual recurrence interval (0.10 annual exceedance probability).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Danville City was included in a Presidential Major Disaster declaration due mainly to the severe flooding associated with Tropical Storm Michael. Catastrophic flash flooding occurred across the City of Danville as extreme rains of 4 to 8 inches in several hours fell. Two people were killed in Danville after being were caught inside vehicles in the floodwaters and were pulled under rising waters as rescuers struggled to reach them. The first was 53-year old man that occurred at 500 PM local time in the 100 block of Colonial Court. The second occurred around 1020 PM on Goodyear Boulevard, as a 60-year old woman was trapped in her car in floodwaters and drowned. There were at least a dozen other high water rescues reported several of these along Riverside Drive where water was reported up to four feet deep. There was severe road and property damage across Danville with costs running into the millions of dollars. According to an early assessment from the Danville Fire Chief, five properties were completely destroyed, 19  sustained major damage, 55 received minor damage and 117 structures were affected.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several reports of flash flooding in Wythe County with a number of roads closed in Wytheville and the eastern portions of the county as early as 900 AM local time. Reed Creek reportedly flooded East Lee Highway bear Carter's Park. The New River trail was flooded near Max Meadows although probably from the flooded New River itself.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed in Pulaski County and the town due to flooding. Peak Creek flooded several roads including Crescent Street, Lottier Bottom Road and Main Street. The creek crested at around 8 feet on a staff gage in town calibrated to the IFLOWS gage (PCRV2) which was out of service during the event. Minor flood stage is 8 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Michael made landfall along the Florida panhandle as major hurricane (Category 4 on the Saffir-Simpson scale) on Wednesday afternoon, October 10th, 2018, then tracked northeastward with the northern portion of the storm circulation tracking across portions of Southside, Virginia Thursday afternoon, the 11th. A deep flow of tropical moisture into the Appalachians and central mid Atlantic region ahead of the storm began to generate excessive rainfall across portions of the region as early as Wednesday evening, mainly along the Interstate 77 corridor, causing some degree of flash flooding and otherwise saturating the ground even before the arrival of the rainfall directly associated with Michael.||As the storm circulation approached on Thursday, a cold front moving in from the west and interacted with the storm and enhanced rainfall especially east of Interstate 81. Widespread rainfall amounts of 4 to 8 inches were reported, along with local amounts over 10 inches, mainly from the mountains of North Carolina up through Southside Virginia. This resulted in significant flash flooding with flash flood emergencies issued for the city of Roanoke, as well as Roanoke County, and southern Pittsylvania county including the city of Danville.  Unfortunately, there were five fatalities as vehicles were swept away by flash flood waters in Pittsylvania County, Danville, and Charlotte County, Virginia.||The massive volume of water also then generated rapid rises on rivers including the New, Roanoke, and Dan. Major flooding was reported at several river gage locations along with a couple of record crests. There were a few landslides reported as well, blocking roads and in one case destroying a shed.||In addition, as the northern portion of the storm circulation moved across the Piedmont, bands of heavier rains/convection developed and mixed strong winds down to the surface.  Many trees were blown down in the water logged soil especially across Pittsylvania, Halifax and Charlotte counties of Virginia where rainfall was heaviest.  Despite some initial reports of tornado sightings, damage surveys revealed no conclusive evidence of tornadic circulations and judged damage was caused by straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed due to flooding in Carroll County. A daycare center was evacuated near a small creek flooding along Fisher Road. Brush Creek near Ivanhoe was reported out of its banks and entering several nearby homes.

Despite some initial reports of tornado sightings, damage surveys revealed no conclusive evidence of tornadic circulations and judged damage was caused by straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wards Mill Branch was flooded and out of its banks, flowing across Coal Creek Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A bridge over Catawba Creek on Hogan Hollow Road (Route 737) was reportedly underwater. The USGS gage on Catawba Creek near Catawba (CTWV2) crested at 7.92 feet (Minor flood stage is 7 feet), its highest level since September, 2004 when it reached 10.3 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remains of Hurricane Michael were preceded in parts of western Virginia by a so-called Predecessor Event (PRE) which brought moderate to heavy rainfall across several counties early on the 11th of October. A deep moisture plume surged north on the periphery of the subtropical ridge over the southeast with the very high precipitable water producing high rainfall rates. The heaviest rainfall from the PRE was concentrated in upper and middle portions of the New River basin and the far upper Dan basin where the amountsl ranged from 2 to 6 inches with isolated higher amounts in the 24 hours ending at 700 AM local time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mill Creek flooded and several people were evacuated from a mobile home park off of Glade Street. Social media had several reports of flooded roads in Galax including the intersection of Swanson Street and McArthur Street and Glendale Road and Hebron Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Michael made landfall along the Florida panhandle as major hurricane (Category 4 on the Saffir-Simpson scale) on Wednesday afternoon, October 10th, 2018, then tracked northeastward with the northern portion of the storm circulation tracking across portions of Southside, Virginia Thursday afternoon, the 11th. A deep flow of tropical moisture into the Appalachians and central mid Atlantic region ahead of the storm began to generate excessive rainfall across portions of the region as early as Wednesday evening, mainly along the Interstate 77 corridor, causing some degree of flash flooding and otherwise saturating the ground even before the arrival of the rainfall directly associated with Michael.||As the storm circulation approached on Thursday, a cold front moving in from the west and interacted with the storm and enhanced rainfall especially east of Interstate 81. Widespread rainfall amounts of 4 to 8 inches were reported, along with local amounts over 10 inches, mainly from the mountains of North Carolina up through Southside Virginia. This resulted in significant flash flooding with flash flood emergencies issued for the city of Roanoke, as well as Roanoke County, and southern Pittsylvania county including the city of Danville.  Unfortunately, there were five fatalities as vehicles were swept away by flash flood waters in Pittsylvania County, Danville, and Charlotte County, Virginia.||The massive volume of water also then generated rapid rises on rivers including the New, Roanoke, and Dan. Major flooding was reported at several river gage locations along with a couple of record crests. There were a few landslides reported as well, blocking roads and in one case destroying a shed.||In addition, as the northern portion of the storm circulation moved across the Piedmont, bands of heavier rains/convection developed and mixed strong winds down to the surface.  Many trees were blown down in the water logged soil especially across Pittsylvania, Halifax and Charlotte counties of Virginia where rainfall was heaviest.  Despite some initial reports of tornado sightings, damage surveys revealed no conclusive evidence of tornadic circulations and judged damage was caused by straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extremely high sustained rain rates (2-4 inches per hour) became concentrated across parts of the Roanoke area between 1100 AM to 200 PM local time. At 243 PM a rare Flash Flood Emergency was issued for Roanoke City, City of Salem and Roanoke County after consultation with local Emergency management amidst reports of numerous water rescues in the area. Radar and rain gages showed 3 to 6 inches of rain during this period from the southern part of Roanoke City into the adjacent portions of Salem. At least 25 roads or intersections were closed at some point due to flooding in Salem. Mason Creek flooded several mobile home communities in Salem as shown on social media. More than 40 people were evacuated from threatened homes. Mason creek crested at the upstream IFLOWS gage (MSCV2) at 7.90 feet around noon, NWS Minor flood stage is 7 feet.   The state of Virginia declared Salem as a Small Business Administration Disaster area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Cyclone Michael tracked from South Carolina northeast and off the Mid Atlantic Coast from Thursday morning, October 11 into early Friday morning, October 12. Showers and scattered thunderstorms associated with the Tropical Cyclone produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia, the Virginia Northern Neck, and the Middle Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Patrick Henry Highway (Route 360) was closed at Amelia Avenue due to flash flooding. Several roads in the area were flooded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Appomattox County was included in a Presidential Major Disaster declaration due mainly to the severe flooding associated with Tropical Storm Michael. Purdums Branch was several feet out of its banks and flooding apartments along Red House Road. In the town of Appomattox, a woman and boy were rescued after fast-moving water trapped the two in a creek behind their home on Church Street. A team of about 17 first responders with the Concord Appomattox Swiftwater Team responded to the rescue effort around 4:45 PM Local time. The two victims were quickly pulled from the waters without injury according to news reports.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains led to some flash flooding as to 2 to 3 inches fell in a short period. Lynchburg Airport ASOS (LYH) set a daily record rainfall for October 11th of 2.58 inches, with records back to 1893. The old record was 1.76 inches in 1990. Flooding was reported along a Ivy Creek with water flowing across Ivy Drive.  City of Lynchburg officials activated the Emergency Action Plan for College Lake dam early Thursday as a result of the heavy rain but did not have to evacuate any residents or businesses downstream of  the dam along Blackwater Creek. Several other roads were reported closed in Lynchburg including Greenwood Drive where it crosses Ivy Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 3 to 5 inches in just a few hours caused flash flooding across parts of Buckingham County. A road was washed out near the intersection of Sycamore creek abd Wood land Church Road. Sharps Creek was flooded across Diana Road washing a vehicle into the stream and some distance downstream before a successful water rescue was carried out. The Slate River near Arvonia (ARVV2) crested at 15.1 feet, above the Minor flood stage of 12 feet.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Montgomery County was included in a Presidential Major Disaster declaration due mainly to the severe flooding associated with Tropical Storm Michael.  At least four roads were reported closed across the county including in the Ellett Valley area. At least six inches of moving water was reported over Toms Creek Road near Redbud Road and Toms Creek was out of its banks and flooding Meadowbrook Road in Blacksburg. Elsewhere in Montgomery County 13-year-old became trapped in an all-terrain vehicle in a flooded creek and the New River Valley swift-water rescue team helped to rescue the teenager.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: County-wide flooding was reported by law enforcement with at least seven roads were reported closed across Floyd County. Four vehicles were abandoned in high water on Buffalo Mountain Road, Spangler Mill Road, Daniel's Run Road and Stonewall Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Michael made landfall along the Florida panhandle as major hurricane (Category 4 on the Saffir-Simpson scale) on Wednesday afternoon, October 10th, 2018, then tracked northeastward with the northern portion of the storm circulation tracking across portions of Southside, Virginia Thursday afternoon, the 11th. A deep flow of tropical moisture into the Appalachians and central mid Atlantic region ahead of the storm began to generate excessive rainfall across portions of the region as early as Wednesday evening, mainly along the Interstate 77 corridor, causing some degree of flash flooding and otherwise saturating the ground even before the arrival of the rainfall directly associated with Michael.||As the storm circulation approached on Thursday, a cold front moving in from the west and interacted with the storm and enhanced rainfall especially east of Interstate 81. Widespread rainfall amounts of 4 to 8 inches were reported, along with local amounts over 10 inches, mainly from the mountains of North Carolina up through Southside Virginia. This resulted in significant flash flooding with flash flood emergencies issued for the city of Roanoke, as well as Roanoke County, and southern Pittsylvania county including the city of Danville.  Unfortunately, there were five fatalities as vehicles were swept away by flash flood waters in Pittsylvania County, Danville, and Charlotte County, Virginia.||The massive volume of water also then generated rapid rises on rivers including the New, Roanoke, and Dan. Major flooding was reported at several river gage locations along with a couple of record crests. There were a few landslides reported as well, blocking roads and in one case destroying a shed.||In addition, as the northern portion of the storm circulation moved across the Piedmont, bands of heavier rains/convection developed and mixed strong winds down to the surface.  Many trees were blown down in the water logged soil especially across Pittsylvania, Halifax and Charlotte counties of Virginia where rainfall was heaviest.  Despite some initial reports of tornado sightings, damage surveys revealed no conclusive evidence of tornadic circulations and judged damage was caused by straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Halifax County was included in a Presidential Major Disaster declaration due to the severe flooding associated with Tropical Storm Michael. Rainfall of 4 to 8 inches in several hours triggered widespread flash flooding across the county with numerous roads closed and extensive damage. County officials described it as 'the worst, most devastating storm we've ever seen in the county'. The 911 dispatch center had more than 300 calls for assistance between 5:00 and 7:00 PM on the 11th and more than 700 by 7:00 AM the next day Among the reports received was Lawless Creek as much as 300 feet out of its banks and flooding a church. News photos showed a portion of Pumping Hill Road near Nathalie completely destroyed. Several water rescues were made, including one on Terrys Bridge Road near Scottsburg on Friday morning the 12th. A debris flow closed a portion of Route 58 in southwest Halifax.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary boundary set up near the Potomac River weak low pressure developed along the boundary. There was plenty of moisture in place from the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico, and this combined with instability to produce very heavy rainfall rates in convection that developed. Convection was maximized around the boundary across northern Virginia near the Potomac River, and this led to several instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level at Cameron Run rapidly rose above flood stage of 11 feet. The water level crested at 15.7 feet at 9:40 AM EST. Most of Lower Holes Run Trail along Cameron Run was flooded, and backwater flooded areas along Backlick Run upstream of Cameron Run.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual long-duration event occurred June 7-11 as a very slow-moving upper trough and surface high across New England combined to produce several days of cool-air damming and persistent rainfall along the frontal boundary and in orographically favored areas of the Blue Ridge. Rainfall was focused over western Franklin and eastern Floyd counties where rain gauges showed 3 to 4.5 inches in the 24-hour period ending at 0800 EDT on June 8th. The rain continued much of the 8th with an additional 2 to 4 inches across that same area. Embedded thunderstorms over eastern Patrick County dropped  2 to 5 inches in several hours in the early afternoon of the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were reported closed in the Callaway area of western Franklin County with water flowing across roadways. Callaway, Old Forge and Ferrum Mountain roads were all closed. A water rescue was made from a stranded vehicle along Callaway Road. Other roads closed several hours later included Madcap, Deyerle Knob and Hickman Roads. Low water bridges along Madcap Creek were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of heavy rainfall with embedded thunderstorms developed across the mountains of southwest Virginia dropping 2 to 3.5 inches in the heaviest bands over several hours on the afternoon of the 19th. Some flash flooding was reported in Pulaski and Galax. In Pulaski the COOP site (PSKV2) had a 24-hour total of 3.28 inches (ending at 700 AM on April 20th), most of which fell during a 6- to 10-hour period from late morning to early evening of the 19th. For this site was the highest on record for any April day with nearly complete precipitation records dating back to 1940 and 6th highest for any day. The old April record was 2.99 inches on April 26, 1978. For a 24-hour duration, the 3.28 inches falls in the 10-year (0.10 annual chance of occurrence) 90-percent confidence interval (3.25-3.75 inches), but it was a much more unusual event  for the shorter duration in which the rain actually occurred, approximately 9 hours according to a nearby automated rain gage. The COOP site at Galax, VA (GAXV2) had a 24-hour total of 2.47 inches ending at 700 AM on the 20th which was the 5th highest April 1-day rainfall on record at this site. A CoCoRaHS gage north of Galax (VA-CR-3) measured 3.30 inches for the same period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Railroad Avenue and Fair Street in Galax were closed with water flowing across the roadway.

Some flash flooding was reported in Pulaski and Galax. In Pulaski the COOP site (PSKV2) had a 24-hour total of 3.28 inches (ending at 700 AM on April 20th), most of which fell during a 6- to 10-hour period from late morning to early evening of the 19th. For this site was the highest on record for any April day with nearly complete precipitation records dating back to 1940 and 6th highest for any day. For a 24-hour duration, the 3.28 inches falls in the 10-year (0.10 annual chance of occurrence) 90-percent confidence interval (3.25-3.75 inches), but it was a much more unusual event  for the shorter duration in which the rain actually occurred, approximately 9 hours according to a nearby automated rain gage. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported 10 to 15 roads closed in and around the town of Pulaski and some flooding affecting businesses in the town. Some of the flooding was urban-type and some directly from Peak Creek. The IFLOWS gage along Peak Creek (PCRV2) rose rapidly and crested in about a 5-hour period at 8.30 feet, slightly above the Minor flood stage of 8 feet. Photos showed Peak Creek flooding several roads in the area including portions of Dora Highway and Crescent Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary boundary set up near the Potomac River weak low pressure developed along the boundary. There was plenty of moisture in place from the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico, and this combined with instability to produce very heavy rainfall rates in convection that developed. Convection was maximized around the boundary across northern Virginia near the Potomac River, and this led to several instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level at the New Alexandria stormwater pump station rapidly rose above flood stage of 5.5 feet, cresting at 7.51 feet at 9:15 AM EST, July 8th. This caused widespread street and yard flooding below the pump station, and at least a couple structures were impacted below I Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved into the area on the 11th, and out ahead of the boundary there was a warm and very humid airmass. The warm and humid airmass caused an unstable atmosphere which led to the development of showers and thunderstorms. Storms produced heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level at the New Alexandria stormwater pump station rapidly rose above flood stage of 5.5 feet, cresting at 5.7 feet at 5:13 PM EST on July 11th. Water spilled over near the pump house, flooding the adjacent parking lot.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lawyers Road was closed due to flooding near the intersection with Helmwood Court and it was also closed between Hunters Mill Road and Lydia Place.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water of 2 to 3 feet in depth was reported flowing across portions of Volney Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak surface boundary ahead of an approaching cold front spawned one severe thunderstorm causing tree damage in Charlotte County. Several other scattered thunderstorms developed across the Piedmont region, resulting in pockets of 2 to localized 4 inch amounts per radar estimates.  The intense rainfall over short durations resulted some brief flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mayflower Drive was reported to be flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Training of thunderstorms produced 4 to locally 6 inches of rain over a short period of time during the evening of July 15th along a portion of Little Back Creek and a few of its associated tributaries in extreme western Bath County, VA.  This resulted in flooding across both Little Back Creek Road and Mountain Valley Road around where they intersect one another, temporarily closing both roads.  The annual recurrence interval for the rainfall from this event was estimated by radar to be at least a 200-year (.005 annual exceedance probability) over a 3-hour duration.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A social media report stated that water was flowing over Route 39 and Route 601 from Big Turn Run and Little Back Creek. Sapling Woods Hollow, a small tributary of Little Back Creek also flooded a portion of Route 39.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms associated with a trough of low pressure produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Driver had to be rescued at Hermitage Road and West Laburnum Avenue due to driving into high water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rescues were reported at Bainbridge Street and West 20th Street. Flash flooding also resulted in road closures in downtown Richmond near the University of Richmond.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Oxford Street and Newport Avenue were impassible due to high water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roadway was impassible due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported along Chesapeake Boulevard, Johnstons Road, and Auburn Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported at the intersection of 26th and 27th Streets, and Granby Street and Colonial Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving upper level trough moving through the area, combined with weak steering flow aloft, and ample heat and humidity allowed for numerous slow-moving severe thunderstorms to develop across Virginia, bringing large and damaging hail and severe wind gusts. A barn was destroyed by severe wind, lightning caused an apartment fire and hail up to two inches in diameter fell in Roanoke City resulted in thousands of dollars in damage across Virginia. In addition, very heavy rainfall occurred especially in parts of northeast Bedford County and the City of Lynchburg where 3 to 4 inches of rain fell in several hours causing some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of flash flooding around Lynchburg as 3 to 4 inches of rain fell in a few hours during the late evening. A tributary of Blackwater creek flooded a portion of Greenwood Drive, near Sandusky Drive and a tributary to Tomahawk Creek flooded, but did not affect any homes. A culvert under a portion of Lake Vista Drive in Forest collapsed due to the heavy runoff and was repaired by VDOT.  Vehicles were reported to be stuck in water at 1200 Wythe Road and in the 3900 block of Old Forest Rd.  Several other roads were reported to have flooded including Fort Avenue Drive and McConville Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked along a stalled boundary, passing through the area overnight on the 4th into the 5th. The lift associated with the low and the boundary combined with high amounts of moisture from the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico, bringing heavy rain to the area. The rain led to several instances of flooding and even an isolated incident of flash flooding over Prince William County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Lake Drive and Leland Road was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked along a stalled boundary, passing through the area overnight on the 4th into the 5th. The lift associated with the low and the boundary combined with high amounts of moisture from the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico, bringing heavy rain to the area. The rain led to several instances of flooding and even an isolated incident of flash flooding over Prince William County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream gauge on the Broad Run at Bristow rapidly exceeded the 9.5 foot flood stage during the indicated period. Piper Lane flooded near Manassas Airport and trails along the stream were also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of low pressure and its associated cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Virginia Department of Transportation reported standing water at Mile Marker 81 along Interstate 95.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of low pressure and its associated cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was covering Interstate 95 at Interstate 64, in the Shockoe Valley Bridge area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms developed over southwest Virginia during the afternoon within a warm and humid air mass ahead of an advancing short-wave trough.  The storms produced hail up to the size of quarters, damaging winds that blew down several trees, and lightning that set a house on fire and destroyed a transformer. Locally heavy rainfall of 3 to 4 inches in a few hours was also observed during the late afternoon along and near the Blue Ridge in parts of Franklin, Bedford and Botetourt counties causing some flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads became impassable due to runoff from heavy rainfall, including a portion of Route 40 and along Hopkins Road where a car was stranded in the water. Two people were rescued by local Fire/EMS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms developed over southwest Virginia during the afternoon within a warm and humid air mass ahead of an advancing short-wave trough.  The storms produced hail up to the size of quarters, damaging winds that blew down several trees, and lightning that set a house on fire and destroyed a transformer. Locally heavy rainfall of 3 to 4 inches in a few hours was also observed during the late afternoon along and near the Blue Ridge in parts of Franklin, Bedford and Botetourt counties causing some flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains produced flooding with water reported flowing over a bridge and some damage to the road occurred at Sheep Creek Road and Jay Bird Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms associated with a trough of low pressure produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Total rainfall of 3.38 inches was reported, with 3.00 inches of rain reported in one hour. Several roads were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The center of Tropical Storm Isaias tracked north just inland of the Middle Atlantic Coast late Monday night, August 3rd through Tuesday morning, August 4th. The Tropical Storm produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was flowing over Coxendale Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper-level trough moved slowly across the central and eastern U.S. drawing abundant moisture northward. At the same time, a complex frontal boundary with several waves of low pressure brought repeated rounds of heavy rainfall to the region. Rainfall totals for the 72-hour period ending at 700 AM on February 7th ranged from 2 to 6 inches with isolated higher amounts mainly along the Blue Ridge Mountains, but most of the rain fell within a 48-hour period. Numerous NWS Cooperative stations recorded all time one-day February rainfall amounts ending on the morning of February 6th and/or the 7th, and numerous two-day February records were also set. Some flash flooding occurred early in the the event as higher rates of rainfall were embedded within the overall rain pattern. Numerous rivers and streams flooded, some reaching crests mainly in the 5- to 10-year flood recurrence interval and many roads were flooded. A state of emergency was declared by the Virginia Governor for several counties in southwest Virginia due to the flooding, including Tazewell and Smyth counties. Flooding was most severe along the Clinch River and tributaries in Richlands, VA where a Flash Flood Emergency was issued in consultation with local officials.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were reported to have been flooded due to the heavy rainfall and runoff.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding caused a sink hole to develop on Pisgah Church Road (Route 735) in Rice.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bridge on Scuffletown Road was washed out due to heavy rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon thunderstorms developed along the southwest Virginia Blue Ridge and drifted southward into the foothills and piedmont producing intense rainfall over fairly saturated ground and causing some significant flash flooding and debris flows in parts of Franklin, Floyd and Henry counties. Rainfall of 2 to 4 inches with isolated higher amounts occurred in a few hours, with the heaviest over northern Henry County. A state of Emergency was declared in Henry County due to the flooding. Flood damage estimates exceeded $1.1 million with eight homes and one business receiving major damage. The storms also reached severe levels in terms of wind with considerable damage reported, mainly across Henry County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported over western Franklin County in the Callaway area, around Daniels Run and the South Fork of the Blackwater River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms well in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Right lane of Interstate 64 East at Mile Marker 240 was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms well in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Merrimac Trail were impassible due to high water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several more roads were reported to be washed out including Sleeping Hill Farm Road and Machinery Drive. A roadway was flooded at the intersection of West Fayette Street and Appalachian Drive, possibly by flooding from the Smith River and flooding tore down a tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low became cut-off over the southern Appalachian region for several days leading to persistent rainfall and eventually some flooding. Four-day (96-hour) rainfall amounts ending at 800 AM EDT on May 22nd ranged from 3 to over 12 inches in the most favored locations. Some of the 11-inch+, 4-day rain totals in Roanoke County were within the 200-year recurrence interval (9.78 to 11.8 inches) per NOAA Atlas 14. The flooding that ensued was almost all in the form of river flooding that took several days to develop. Nearly every major river basin saw some flooding, but the most notable occurred in the New River basin where crests ranged from the 4th to 8th highest on record at the Virginia gaging stations along the river. Stages on the upper New were higher than in October 2018 when the remains of Hurricane Michael transited the region. The incredible rainfall, runoff and numerous debris flows produced widespread damage to roads in the region with VDOT reporting over $5 million in damages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lone Ivy Road was reported to be flooded. The Smith River near Woolwine gage (SMWV2) rose above Minor flood stage of 9 feet by 545 AM EST and crested at 9.75 feet at 845 AM EST. This was the 5th highest stage in the period of record at this gage with data back to 1995. According to USGS data this was just below a 10-year recurrence interval flood (0.1 annual chance of occurrence).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon thunderstorms developed along the southwest Virginia Blue Ridge and drifted southward into the foothills and piedmont producing intense rainfall over fairly saturated ground and causing some significant flash flooding and debris flows in parts of Franklin, Floyd and Henry counties. Rainfall of 2 to 4 inches with isolated higher amounts occurred in a few hours, with the heaviest over northern Henry County. A state of Emergency was declared in Henry County due to the flooding. Flood damage estimates exceeded $1.1 million with eight homes and one business receiving major damage. The storms also reached severe levels in terms of wind with considerable damage reported, mainly across Henry County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Smith River was reported to be completely flooding over River Road in Fieldale near Shadyview Road. The Smith River at Bassett (BASV2) stage was around 12 feet near the time of this report. The river crested at 13.35 feet (14400 cfs) around 822 EST per USGS statistics. No flood stage had been set at this gage mainly due to the flood control exercised by Philpott Dam. But the stage was the 2nd highest since dam began operation in 1952, after the flood in September, 1987 of 15.20 feet. It should be noted that Philpott Dam lost power earlier in the evening due to a mudslide and the dam operators were unable to reduce downstream flows to the normal extent.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of thunderstorms developed in the late evening hours of May 16th over parts of Bath County. These slow-moving storms dropped very heavy rain of 2 to 4 inches in just a few hours per radar estimates and rain gages. Some of the 1-hour rainfall amounts exceeded a 100-year recurrence interval (.01 annual chance of occurrence).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of downtown Hot Springs near the Bath House were flooded and parts of U.S. 220 flooded for several miles to the south, leaving the road impassable for a period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of thunderstorms developed in the late evening hours of May 16th over parts of Bath County. These slow-moving storms dropped very heavy rain of 2 to 4 inches in just a few hours per radar estimates and rain gages.
