EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mudslides and debris blocked portions of Highway 220 near Hot Springs closing the road for several miles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged convective event with deep moist southerly flow in an unstable environment with strong wind shear generated supercell thunderstorms across Southeast Tennessee and Southwest North Carolina. The lengthy period of heavy rain resulted in widespread three to four inch rainfall totals across East Tennessee, Southwest North Carolina, and Southwest Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads flooded across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front extending from a complex surface low pressure system, brought intense thunderstorms which produced damaging winds and very heavy rain on April 12-13.  The heavy rains resulted from a deep plume of tropical moisture lifted northward ahead of the cold front. Heavy rain began during the evening of April 12th and exited the region shortly after sunrise on the 13th, lasting roughly a 12-hour period. Between 1.5 and 4 inches of rain fell across the mountains and foothills, with isolated 5-inch amounts along the Blue Ridge.  The intense rainfall rates and rapid runoff caused widespread flash flooding of small creeks and streams. Virginia Department of Highways (VDOT) reported very significant damage to road infrastructure across numerous counties with damage totals exceeding $1.2 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car had to be towed out of floods water on Carver Road. Several other roads in the county were flooded, especially in the Bassett Forks area. VDOT reported damage to several of the flooded roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front extending from a complex surface low pressure system, brought intense thunderstorms which produced damaging winds and very heavy rain on April 12-13. The intense rainfall rates and rapid runoff caused widespread flash flooding of small creeks and streams. Virginia Department of Highways (VDOT) reported very significant damage to road infrastructure across numerous counties with damage totals exceeding $1.2 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 614 was flooded by Craig Creek with over six inches of water reported across the bridge. The IFLOWS stream gage at this location was out of service at the time, but the upstream IFLOWS gage on Craig Creek near Abbott (ABBV2) crested at 11.6 feet. This was over the flood stage of 10 feet and the 2nd highest (highest is 11.9 feet in Oct. 2018 with remains from Hurricane Michael) in a fairly short period of record (back to 2010). A water rescue was also preformed in the Abbott area, where a car drove into flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front extending from a complex surface low pressure system, brought intense thunderstorms which produced damaging winds and very heavy rain on April 12-13. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports of flash flooding from Brush Creek in the Pilot area were received and there was street flooding in urban areas of Christiansburg and Blacksburg. In addition, the South Fork of the Roanoke River at Shawsville (SHAV2) rose very rapidly to a crest of 6.83 feet (flood stage is 5 feet) at 725 AM EST. According to USGS data the peak discharge of 4550 cfs was somewhere between a 2- and 5-year flood (0.5 to 0.2 annual chance of occurrence). Several roads in the county sustained damage according to VDOT.

The USGS site at Kerrs Creek near Lexington (KCKV2) crested at 9.24 feet (3700 cfs) in the morning of the 13th. This was just below a 10-year flood event (0.1 annual chance of occurrence) per USGS data.

Virginia Department of Highways (VDOT) reported very significant damage to road infrastructure across numerous counties with damage totals exceeding $1.2 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The IFLOWS stream gage at Pulaski (PCRV2) rose from near baseflow to flood stage (8 feet) in less than 6 hours and crested at 11.4 feet around 730 AM EST on the 13th. Moderate flood stage is 11 feet. This was the highest crest in the fairly short and erratic history of this gage (back to around 2010), It exceeded the previous record of 11.2 feet set on March 13, 2010. Other small tributaries of Peak Creek flooded as well and local news reports spoke of the 'worst flooding in 40 years' with up to a dozen homes flooded into the living areas. Three water rescues were conducted as well around Pulaski.

The intersection was closed. Social media photos showed flooding on Franklin Road at Wonju Street. A mudslide at a car dealership caused two cars to slide into the resulting sinkhole with some damage to the vehicles.

Between 1.5 and 4 inches of rain fell across the mountains and foothills, with isolated 5-inch amounts along the Blue Ridge.  The intense rainfall rates and rapid runoff caused widespread flash flooding of small creeks and streams. Virginia Department of Highways (VDOT) reported very significant damage to road infrastructure across numerous counties with damage totals exceeding $1.2 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports from a local newspaper showed water over six inches deep flowing across a road along Sugar Run, which was heavily swollen with runoff from the heavy rain. Some damage occurred to roads along this stream.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front extending from a complex surface low pressure system, brought intense thunderstorms which produced damaging winds and very heavy rain on April 12-13.  The heavy rains resulted from a deep plume of tropical moisture lifted northward ahead of the cold front. Heavy rain began during the evening of April 12th and exited the region shortly after sunrise on the 13th, lasting roughly a 12-hour period. Between 1.5 and 4 inches of rain fell across the mountains and foothills, with isolated 5-inch amounts along the Blue Ridge.  The intense rainfall rates and rapid runoff caused widespread flash flooding of small creeks and streams. Virginia Department of Highways (VDOT) reported very significant damage to road infrastructure across numerous counties with damage totals exceeding $1.2 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Smith River near Woolwine gage (SMWV2) rose quickly in the early morning hours and exceeded the flood stage of 9 feet, cresting at 9.65 feet (2310 cfs) around 500 AM EST. This was the 5th highest crest on record at this gage with data back to 1995. According to USGS data this was approximately a 10-year flood event (0.10 annual chance of occurrence). There was some damage to roads in the county according to VDOT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front extending from a complex surface low pressure system, brought intense thunderstorms which produced damaging winds and very heavy rain on April 12-13. Heavy rain began during the evening of April 12th and exited the region shortly after sunrise on the 13th, lasting roughly a 12-hour period. Between 1.5 and 4 inches of rain fell across the mountains and foothills, with isolated 5-inch amounts along the Blue Ridge.  The intense rainfall rates and rapid runoff caused widespread flash flooding of small creeks and streams. Virginia Department of Highways (VDOT) reported very significant damage to road infrastructure across numerous counties with damage totals exceeding $1.2 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were reported to be flooded and blocked. These incuded Justus Mill Road, St. Peter Road, Cripple Creek Road and Hope Road. Millers Creek Road was damaged by flowing water from Miller Creek. Information on damage to roads and infrastructure provided by Virginia DOT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central and south central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wilkerson Road at Butcher Creek was reported impassible due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper-level trough moved slowly across the central and eastern U.S. drawing abundant moisture northward. At the same time, a complex frontal boundary with several waves of low pressure brought repeated rounds of heavy rainfall to the region. Rainfall totals for the 72-hour period ending at 700 AM on February 7th ranged from 2 to 6 inches with isolated higher amounts mainly along the Blue Ridge Mountains, but most of the rain fell within a 48-hour period. Numerous NWS Cooperative stations recorded all time one-day February rainfall amounts ending on the morning of February 6th and/or the 7th, and numerous two-day February records were also set. Some flash flooding occurred early in the the event as higher rates of rainfall were embedded within the overall rain pattern. Numerous rivers and streams flooded, some reaching crests mainly in the 5- to 10-year flood recurrence interval and many roads were flooded. A state of emergency was declared by the Virginia Governor for several counties in southwest Virginia due to the flooding, including Tazewell and Smyth counties. Flooding was most severe along the Clinch River and tributaries in Richlands, VA where a Flash Flood Emergency was issued in consultation with local officials.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous streets were flooded in Richlands due to urban runoff and and rapidly rising waters from the Clinch River and other streams especially Big Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets were flooded in the city of Norfolk.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southwest winds aloft were responsible for carrying deep tropical moisture across the Piedmont during the morning of the 21st, while northeasterly flow near the surface was in place due to high pressure wedged against the eastern face of the Appalachians. The high moisture content across the Piedmont, with a precipitable water value of 1.77 measured from the morning sounding at KGSO, as well as very light mean winds, set the stage for slow-moving, highly efficient rainfall. This would be over soils that, in many areas, were 50-75 percent saturated to start the day due to earlier rainfall events per FLASH estimates.||Regarding the event, a flash flood warning was initially issued at 8:27 am after portions of northwest Henry County and the City of Martinsville received between 1.5 and 2.5 inches of rainfall since around 6:00 am.  Training of storms producing heavy rain continued, and the warning was upgraded to a flash flood emergency at 10:15 am after reports were received of swift water rescues taking place and flood waters entering homes.  In response to the flooding, Henry County officials declared a local State of Emergency to allocate funding and resources to help with the resulting property damage.||Numerous roads were closed due to flooding and/or debris flows, including these listed below.  Flood waters were observed receding quickly by noon, with most roads that did not sustain damage or were blocked by debris opened by 3:00 pm.|* U.S. Route 220 South/Virginia Avenue from Mountain Top Court to Appalachian Drive/State Route 57 East and the ramp intersection due to flooding|* U.S. Route 220 North from Horsley Road/Virginia Avenue to Appalachian Drive/State Route 57 West due to flooding|* Route 665 East/West from dead end to Figsboro Road and State Route 108 due to downed tree|* State Route 174 East from State Route 108 to Beaver Hills Club Drive/Kings Mountain Road due to flooding|* State Route 174 West from FR-1008 to Jack Dalton Road/Route 1159 due to flooding|* Route 714 North/South from Kings Mountain Road/State Route 174 East to Figsboro Road/State Route 108 due to flooding|* Route 755 East/West from Fairystone Park Highway/State Route 57 to Alan Adale Drive/Fairystone Park Highway/State Route 57 due to flooding|* Route 703 North/South from Campbell Court/Fairystone Park Highway/Route 715/State Route 57 to Bassett Heights Road/Route 672 due to flooding|* Route 698 North/South from Jarrett Drive/Route 679 to John Henry Road/Out A Way Drive/Route 780 due to flooding|* Route 609 North/South from Artwood Drive/Wigginton Road/Route 1000 to Watson Drive/Route 943 due to flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from very 1.5 to 2 inches of rain within a 2-hour period caused Blackberry Creek to rise rapidly out of its banks and cause flooding on Blackberry Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding was observed in the Bassett and Stanleytown communities.  This includes flooding of Riverside Drive as Blackberry Creek rose out of its banks, as well as flooding at the intersection of Oakcrest Circle and Winnfield Road where a tributary of Little Reed Creek overflowed its banks.  Little Reed Creek also flooded out of its banks, overflowing onto Highway 220, including numerous businesses along the highway as far south as where the creek merges with Reed Creek and then empties into the Smith River.  There were reports that as many as 40 automobiles were trapped along Highway 220 by the flood, with a few occupants needing assistance to evacuate the vehicles.  Most people were able to leave the vehicles on their own.  Flood waters of Little Reed Creek were intense enough to damage the bridge that crosses the creek along Edgewood Drive. Portions of the Great Road were closed for several hours due to flooding, as was Daniels Creek Road near Reed Creek.  Numerous other roads and buildings were impacted as well to varying degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Radar precipitation estimates and personal mesonet stations indicate that between 1.75 and 2.5 inches of rain fell in the Chatmoss area, much of this rain falling in a 1-hour period across soils that were near saturation from recent rainfall.  These amounts were anywhere from an 8- to 15-year rainfall event per FLASH estimates.  Runoff from this rainfall caused flooding along Spruce Street, near Irisburg Road, making the road impassible until the floodwaters receded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms during the afternoon and evening of the 22nd developed in a typical summertime environment of deep southerly windflow, carrying tropical moisture across the mid-Atlantic (with daily precipitable water values ranging from 1.30 to 1.60 inches), while abundant sunshine each afternoon provided the instability (CAPE values 1500-2500 J/Kg each day). The results were spotty thunderstorms that were efficient in producing localized heavy rain, often over ground that was excessively moist from prior rainfall events.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms produced widespread 2 to 4 inch rainfall amounts across central Rockbridge County, more than double the 1-hour flash flood guidance in this area given moist soil conditions. Much of this rainfall fell in a 2-hour period, which equated to around a 100-year rainfall event for areas just west of the Kerrs Creek community.  Multiple roads were closed due to flooding of Kerrs Creek, including Big Spring Drive, West Midland Trail at Fredericksburg Road, and Muddy Lake at West Midland Trail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving storms developed along a pressure trough in central Virginia, resulting in instances of flooding and flash floodint.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mudslide occurred due to heavy rainfall around the 2500 Block of Spring Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed, and with little steering flow aloft this caused the storm motion to be slow. The slow storm motion resulted in instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The road was closed due to a sinkhole at the Intersection of Moseby Court and Moseby Drive.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level along the South Fork Quantico Creek rapidly rose above flood state of 9 feet, cresting at 12.04 feet at 9:30 AM EST on August 13th. The water level remained above flood stage until 11:30 AM EST on the 13th. Joplin Road was covered by water around the bridge and a few feet of water were flowing over the road nearby.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level shortwave moved across the central Appalachians from the 6th to the 7th. Showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening of the 6th, and lingered into the night. Heavy rain fell in portions of southwestern Virginia just after midnight, with 2-3 inches of rain falling over several hours. An automated rain gauge at the Buchanan County Airport near Vansant measured 2.25 inches of rain. This led to isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Looney Fork flooded, closing a section of State Route 612.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving scattered showers and thunderstorms prospered across portions of southwest Virginia during the early evening hours on the 20th. This resulted in multiple high water issues near the Clintwood area of Dickenson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall across the Clintwood area resulted in multiple roadways to be inundated with water. These included Camp Creek Road, Brush Creek Road, Main Street, and Route 631.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple rounds of rainfall on the 31st were the result of a weak disturbance passing through in the morning, followed by a warm front pressing northward through southwest Virginia that evening. Showers and thunderstorms associated with the warm front caused impassable roadways across several towns in Buchanan County. A weather station in the town of Stacy reported over three inches of rain had fallen within a two hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple areas across Buchanan experienced impassable roadways due to high water issues. Looney Creek rose out of its banks near the town of Artia, which resulted in flooding along Route 656. Near Big Rock, several sections of Route 460 were closed due to high water along the road. Around the town of Grundy, both 6 and 20 Mile Branch Road and Slate Creek Road observed water along the road due to adjacent creeks rising out of their banks. Other roads that experienced impassable roadways were Poplar Creek Road in Pearly, Elkins Branch Road near Home Creek, and Convict Hollow Road near the town of Longbottom. Route 690 N near Whitewood was closed for a time due to high water along the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and storms developed along around a nearly stationary boundary, and this led to instances of flooding and flash flooding due to the slow storm movement.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The road was closed at Route 7 near Hamilton Station Road due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Plenty of moisture from the Gulf of Mexico combined with a boundary to trigger showers and thunderstorms. A light flow aloft that was nearly unidirectional caused some showers and thunderstorms to train over the same areas, which led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The South Fork Back Creek was out of its banks with six to ten inches of water rushing across VA-814 Love Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few storms led to isolated instances of flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of flowing water over Brock Rd. at the intersection with Jeans Dr.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and storms developed along around a nearly stationary boundary, and this led to instances of flooding and flash flooding due to the slow storm movement.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level at Limestone Branch rapidly rose above the flood stage of 7 feet, cresting at 10.26 feet at 10:20 PM EST, August 6th. Water entered entered homes near the stream and Route 15 was flooded at Limestown Branch in between Leesburg and Lucketts. The water remained above flood stage until 12:04 AM EST on August 7th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Plenty of moisture from the Gulf of Mexico combined with a boundary to trigger showers and thunderstorms. A light flow aloft that was nearly unidirectional caused some showers and thunderstorms to train over the same areas, which led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were reports of Rockslides due to heavy rainfall near Wintergreen.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms associated with low pressure and a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central and southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mount Hermon Road near County Line Road was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and storms developed along around a nearly stationary boundary, and this led to instances of flooding and flash flooding due to the slow storm movement.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level rapidly rose above the flood state of 8 feet, cresting at 11.11 feet at 12:25 AM EST on August 7th. Portions of Route 662 were flooded and water approached a building on Main Street in Waterford. The water level remained above flood stage until 5:41 AM EST on August 7th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the most significant flooding events in years occurred during November 11th and 12th, given both the amounts of rainfall and the footprint where flooding occurred.  In the wake of high pressure passing east off the mid-Atlantic coast, a plume of deep tropical moisture was rapidly carried inland to the central Appalachians ahead of a slow-moving cold front.  Though this plume was of tropical origin, it was not directly related to Tropical Storm Eta, which was off the coast of southern Florida.  Precipitable Water values were in the extremely high range of 1.9 to 2.2 inches with this airmass, around the 99th percentile for mid-November.  In addition, evapotranspiration was significantly lower than during the previous few months given lower daytime heating and the fact that most vegetation had become dormant for the upcoming winter months.  Despite dry conditions for almost two weeks leading up to the event, numerous instances of flooding and flash flooding occurred as 4 to 6 inches of rain fell across portions of the Piedmont on the 11th, followed by an additional 1 to 3 inches on the 12th.  Some of the activity was convective in nature, producing locally 2 to 4 inch per hour rainfall rates.  The rainfall produces numerous instances of flooding and flash flooding, followed shortly by river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: After 2 to 3 inches of rain fell across Appomattox county during the morning, an additional 1.75 to 2.25 inches of rain fell during the evening, most of it within a hour, as a line of slow-moving thunderstorms passed across the area.  This caused numerous creeks, already running high from the earlier rainfall, to flood out of their banks.  Notable among the flood reports was water about one foot deep running across Horseshoe Road. At least five water rescues were performed by emergency personnel, including one at North Creek Road where North Creek was observed flooding the roadway, and another at River Ridge Road at the Appomattox River.  Additional rounds of rain of weaker intensity persisted through the late evening hours, maintaining the flooding conditions, though flash flooding ended by 11:00 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep tropical moisture, ushered into our area by a southwesterly low level jet, overran easterly wind flow associated with high pressure wedging near the surface. Precipitable water values per the RNK/GSO 31/12Z soundings were 1.64/2.04 respectively.  Despite abundant moisture, instability remained strictly limited, preventing high rainfall rates from occurring.  As such, widespread 1 to 3 inch rainfall amounts were observed, but most of which fell over a 4 to 8 hour period of time under rainfall rates averaging 0.1 to 0.3 inches per hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Patrick County 911 Center reported that Commerce Street in the Town of Stuart is closed off due to Campbell Branch overflowing its banks several inches deep across the roadway.  A personal mesonet station in Stuart recorded roughly 1.8 inches of rainfall between 1130 am and 1230 pm EDT, between a 2- and a 5-year rainfall event per NOAA Atlas-14 point frequency estimates, though soils were becoming saturated from rainfall earlier in the day before this convective band moved through.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the most significant flooding events in years occurred during November 11th and 12th, given both the amounts of rainfall and the footprint where flooding occurred.  In the wake of high pressure passing east off the mid-Atlantic coast, a plume of deep tropical moisture was rapidly carried inland to the central Appalachians ahead of a slow-moving cold front.  Though this plume was of tropical origin, it was not directly related to Tropical Storm Eta, which was off the coast of southern Florida.  Precipitable Water values were in the extremely high range of 1.9 to 2.2 inches with this airmass, around the 99th percentile for mid-November.  In addition, evapotranspiration was significantly lower than during the previous few months given lower daytime heating and the fact that most vegetation had become dormant for the upcoming winter months.  Despite dry conditions for almost two weeks leading up to the event, numerous instances of flooding and flash flooding occurred as 4 to 6 inches of rain fell across portions of the Piedmont on the 11th, followed by an additional 1 to 3 inches on the 12th.  Some of the activity was convective in nature, producing locally 2 to 4 inch per hour rainfall rates.  The rainfall produces numerous instances of flooding and flash flooding, followed shortly by river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from 1 to 1.5 inches of rain in about a one-hour time period caused flooding several inches deep to flow across the intersection of Wilkerson Road and Kentuck Road. The road was reported impassible until after the water receded.

In the wake of high pressure passing east off the mid-Atlantic coast, a plume of deep tropical moisture was rapidly carried inland to the central Appalachians ahead of a slow-moving cold front.  Though this plume was of tropical origin, it was not directly related to Tropical Storm Eta, which was off the coast of southern Florida.  Precipitable Water values were in the extremely high range of 1.9 to 2.2 inches with this airmass, around the 99th percentile for mid-November.  In addition, evapotranspiration was significantly lower than during the previous few months given lower daytime heating and the fact that most vegetation had become dormant for the upcoming winter months.  Despite dry conditions for almost two weeks leading up to the event, numerous instances of flooding and flash flooding occurred as 4 to 6 inches of rain fell across portions of the Piedmont on the 11th, followed by an additional 1 to 3 inches on the 12th.  Some of the activity was convective in nature, producing locally 2 to 4 inch per hour rainfall rates.  The rainfall produces numerous instances of flooding and flash flooding, followed shortly by river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: After 2 to 2.5 inches of rain fell during the morning across much of Buckingham County, a  band of slow-moving thunderstorms moved across the county during the evening.  Runoff from this heavy rain caused water to flow across the road near the intersection of Howardsville Road and Watoga Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front, draped across the foothills and Piedmont and supported aloft by multiple waves of energy entering from the Tennessee Valley, provided the triggers for  scattered slow-moving thunderstorms to develop during the afternoon across the mountains and foothills.  Strong daytime heating provided the instability to allow some storms to intensify to severe levels, producing damaging winds and hail.  In addition, deep tropical moisture in place in the wake of Tropical Storm Isaias allowed some storms to produce heavy rain, with 2-4 inch per hour rainfall rates at times.  Light winds aloft made for slow storm movement, allowing storms to remain over the same locations for extended periods of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff due to a thunderstorm producing heavy rain caused flooding along the Christiansburg Pike, temporarily making the road impassible. A landslide occurred from a roadside hill onto the pike, blocking the road. Radar rainfall estimates indicate that 2 to possibly 3 inches fell in the nearby area where the flooding and the landslide occurred.

Precipitable Water values were in the extremely high range of 1.9 to 2.2 inches with this airmass, around the 99th percentile for mid-November. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the most significant flooding events in years occurred during November 11th and 12th, given both the amounts of rainfall and the footprint where flooding occurred.  In the wake of high pressure passing east off the mid-Atlantic coast, a plume of deep tropical moisture was rapidly carried inland to the central Appalachians ahead of a slow-moving cold front.  Though this plume was of tropical origin, it was not directly related to Tropical Storm Eta, which was off the coast of southern Florida.  Precipitable Water values were in the extremely high range of 1.9 to 2.2 inches with this airmass, around the 99th percentile for mid-November.  In addition, evapotranspiration was significantly lower than during the previous few months given lower daytime heating and the fact that most vegetation had become dormant for the upcoming winter months.  Despite dry conditions for almost two weeks leading up to the event, numerous instances of flooding and flash flooding occurred as 4 to 6 inches of rain fell across portions of the Piedmont on the 11th, followed by an additional 1 to 3 inches on the 12th.  Some of the activity was convective in nature, producing locally 2 to 4 inch per hour rainfall rates.  The rainfall produces numerous instances of flooding and flash flooding, followed shortly by river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: With 1.5 to 2 inches of rain having already fallen earlier in the day, a band of fast-moving thunderstorms producing heavy rain moved across the community of Blacksburg.  Between 7:00 pm and 7:40 pm, a weather station in Blacksburg recorded about 1.25 inches of rain with this band.  Runoff from the rainfall push Stroubles Creek out of its banks near the Duck Pond on the Virginia Tech University campus, flooding Duck Pond Drive.  The road was impassible for several hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture returned to the lower mid-Atlantic region during the period August 12th - 15th, with precipitable water values ranging from 1.6 to 1.9 inches each day.  A frontal boundary stalled near the Interstate 64 corridor provided a trigger for convection, supported aloft by passing upper level disturbances. Strong daytime heating contributed to deep instability, resulting in thunderstorms with high rainfall rates.  Light winds aloft resulted in mean wind speeds generally 10 knots or less, indicating slow cell movement.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms produced 1.5 to 2 inches of rain within about an hour across the town of Tazewell. FLASH data indicates this amount to be 1.5 to 1.7 times greater than 1-hour flash flood guidance for this area. CREST unit streamflow for this event was 550 cfs/mi^2, while the 1-hour average return interval was around a 25-year event. Runoff from this rainfall caused flooding of several roads in the vicinity of Dogwood Road and Steeles Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough between an approaching cold front from the west and a tropical disturbance offshore resulted in a band of heavy showers and thunderstorms along the I-95 corridor on the afternoon/evening of 9/10, resulting in multiple instances flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One foot of water was flowing across East Maple Street near Little Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture returned to the lower mid-Atlantic region during the period August 12th - 15th, with precipitable water values ranging from 1.6 to 1.9 inches each day.  A frontal boundary stalled near the Interstate 64 corridor provided a trigger for convection, supported aloft by passing upper level disturbances. Strong daytime heating contributed to deep instability, resulting in thunderstorms with high rainfall rates.  Light winds aloft resulted in mean wind speeds generally 10 knots or less, indicating slow cell movement.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms produced 1.5 to 2 inches of rain within about an hour in an urbanized/highly developed area within the town of Claymont Hill. FLASH data indicates this amount to be 1.5 to 1.7 times greater than 1-hour flash flood guidance for this area. CREST unit streamflow for this event was 600-650 cfs/mi^2, while the 1-hour average return interval was around a 25-year event. Runoff from this rainfall caused flooding of roads around the Claymont Hill Mall, which were closed off until the flooding receded.  Water from the area around the mall then channeled along an unnamed creek running north adjacent to Highway 460, where flooding occurred near the Bandy Auto Care Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture returned to the lower mid-Atlantic region during the period August 12th - 15th, with precipitable water values ranging from 1.6 to 1.9 inches each day.  A frontal boundary stalled near the Interstate 64 corridor provided a trigger for convection, supported aloft by passing upper level disturbances. Strong daytime heating contributed to deep instability, resulting in thunderstorms with high rainfall rates.  Light winds aloft resulted in mean wind speeds generally 10 knots or less, indicating slow cell movement.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to three inches of rain fell across portions of Christiansburg during a roughly 2-hour period, which was between a 5- and 10-year event per NOAA Atlas 14 point frequency estimates.  Runoff from this rainfall caused a roadside ditch running along Phlegar Street to overflow onto the road an estimated couple feet deep between 2nd and 3rd Streets.  2nd Street was also observed to be under water and impassible.  In addition, water several inches deep was observed flowing across nearby Radford Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the most significant flooding events in years occurred during November 11th and 12th, given both the amounts of rainfall and the footprint where flooding occurred.  In the wake of high pressure passing east off the mid-Atlantic coast, a plume of deep tropical moisture was rapidly carried inland to the central Appalachians ahead of a slow-moving cold front.  Though this plume was of tropical origin, it was not directly related to Tropical Storm Eta, which was off the coast of southern Florida.  Precipitable Water values were in the extremely high range of 1.9 to 2.2 inches with this airmass, around the 99th percentile for mid-November.  In addition, evapotranspiration was significantly lower than during the previous few months given lower daytime heating and the fact that most vegetation had become dormant for the upcoming winter months.  Despite dry conditions for almost two weeks leading up to the event, numerous instances of flooding and flash flooding occurred as 4 to 6 inches of rain fell across portions of the Piedmont on the 11th, followed by an additional 1 to 3 inches on the 12th.  Some of the activity was convective in nature, producing locally 2 to 4 inch per hour rainfall rates.  The rainfall produces numerous instances of flooding and flash flooding, followed shortly by river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: With about 2 inches of rain having already fallen earlier in the day across the Jacobs Creek watershed, a band of thunderstorms passed across the area during the evening.  Multiple personal weather stations observed 1.25 to 1.5 inches of rain during a 45-minute period between 6:30 pm and 7:15 pm, falling over saturated soils.  Runoff from this rain pushed Jacobs Creek out of its banks, which was then observed flowing across Red House Road. The road was impassible until the flood waters receded.  An automobile became stranded in the floodwaters and had to be towed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Zeta passed quickly across the lower mid-Atlantic region on the morning of the 29th, but still brought 2-3 inches of rainfall to the foothills of the Blue Ridge and the Piedmont region.  Much of this rain fell within a 1-2 hour period, resulting in rapid flooding of several small streams.  Residual moisture in the wake of Zeta allowed for redevelopment of bands of slow-moving storms producing additional heavy rain, which also resulted in localized flooding across the Piedmont of Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Training thunderstorms formed along a boundary left in the wake of Tropical Storm Zeta, producing 2.5-4 inches of rain in a three to four hour period.  Rainfall rates were observed to be one to two inches per hour.  The Campbell County 911 Center reported that at least seven roads within the central part of the county were flooded and impassable.  This included Yellow Branch rising out of its banks near the intersection of Morman Mill Road and Patterson Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Zeta passed quickly across the lower mid-Atlantic region on the morning of the 29th, but still brought 2-3 inches of rainfall to the foothills of the Blue Ridge and the Piedmont region.  Much of this rain fell within a 1-2 hour period, resulting in rapid flooding of several small streams.  Residual moisture in the wake of Zeta allowed for redevelopment of bands of slow-moving storms producing additional heavy rain, which also resulted in localized flooding across the Piedmont of Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tributary of Daniels Creek overflowed its banks and flooded onto Oakland Drive, making it impassible until the water receded.  The flooding was the result of up to two inches of rain inside a two hour window, with one to 1.5 inch per hour rainfall rates per nearby personal weather station observations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Zeta passed quickly across the lower mid-Atlantic region on the morning of the 29th, but still brought 2-3 inches of rainfall to the foothills of the Blue Ridge and the Piedmont region.  Much of this rain fell within a 1-2 hour period, resulting in rapid flooding of several small streams.  Residual moisture in the wake of Zeta allowed for redevelopment of bands of slow-moving storms producing additional heavy rain, which also resulted in localized flooding across the Piedmont of Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple weather stations in the southeastern portion of Franklin County recorded between two to locally 3.5 inches of rainfall inside a three hour period during the passage of Tropical Storm Zeta.  Rainfall rates of one to two inches per hour were observed in some locations.  This rain caused multiple streams to flood out of their banks onto nearby roadways in the Snow Creek area, making them impassible until the water receded.  This includes Muddy Fork Road flooded by Reed Creek and Sutton Hollow Road closed due to flooding of Crawford Creek and Snow Creek. Fawndale Road and portions of the Virgil Goode Highway were also reported flooded and impassible for a few hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad closed upper low drifted across South Carolina and northwest back into southwest Virginia and West Virginia bringing persistent rainfall that eventually led to flooding. There were repeated rounds of heavy rainfall with widespread amounts of 2 to 5 inches, with isolated totals over 10 inches in a 3-day period in parts of Halifax County, VA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Walnut Avenue near Glade Creek was closed due to water flowing over it. Flooding also occurred along Tinker Creek where the USGS gage near the confluence of Glade Creek crested at 16.96 feet in the afternoon of the 17th. No flood stage has been set at this relatively new gaging station, but Tinker Creek overflows the low-water bridge on Wise Avenue at a stage of around 7 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving afternoon thunderstorms produced some flash flooding and debris flows in Tazewell and Smyth counties. Radar-estimated rainfall of 2 to 4 inches in less than 3 hours occurred near and south of Tannersville in Tazewell County and in far northern Smyth County near Broadford.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several debris flows and roads flooded and  closed by the runoff from intense rainfall.  A road near Broadford in the northwest part of the county was flooded and covered with debris and rocks, requiring several hours of cleanup. Virginia Highway 42, Blue Grass Trail, was also flooded and closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Zeta passed quickly across the lower mid-Atlantic region on the morning of the 29th, but still brought 2-3 inches of rainfall to the foothills of the Blue Ridge and the Piedmont region.  Much of this rain fell within a 1-2 hour period, resulting in rapid flooding of several small streams.  Residual moisture in the wake of Zeta allowed for redevelopment of bands of slow-moving storms producing additional heavy rain, which also resulted in localized flooding across the Piedmont of Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple weather stations in the vicinity of the Blue Ridge in Carroll County indicate that between 1.5 and 2.5 inches of rain fell inside a two-hour period during the passage of Tropical Storm Zeta at rates of one to two inches per hour in spots.  This rain caused multiple streams to flood out of their banks onto nearby roadways, making them impassible until the water receded, including across Spring Bud Road and Route 52 as Paul's Creek rose out of its banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Zeta passed quickly across the lower mid-Atlantic region on the morning of the 29th, but still brought 2-3 inches of rainfall to the foothills of the Blue Ridge and the Piedmont region. Residual moisture in the wake of Zeta allowed for redevelopment of bands of slow-moving storms producing additional heavy rain, which also resulted in localized flooding across the Piedmont of Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple data sources across all of Patrick County, including trained spotters and personal automated weather stations, indicate that between two and locally three inches of rain fell during a two-hour period during the passage of Tropical Storm Zeta from roughly 9 am to 11 am EDT.  Rainfall rates were observed at one to two inches per hour in spots.  This rain caused multiple streams to flood out of their banks onto nearby roadways, some up to 12 inches deep in the vicinity of Buffalo Creek, making them impassible until the water receded.  This included Egg Farm Road where it intersected Grassy Branch Creek, as water was estimated to be at least eight inches deep over the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with large hail spread northward across East Tennessee during the early morning hours of March 27, reaching southwest Virginia by late morning. These storms were associated with a warm front, which later stalled across northeast Tennessee. This stalled front was the focus of additional thunderstorms that produced damaging winds and  flooding in the evening of March 27 and into March 28.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding of roadways caused vehicles to become stranded. Road closures. Highway 421 near Pennington Gap was impassable. Reports of structures being flooded in Pennington Gap. A 24 hour rainfall measurement of 4.37 inches at Jonesville at 8:00 AM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple waves of energy passing along a stalled frontal boundary near the Ohio River resulted in several rounds of prolonged and, at times, heavy rain across the northern half of Bath County.  In the 48 hour period ending 10 am on the 28th, the northern half of Bath County had already received between 2 to locally 3.25 inches of rainfall from shower and thunderstorm activity. Snow pack prior to the arrival of the rainfall was confined to the highest ridge tops, where locally up to 4 inches was on the ground.  By the morning of the 28th, soils were almost completely saturated, resulting in efficient runoff of rainfall from showers and thunderstorms that would occur during the evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: After at least 3 inches of rain had already fall in the upper reaches of Back Creek during the previous day, resulting in saturated soil conditions, heavy rain from a line of thunderstorms caused Back Creek to rise quickly to a stage of 8.87 feet per the USGS stream gauge near Sunrise. This rise caused Back Creek to rapidly flood across Virginia Route 39, closing the road until the flood waters receded. Key Impacts: flooded & impassible roadway; transportation delays.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front triggered showers and scattered thunderstorms. Locally heavy rain from thunderstorms led to isolated instances of flooding and flash flooding in the northern Shenandoah Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The gauge at New Market along the Smith Creek rose above flood stage of 8 feet, cresting at 9.45 feet at 8 PM EST. The water level fell below flood stage at 10:23 PM EST on the 24th. Mount Airy Lane was flooded and Route 826 was also flooded. Agricultural flooding also took place near Smith Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a trough of low pressure produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reporting sites showed 2.0 to 2.5 inches of rain fell in 45 minutes. Standing water was reported on several roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front dropped into the area from the northeast. The airmass was very warm and humid ahead of the boundary, and that led to the development of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rainfall. The storm motion was slow due to light winds aloft, so the heavy rain led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were over a dozen calls for roads closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central and eastern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were flooded near Isle of Wight and Central Hill. Some roads were closed in the area due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms trained across southern Highland County, forming in an environment of CAPE exceeding 2,500 J/Kg and Precipitable Water of around 1.5 inches.  The storms produced 2.5 to 4 inches of rainfall amounts over a 2 to 3-hour period, with rainfall rates at times reaching 5 to 6 inches per hour.  Steep terrain in the Back Creek basin aided in creating efficient runoff to cause the stream gauge at Back Creek at Sunrise to rise to 10.01 feet, exceeding Moderate Flood Stage set at 10 feet.  This is the highest this gauge has risen since 2008.  FLASH estimated that rainfall just upstream from the stream gauge was over 3 times greater than 1-hour Flash Flood Guidance.  CREST Unit Streamflow was estimating over 1,000 cfs per square mile, whiile CREST 1-hour Average Return Interval estimates put this rainfall at well over a 200-year event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from a thunderstorm caused Indian Run to flood out of its banks and flow across Fontella Road, causing the road to become impassible.  The road was reopened after the flood waters receded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across the lower Mid-Atlantic during the afternoon and evening of June 10th, forming in an environment of strong afternoon heating in a moist atmosphere.  Storm Prediction Center Mesoanalysis indicated surface-based CAPE values as high as 2500 J/Kg at the onset of thunderstorm activity, while Precipitable Water values in the area were about 2.0 inches.  Nearby rain gauges indicated about 2.3 inches of rain fell in a 60-minute period, which is roughly a 10-year event per NOAA Atlas 14 Point Precipitation Estimates.  Rainfall rates at times were recorded reaching in excess of 4 inches per hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of heavy rain and poor drainage resulted in flash flooding in the community of Appomattox, especially along Confederate Avenue where runoff became over 3 feet deep, with one witness observing water rising up to the hood of a stranded vehicle.  Nearby automated personal weather stations indicated about 1.5 inches of rain fell within a 30 to 40 minute period, with rainfall rates as high as 4 inches per hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms associated with tropical cyclone Claudette produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Right lane on east bound Interstate 64 was closed due to flooding at Mile Marker 297 (Yadkin Road).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front dropped into the area from the northeast. The airmass was very warm and humid ahead of the boundary, and that led to the development of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rainfall. The storm motion was slow due to light winds aloft, so the heavy rain led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Turkey Ridge Road around VA-650 was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front dropped into the area from the northeast. The airmass was very warm and humid ahead of the boundary, and that led to the development of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rainfall. The storm motion was slow due to light winds aloft, so the heavy rain led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Old Stillhouse Road around VA-635 was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front passed through the area during the afternoon of the 14th into the evening and overnight hours. Ahead of the cold front, there was plenty of instability and moisture, so thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall. This led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Accotink Creek at Strathmeade Springs rapidly passed minor flood stage, cresting at 254.08 feet at 1:00 AM EST. The water level fell below flood stage at 2:41 AM EST. |Both Woodburn Road and Prosperity Avenue were flooded by at least six inches of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front passed through the area during the afternoon of the 14th into the evening and overnight hours. Ahead of the cold front, there was plenty of instability and moisture, so thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall. This led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream at Difficult Run surpassed minor flood stage, cresting at 195.74 feet at 3:50 AM EST. The water level fell below flood stage at 5:47 AM EST.  Six inches of water covered the area around its lowest point.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large thunderstorm complex moved east from the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys across southwest Virginia. The system caused dozens of trees to be toppled across the region.  Heavy rainfall from these storms also caused localized flooding in the City of Roanoke, where rainfall rates were in excess of 4 inches per hour at one point, between a 5-year and 10-year rainfall event per NOAA Atlas 14 Point Frequency Estimates.  Rainfall amounts across the City of Roanoke ranged from 1.50 to 1.75 inches, not unusual for thunderstorm activity, but still enough to cause localized flooding given the more urbanized nature of the impacted area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain amounts between 1.5 and 1.75 inches fell from a thunderstorm within a 45 minute period across portions of the downtown area in the City of Roanoke.  Runoff from this rainfall resulted in about three feet of standing water near the intersection of Salem Avenue and 1 1/2 Street.  At least one car became stranded in the flood waters, though it is unknown if the occupant(s) required rescue.  The road was reopened to traffic  after the flood waters receded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a warm front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding and flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Battlefield Boulevard was impassable due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A light flow aloft along with an unstable atmosphere led to slow moving showers and thunderstorms. Heavy amounts of rain led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Holmes Run was out of its banks and flowing onto nearby trails and roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A light flow aloft along with an unstable atmosphere led to slow moving showers and thunderstorms. Heavy amounts of rain led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was blocking several lanes of the George Washington Parkway between Slaters Lane and Bashford Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow-moving thunderstorms trained across southern Highland County, forming in an environment of CAPE exceeding 2,500 J/Kg and Precipitable Water of around 1.5 inches.  The storms produced 2.5 to 4 inches of rainfall amounts over a 2 to 3-hour period, with rainfall rates at times reaching 5 to 6 inches per hour.  Steep terrain in the Back Creek basin aided in creating efficient runoff to cause the stream gauge at Back Creek at Sunrise to rise to 10.01 feet, exceeding Moderate Flood Stage set at 10 feet.  This is the highest this gauge has risen since 2008.  FLASH estimated that rainfall just upstream from the stream gauge was over 3 times greater than 1-hour Flash Flood Guidance.  CREST Unit Streamflow was estimating over 1,000 cfs per square mile, whiile CREST 1-hour Average Return Interval estimates put this rainfall at well over a 200-year event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly 3 inches of rain fell from a thunderstorm inside of a 1 hour period of time in the Big Island area, including along Camden Road.  Rainfall rates were observed to be as high as 5 inches per hour at times during the event.  Runoff from this rainfall caused Camden Road to become flooded by several inches of water and impassible.  Water was also reported by law enforcement entering a basement of a home.  FLASH (Flooded Locations and Simulated Hydrographs Project) estimated that 1-hour rainfall was about 2.5 times that of Flash Flood guidance and that this was a 25 to 50-year event per FLASH 1-Hour ARI estimates.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widely scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of June 11th in an environment of strong afternoon heating as temperatures warmed into the low to mid 80s ahead of a backdoor cold front draped across northern Virginia. CAPE values were in excess of 2,000 J/Kg and Precipitable Water values were observed to be in the 1.8 to 1.9 inch range. Weak atmospheric winds resulted in slow storm motion.  The combination of deep instability and abundant moisture resulted in storms producing high rainfall rates of 2 to locally 5 inches per hour, with 1-hour rainfall totals exceeding 3.2 inches near the City of Lynchburg.  This rainfall is a 100-year event per NOAA Atlas 14 Point Precipitation Frequency estimates.  One swift water rescue was reported in the City of Lynchburg when a vehicle was stranded in the floodwaters from Blackwater Creek.  No injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 2 and 2.5 inches of rain fell within a 90-minute period across the community of Boonsboro, at times falling at rates of 4 to 5 inches per hour. This is roughly a 10-year rainfall event per NOAA Atlas 14 Point Precipitation Frequency estimates. This rainfall caused flooding across Walnut Hollow Road at Indered Farm Road.  The road was reopened and passable after the water receded.  No damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of between 2.5 and 3 inches fell within a 90-minute period near the community of Keeling, at times falling at rates of 4 to 5 inches per hour. This is estimated to be a 10- to 25-year rainfall event per NOAA Atlas 14 Point Precipitation Frequency Estimates. The heavy rain caused a tributary of Birch Creek to overflow its banks across Richmond Highway, temporarily closing the highway until the water receded. No damage to the road was reported.

Doppler radar indicated that between 2.5 and 3 inches of rain fell in the area during a 3-hour period from a slow-moving thunderstorm.  This amount was between a 10- and 25-year rainfall event per NOAA Atlas 14 Point Precipitation Frequency estimates.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 2.5 and 3.5 inches of rain fell from a slow-moving thunderstorm across the Blackwater Creek watershed during a 90-minute period.  Rainfall rates were observed to 2 to 3 inches per hour during much of this event.  This caused flooding along Blackwater Creek, which caused water to enter apartments along Sandusky Drive.  Multiple residents of these apartments were forced to evacuate until the water receded.  In addition, an automobile became stranded in the flood water along Greenwood Drive where it crosses Blackwater Creek.  No injuries were reported and the occupants were able to escape the flooded vehicle and move to a safe location.

One storm in particular strengthened to strong levels over Buchanan County and inflicted downed trees due to gusty winds. A brief heavy downpour also resulted in flash flooding in front of a local grocery store near the town of Big Rock.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water impacted both lanes of US 460 in front of Rameys Grocery Store in the Big Rock Community.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with large hail spread northward across East Tennessee during the early morning hours of March 27, reaching southwest Virginia by late morning. These storms were associated with a warm front, which later stalled across northeast Tennessee. This stalled front was the focus of additional thunderstorms that produced damaging winds and  flooding in the evening of March 27 and into March 28.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roadways were flooded and impassable around Wise.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A southerly flow allowed for plenty of moisture ahead of a cold front. The moisture along with an unstable atmosphere caused heavy rain to be associated with thunderstorms, and this led to instances of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level rose above flood stage along the Accotink Creek at Strathmeade Springs. The water level crested at 252.76 feet on July 1st at 11:00 PM EST, before falling below flood stage at midnight. Woodburn Road and Prosperity Avenue were flooded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed or washed out due to high water across the northwest part of the county, including Crymes Road, Kings Road, and Falls Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widely scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening of July 11th.  A few of the storms proved capable of producing sporadic damaging winds and locally heavy rainfall, supported by strong instability with CAPE values reaching as high as 2,000 J/Kg across the mountains by late afternoon.  Precipitable water values at 1.5 inches, was an indication of a moist enough atmosphere to support heavy rain.  The stronger storms were observed producing rainfall amounts as high as 5 inches per hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated two inches of rain fell within an hour from a slow-moving thunderstorm across the Dry Creek drainage basin, between a 10- and 25-year rainfall event per NOAA Atlas 14 Point Precipitation Frequency estimates.  The rain was estimated to be falling at rates of three to four inches per hour per KFCX Doppler radar, and caused Dry Creek to overflow its banks and flow across Camp Road several inches deep.  No damage to the road was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving series of localized thunderstorms produced intense rainfall in excess of 11 inches during a 3- to 4-hour period of time during the evening of July 24th, 2021, which is an exceedingly rare event.  NOAA Atlas 14 Point Precipitation Estimates put this amount of rain for a 6-hour duration at well over an 1000-year rainfall event, or less than a 0.1% of occurring during any given year. Nearly all of the 10.1 miles^2 (per USGS Stream Stats) of the Sycamore Creek basin received heavy rain.  A National Water Model simulation of streamflow at the mouth of Sycamore Creek where it empties into the James River calculated a flow of 3,979 cfs.  If close to accurate, this flow would be between a 50- and 100-year flooding event per USGS Stream Stats.  However, as the basin is heavily wooded and sparsely populated, and given that the rain fell on a Saturday evening when commuting would be at a minimum, very few impacts were observed and/or reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from several inches of rain caused Sycamore Creek to rise out of its banks and flow across Sycamore Creek Road near the intersection of Woodlawn Church Road.  At around 9:40 pm EST, the rainfall triggered at least one debris flow nearby.  The flooding left large amounts of debris along the bridge crossing the creek and across the roadway.  Structural damage to the road was also observed and required repair.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite prolonged periods of dry weather before the event, deep moisture from the Gulf of Mexico pooled across the lower Mid-Atlantic ahead of an approaching cold front.  Precipitable water values by the afternoon of July 1st were estimated to have reached the 1.8 to 2 inch range.  Strong afternoon heating, combined with steepened lapse rates associated with a passing upper level disturbance, produced a highly unstable atmosphere  causing localized wind damage from severe thunderstorms. While widespread rainfall was beneficial for most, thunderstorms began to train over a few locations, producing prolonged rainfall rates of 3 to as high as 5 inches per hour, resulting in flash flooding for some locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Training thunderstorms dropped 2 to 3.5 inches of rain across the community of Blacksburg, with much of this rain falling within a 60-minute period. This caused flash flooding along Stroubles Creek, with rushing water at least a foot deep flowing across Duck Pond Drive and Plantation Road, causing both roads to be impassible.  Smithfield Road and Oak Lane were also covered by flowing water.  All roads were reopened after the flood waters receded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms associated with low pressure and a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Randolph Road was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary tapped into plenty of moisture and instability for showers and thunderstorms. Weak winds aloft caused slow moving storms, which led to instance of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US-50 Arlington Boulevard was closed at Long Branch near VA-699 Prosperity Avenue. Water was flowing across the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary tapped into plenty of moisture and instability for showers and thunderstorms. Weak winds aloft caused slow moving storms, which led to instance of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level along the Accotink Creek at Strathmeade Springs rapidly rose above flood stage at 6:46 AM EST, cresting at 254.54 feet at 9:35 AM EST. The water level fell below flood stage at 11:48 AM EST. Woodburn Road and Prosperity Avenue were flooded by at least six inches of flowing water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widely scattered thunderstorms developed in an environment of strong daytime heating on August 19th, allowing for deep instability as surface-based CAPE values were observed to be in the 1,500 to 2,500 J/Kg range during the evening for areas mostly along and east of the Blue Ridge.  The thunderstorms were fueled by deep tropical moisture, with precipitable water observed to be 1.90 inches per the August 20/00Z upper air sounding conducted by the NWS in Blacksburg.  One thunderstorm developed over the city of Roanoke shortly after 8:00 pm EDT, followed by another that moved across the city around 9:00 pm EDT.  Doppler radar estimated that between 3 and 4 inches of rain fell across portions of the city, including the downtown area, during a 75- to 90-minute period.  Two automated rain gauges, located nearby the areas of radar-estimated greatest rainfall, recorded between 2 and 2.5 inches of rain within 75 minutes, both of which are between 10- and 25-year rainfall events per NOAA Atlas 14 Point Precipitation Frequency estimates.  Given the urbanized nature of where the rainfall occurred, much of the rainfall converted directly into runoff, overwhelming the city's storm drain system.  Multiple streets near the downtown area became flooded with 1 to 2 feet of mainly standing water, but water was an estimated 4 feet deep in a few spots.  Numerous cars parked along the flooded streets had water enter the passenger area.  At least 5 water rescues were conducted by the City of Roanoke Fire & Rescue as cars attempted to drive through the flood waters and stalled.  No injuries were reported.  About an hour after heavy rain ended, the flooding had abated and most of the previously-flooded roads were passable again.  Most of this rain fell across the Tinker Creek watershed, causing the stream gauge for Tinker Creek Above Glade Creek to register a 4.5 foot rise to crest just above Action Stage (7.0 feet), before water receded again.  The National Water Model estimated the peak flow at this stream gauge to be around 2,000 cfs, which is well under a 2 year event per USGS Stream Stats.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Salem Avenue and Campbell Avenue were flooded with up to 4 feet of standing water as heavy rain overwhelmed the storm sewer system.  Five water rescues were performed as cars drove into the flood waters, causing the vehicles to stall.  No injuries were reported.  Broadcast media reported that multiple cars parked along Salem Avenue experienced water intrusion into the vehicle passenger compartments and exhaust systems, with some of the vehicle needed to be towed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary tapped into plenty of moisture and instability for showers and thunderstorms. Weak winds aloft caused slow moving storms, which led to instance of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a water rescue at the Intersection of VA-677 Old Courthouse Road and Besley Road due to high water flowing out of a creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak boundary tapped into plenty of moisture and instability for showers and thunderstorms. Weak winds aloft caused slow moving storms, which led to instance of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level along Difficult Run rapidly rose out of its banks above flood stage at 7:43 AM EST before cresting at 196.17 feet at 11:15 AM EST. The water level fell below flood stage at 7:35 PM EST.  Leigh Mill Road was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary remain draped overhead while a deep southerly flow ushered in plenty of moisture. Showers and thunderstorms resulted in heavy rainfall that led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was estimated to be about two to three feet deep on King Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary remain draped overhead while a deep southerly flow ushered in plenty of moisture. Showers and thunderstorms resulted in heavy rainfall that led to instances of flooding and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: VA-689 Chesterbrook Road was closed at Little Pimmit Run.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance crossed through the area from the west on August 19th, leading to showers with moderate to heavy rainfall expanding in coverage throughout the day. Due to the rainfall received with the remnants of Tropical Storm Fred the previous day, soil across the area was already saturated in many locations which became the most susceptible to flash flooding issues. One of those areas ended up being the observance of high water over a few roads in Buchanan County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water flowed across Route 2450 near the town of Big Rock.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance crossed through the area from the west on August 19th, leading to showers with moderate to heavy rainfall expanding in coverage throughout the day. Due to the rainfall received with the remnants of Tropical Storm Fred the previous day, soil across the area was already saturated in many locations which became the most susceptible to flash flooding issues. One of those areas ended up being the observance of high water over a few roads in Buchanan County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the town of Hurley, high water flowed across Hurley Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 657 (Ashcake Road) eastbound lanes were briefly closed due to water running over the roadway. The road remained partially closed due to water on road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front approached the Ohio Valley from the north on August 30th combined with a weak upper level disturbance. Advancing moisture seeping into the area ahead of the remnants of Hurricane Ida allowed for showers and thunderstorms to develop across the area throughout the day. ||Many of these storms were slow moving and produced heavy downpours that led to very significant flooding in the town of Hurley in Buchanan County. A local 85 year old woman died within her flooded home that evening and twenty residences had considerable damage due to Guesses Creek rising out of its banks. Many roads around the community were impassable and high water surrounded the Hurley Family Health Center. ||The risk for flooding diminished late that evening, but would continue nearby in West Virginia as the remnants of Ida surged northward.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hurley Family Health Center Building was surrounded by high water in the town of Hurley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak front near the Appalachian Mountains interacted with a warm, moist air-mass |to spark widely scattered thunderstorms. A couple of these storms produced damaging winds and penny size hail, and local rainfall rates of 3 to 4 inches per hour were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 1.5 and 2.2 inches of rain (both a 5-10 event per NOAA Atlas-14 Point Precipitation Frequency estimates) fell across the southern half of the Town of Blacksburg, including the headwaters of Cedar Run, within a 60-minute period.  Though not a particularly impressive rainfall event by most standards, flooding of Cedar Run along Cedar Run Road near Sweeny Road is known by locals to flood at times due to constricted culverts passing under the road.   Runoff from the rainfall was sufficient to overflow across Cedar Run Road several feet deep, with one automobile becoming stranded in the flood waters up to its headlights.  The occupant of the vehicle required the assistance of a swift-water rescue team, with no injuries reported.  The vehicle had to be towed out of the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms well in advance of a cold front produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Melody Road was flooded and impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated instance of flash flooding occurred from a thunderstorm in Rockingham County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mount Olivet Church Road was closed near Spotswood Trail due to high water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High standing water was blocking three lanes along Interstate 395 Northbound around VA 120.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms associated with low pressure moving from North Carolina northeast across Southeast Virginia and off the coast produced heavy rain which caused flooding and flash flooding across portions of central and eastern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported on a portion of Denbigh Boulevard in Newport News.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms associated with low pressure moving from North Carolina northeast across Southeast Virginia and off the coast produced heavy rain which caused flooding and flash flooding across portions of central and eastern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall total of 4.25 inches was reported since 1 PM. There was no confirmation of flooding, but a spotter reported that flooding was likely ongoing nearby.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of southeast Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were flooded in the central and southern portion of the city of Chesapeake, including Battlefield Boulevard and Benefit Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms along a frontal boundary produced heavy rain which caused flash flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Vehicle was stuck in high water at the intersection of Cumberland and North Harrison Streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep tropical moisture associated with the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicholas was lifted northward ahead of a strong cold front.  Precipitable water values ranging from 1.9 to 2.2 inches were carried into southern Virginia during the evening of the 21st. Warm rain processes produced localized rainfall rates of 2- to 3-inches per hour during the late evening of the 21st into early on the 22nd, enhanced by orographic lift up the Blue Ridge.  FLASH (Flooded Locations And Simulated Hydrographs Project) data indicated bands of rainfall were producing amounts of 1.5 times flash flood guidance across Floyd and Montgomery Counties, with 10-year annual return intervals in spots near the crest of the Blue Ridge before rainfall diminished toward dawn.  During late afternoon into the evening on the 22nd, a line of thunderstorms developed further east as the cold front advanced across the mountains.   The line of storms stalled across portions of Botetourt and Bedford Counties, while CAPE values of 1,500 J/Kg, provided enough instability to support rainfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour.  Despite antecedent dry conditions, the areas heavy rain was sufficient to produce localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from heavy rainfall, a radar estimated 3.5 to 4 inches inside of a 3-hour period, caused Johnson Creek to flood out of its banks.  East Fork Road was flooded by the creek and impassible until the flooding receded.  No damage to the road was reported.  Rainfall rates were as high as 3 inches per hour per FLASH estimates.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from heavy rainfall, a radar estimated 4 to 4.5 inches inside of a 3-hour period, caused Dry Run to flood out of its banks. Marigold Lane was flooded by Dry Run and impassible until the flooding receded. No damage to the road was reported. Rainfall rates were as high as 3 to 4 inches per hour per FLASH estimates.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Ida produced widespread flooding along with instances of flash flooding across the area. Tropical moisture infiltrated the area and there were moderate amounts of instability as well. This combined with the lift provided from the remnants of Ida led to heavy rainfall during this time. Rainfall amounts averaged around 1-3 near and east of Interstate 95, with amounts around 2 to 5 inches across portions of northern Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water rapidly developed along 5th Street and Harris Road due to heavy rainfall, causing the road to be closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong heating during the afternoon created an unstable airmass with surface-based CAPE values in excess of 3,000 J/Kg across Tazewell County and the surrounding area, while precipitable water values varied between 1.6 and 1.8 inches.  One thunderstorm developed to the near Richlands at around 6:15 pm EDT and lingered for about 75 minutes before weakening. This storm produced prolonged rainfall rates of 3 to 4 inches per hour.  Runoff from this storm resulted in small stream flooding of tributaries of the Clinch River, including Little Town Hill Creek, which flooded across U.S. Highway 460 and Hillcreek Road.  MRMS FLASH (Flooded Locations and Simulated Hydrograph) data indicated a 3-hour Average Recurrence Interval between a 40- and 75-year event, while estimated rainfall was up to 1.8 times that of 3-hour flash flood guidance.  CREST (Coupled Routing and Excess Storage) Unit Streamflow in the area ranged from 300 to 500 cfs per square mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused Little Town Hill Creek to overflow its banks, flooding across Hillcreek Road, as well as U.S. Highway 460 to a depth of up to 4 feet.  One car was caught in the floodwater and the occupant had to be rescued by emergency responders.  Flooding across Highway 460 lasted for around two hours before flooding receded and the highway was reopened.  No damage to the road was reported, but with some damage to the flooded vehicle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front, drifting northward from the Carolinas across the lower Mid-Atlantic, triggered scattered thunderstorms with heavy rain.  Strong heating during the afternoon supported surface-based CAPE values rising into the 2,000 to 2,500 J/Kg range, while precipitable water values ranged from around 1.5 inches along the Blue Ridge to in excess of 1.8 inches across the central Piedmont of Virginia and North Carolina.  Wind speeds through 700 mb were generally around 10 knots, supporting slow cell movement that would contribute to prolonged heavy rainfall over some locations. Many of the storms produced rainfall at 3 to 5 inch per hour rates, which resulted in flash flooding of small streams in the local area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused a tributary of Mill Creek to overflow its banks and flood across Old Chapel Road near the intersection with Kennel Hill Lane.  The road was reopened after flooding receded, with no damage reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The approach of a cold front, daytime heating, and increasing low level instability, led to the development of isolated showers and thunderstorms. One of these storms reached severe levels and produced damaging winds. Additionally, lightning strikes caused damage  to homes and trees. A female occupant of one of these homes sustained injury and had to obtain medical help. Thunderstorms began training along the Bath and Rockbridge County border during the afternoon, producing rainfall rates as high as 5 inches per hour.  CREST Unit Streamflow in this area rose in excess of 600 cfs per mi^2, and 1-hour rainfall amounts were estimated to be 1.5 times as high as flash flood guidance.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from a series of training thunderstorms caused Gochenhour Branch to flood out of its bank and across Brattons Run Road up to 3 feet deep.  No damage was reported and the road was reopened after flooding receded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary remained parked over the Central Appalachians on the last week of July, which kept southwest Virginia suseptible to heavy downpours from daily showers and thunderstorms for a prolonged period of time. Copious amounts of late evening rain on the 27th resulted in nighttime flash flooding in Dickenson County, where pockets of 2 to 4 inches fell. Local creeks and streams rose out of their banks early in the morning of July 28th and resulted in water on roadways and washing out several residential bridges north of Clintwood. High water also entered into the Clintwood Public Library overnight and flooded the first floor of the building.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water entered into the Clintwood Public Library and permeated on the first floor. Flooding was also observed along Dickenson Highway and Coeburn Road.
